title: EGEBERG'S OUSTER IS EXPECTED SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Sources at the Department of Health, Education and welfare said today that Dr. Roger O. Egeberg would be relieved of his post as the top Federal health officer, probably after the first of the year.

title: Place Without Doors at Long Wharf
description: NEW HAVENThere is a certain kind of French play that never seems to be par ticularly popular with Ameri can audiences, which is a pity for American audiences. I am thinking of plays by au thors such as JeanJacques Bernard, Henri di Monther lant or even perhaps Jean Anouilh. What those dis parate playwrights have in common is a love of conver sation for its own sake, and the gradual disclosure of the recesses of the heart. They can be slow, they can even be wordy, but they can also fire the imagination.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Four years of study of the landlocked salmon, lake trout and brook trout population of Maine's famous Moosehead Lake will result in yearly stockings of salmon and a recommendation that the present legal length limit for that species in the lake be dropped to 12 inches.

title: Young German Voters Impress Elders
description: BONN, Nov. 30  The new 18to21yearold voters in West Germany appear to be conscientious, highly indepen dent and rather sober, contrary to the fears of some of their elders, who had expected vio lence or apathy.

title: 76ERS OVERCOME BULLETS BY 10498
description: Celtics Top Braves,109106, in TwinBill Opener

title: Extending Family Planning
description: The nation's population has been officially put at 204,765,770 as of last April 1, an increase of about 24 million over the figure of a decade ago. In 1917, as Presi dent Nixon recently pointed out in a special message on population problems, the total number of Americans passed 100 million after three full centuries of steady growth. A mere halfcentury later, in 1967, the 200million mark was passed.

title: U.S. FAILS TO ORBIT LARGE TELESCOPE
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP)The largest space telescope ever launched tailed to reach orbit tonight when protective nose cone did not separate from the booster rocket. The failure ruined $98.5million project that could have unlocked many secrets of the universe.

title: Hanoi Seems to Softeri Terms on a Vote
description: PARIS, Nov. 30  North Vietnam indicated tonight that it might not oppose internation al supervision of elections in South Vietnam if they were held under a coalition govern merit  a government that the Communists are trying to pro mote in place of the present one in Saigon.

title: CENTER FIELDERS ARE EXCHANGED
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 The California Angels con tinued their offseason dealing today when they completed sixplayer trade with the Chi cago White Sox.

title: Nixon Is Irked by Return Of Defector to Soviet Ship
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  President Nixon called today for a very full and immediate investigation of the Coast Guard's refusal to grant polit ical sanctuary to the Lithua nian sailor who tried to flee last week from a Soviet fishing boat.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Foreign Stock Indexes

title: TRADE BILL CURBS MADE NARROWER BY SENATE PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Senate Finance Committee substantially rewrote the House passed trade legislation today in an evident effort to make the bill less objectionable to the Nixon Administration and free trade forces generally.

title: Lunch Crowd Here Eats Up Ali's Punching, Poetry and PutOn
description: As he pulled on his white satin trunks, Muhammad Ali surveyed his small dressing room audience yesterday.

title: Pierre's New Supper Club, La Foret, Opens Tonight
description: La Foret, a new supper club specializing in haute cuisine, will open tonight at 7:30 at the Pierre, 61st Street and Fifth Avenue. The club has been de signed by Maurice Carrere of Maxim's in Paris. It will be open Tuesdays through Satur days for dinner, supper and dancing from 7:30 until 2:30.

title: 'Adam at 6 A.M.' Sneers at Mid-America
description: At one point in "Adam at 6 A.M.," Adam Gaines (Michael Douglas), a supposedly hip, young, California college professor visiting some distant relatives in Missouri, is questioned about his movie preferences by a beer-guzzling cousin, who likes Julie Andrews movies. Adam looks pained. He prefers films such as "Blow-Up." The cousin scoffs, and the movie, which aspires to a superiority it never deserves, scoffs at the cousin. The movie knowsand assumes that we agreethat anyone who likes Antonioni must be all right, and that anyone who likes Julie Andrews is a card-carrying, right-wing, war-mongering, all-American jerk.This is, to say the least, rather simplistic logic. (As a matter of fact, I have a friend who can make quite a case in behalf of the metaphysical splendor of what he calls The Cinema of Julie Andrews.) It is, however, typical of "Adam at 6 A.M.," a movie full of mid-cult opinions about the vacuity of mid-cult American life. It looks authentic (much of it was filmed in rural Missouri), but its value crises sound very much like those that people who live in Beverly Hills wish they could have if they weren't too busy making movies like this.The principal problem of the film is that, for the plot to work, Adam Gaines must be a bigger jerk than the people he, and the movie, put down. Tired of his superficial parents, his beautiful mistress and the perfunctory demands of his academic career, Adam goes back to his family roots in the Middle West, where he spends the summer working as a manual laborer on a land-clearing gang, close to what somebody describes, quite seriously, as "God's own mud."For a while Adam thinks he has found some answers, first from Harvey, a fellow crew member who works all day with his hands and stays up half the night studying to become a TV repairman. There is also Jerri Jo Hopper, the quintessential, small-town beauty queen, who makes very good apple pies and is superb in bed.Harvey, however, turns out to be a fraud, a spineless boozer and petty gambler, fated to spend his life migrating from one temporary job to another. Even more of a shock to Adam (although it's apparent to the audience from her first appearance) is the revelation that Jerri Jo dreams of a French provincial house in a suburb and will spend her life seeking truth in the pages of the Ladies' Home Journal.Perhaps if Adam had spent a little less time looking at movies like "Blow-Up" and a little more time watching Julie Andrews movies, or even television, he might not be quite as shocked as he is by what he finds in Middle America. But then, of course, there wouldn't be any movie."Adam at 6 A.M." is based on an original screenplay by Stephen and Elinor Karpf (their first) and is the first directorial effort of Robert Scheerer, who has directed some quite classy television specials, including Barbra Streisand's "A Happening in Central Park." The film, unfortunately, has the same kind of classy and (under these circumstances) fake looklots of zoom shots (backed by a loud rock score), traveling shots and images photographed either through glass or as reflections.The performances, however, are attractive. Mr. Douglas hasn't much to do but look bemused (as he drives his Porche) or pained (as he realizes everyone else's stupidity), but Joe Don Baker could win this year's Jack Nicholson award as the good-natured Harvey, and Lee Purcell is absolutely right, down to the slightest pout, as Jerri Joe, the kind of girl who doesn't think you should go all the way on a first date."Adam at 6 A.M." opened yesterday at the R.K.O. 59th Street Twin Theaters where, beginning at 11 A.M., the feature starts every hour, on the hour, in one of the two auditoriums.

title: Tennis Patrons To Have a Party
description: The Eastern Tennis Patrons Party, an annual dinner dance, will be held Thursday at the Pierre. The patrons group tries to encourage an interest in tennis for children in the metropolitan area.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Nov. 24:

title: Mrs. Evelyn Lehman, 78, Dies; Society Figure Aided Charities
description: Mrs. Evelyn Schiffer Lehman, who was a wellknown society figure, died yesterday in New York Hospital after a long ill ness. She was 78 years old and lived at 32 East 64th Street.

title: Army Town: Brides, Ricebirds and Hawks
description: COLUMBUS, Ga.At sun down thousands of ricebirds that have hunted for food all day in the fields and mead ows of South Georgia return to Columbus to nest in a row of pin oaks along a grassy median strip on Broadway, the city's main shopping street. Darting between tree tops in flying phalanxes, the small, black of birds fill the street with whistles and chirping that make Broadway in the early evening sound like a tropical rainforest. Ap parently the ricebirds learned long ago to prefer the neon lighted security of city life to the cold, dark piney woods and its dangers.

title: The Pentagon Folks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30People not lucky enough to have Pentagon folks living in their neighborhoods were probably puzzled last week when Secretary Laird called the bombing of North Vietnam a protective re action. Didn't our planes bomb the bejeebers out of North Vietnam? they probably asked. Isn't bombing the bejeebers out of somebody a bombing?

title: Scott Stooped in 9th Roundl
description: PARIS, Nov. 30 (AP)Max Cohen of France stopped Fraser Scott of Seattle in the ninth round of their 10round mid dleweight bout tonight.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Albert C. Nolte Is Dead at 79; Patent Lawyer Was Engineer
description: PLANDOME, L. I., Nov. 30 Albert C. Nolte, a patent engi neer and lawyer, died today in Manhasset Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 79 years old and lived at 38 Willets Lane here and at 475 Park Avenue in New York.

title: Poverty Agency Awards Grants To Controversial Law Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30The Office of Economic Opportu nity, sensitive to the contro versy that arose last week over the dismissal of two men who directed its legal services pro grain, announced today that it had given new grants to two of the most controversial local agencies in the program.

title: Man's Body Found in Queens
description: The police in Glendale, Queens, tried yesterday to identify the body of a naked man, with the tattoo of a boxer on his left forearm, found floating in the Ridgewood res ervoir near the Interborough Parkway and Cypress Avenue.

title: Hurricane Unit Ends Tour
description: MIAMI, Nov. 30 (UPI)  The National Hurricane Center wound up today its hurricane watch for 1970, a year that produced one of history's most damaging hurricanes  Celia. The hurricane, which went ashore at Corpus Christi, Tex., in October, caused damage of nearly $454million and left 11 dead in Texas, plus 5 killed in Cuba during its early stage.

title: WINNERS IMPROVE PLAYOFF CHANCES
description: ATLANTA, Nov. 30 (UPI)  The Miami Dolphins blended the power of Larry Csonka, the speed of Eugene (Mercury) Morris and the timely passing of Bob Griese to heat the At lanta Falcons, 207, tonight in the National Football League.

title: Major Independents
description: Major Independents

title: CANTERBURY FINDS  APARTHEID IS RISING
description: LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) The Archbishop of Canter bury reports that apartheid is on the increase in South Africa.

title: Appeal to City for Firm Stand On Union Demands Denounced
description: Leaders of unions represent ing city employes were sharply critical yesterday of Ralph Gross, president of the Com merce and Industry Associa tion, who had urged the city stand firm against what he called outrageous demands by its firemen, policemen and sanitation workers.

title: TOTAL IN CENSUS IS 204.7 MILLION
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The 1970 census counted 204, 765,770 Americans, 24 million more than in 1960, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Laing Twists Life's Verse Into Knots
description: Ronald D. Laing, the Scot tish psychoanalyst famous for suggesting that insanity may be a sane reaction to an insane world, has now taken refuge in poetry and sketch to get his message across.

title: HAROLD WILCOX DIES; CONSERVATIONIST, 59
description: Harold Hinton Wilcox, a con servationist, died yesterday at his home after a brief illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 2 Fifth Avenue.

title: Novelist's Letter on the Nobel Prize
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 30Fol lowing, in translation from the Russian, is the text of a letter from the author Alek sandr 1. Solzhenitsyn to the Swedish Academy explaining his decision against going to Stockholm to accept the 1970 Nobel Prize:

title: Guyana Outlines Proposal To Control Bauxite Concern
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, Nov. 30The Guyanan Govern ment's plans to acquire a con trolling interest in the bauxite industry, owned by United States and Canadian interests, have been outlined by Prime Minister Forbes Burnham.

title: New System for Panama Canal Recommended by Nixon Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  A Presidential commission recom mended to President Nixon to day that a joint United States Panama unified canal system be set up to operate the present Panama Canal and a new water way it proposed be built about 10 miles away.

title: Screen: The End of Summer at the New Yorker
description: Of the films by Yasujiro Ozu that I have seen, The End of Summer (1961), which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater, is the best, the most subtle, the most ambitious and the most successful in achieving the blend of comic insight and tragic vision that informs this director's cinema. It is a late work (Ozu died in 1963, at the age of 60) and it tells several stories at once, touching upon a broad range of experience. It has a qual ity of luminous intelligence exceptional even in a career for which such intelligence was generally the controlling noint of view.

title: MAURICE E. WOLF, MEDICAL TEACHER
description: Dr. Maurice E. Wolf, a pro fessor of medicine in France until World War II, died yes terday in Mount Sinai Hospital, after a short illness. He was 75 years old and lived at 50 Central Park West.

title: Tree in Rockefeller Center
description: Rockefeller Center's 60foot high Christmas treea three ton Vermont white spruce was hoisted into an upright po sition yesterday at the sunken plaza skating rink as excited children watched. It will be lighted Dec. 10 at 5:30 P.M. and remain on display until Jan. 3.

title: Cuban Exiles Plead Guilty To Murder Plot Charges
description: Two Cuban exiles pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday to a charge of at tempted conspiracy to commit murder in connection with ter rorist activities here against the Cuban Government of Pre mier Fidel Castro.

title: Brooklyn Man Seized in Slaying Of 4 in East Village Bar Holdup
description: A 22yearold Brooklyn man was arrested last night as a suspect in the holdup murders of four persons in an East Vil lage bar last week.

title: SHOWDOWN NEARS ON TAXI CONTRACT
description: The lengthy negotiations in the taxi industry appeared yes terday to be heading toward an agreement or a breakdown later this week.

title: Less Optimism on Berlin
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev's optimism about resolving the Berlin problem, expressed in a speech in Soviet Armenia, contrasts starkly with the traffic slowdown imposed by East Germany on the autobahns linking West Berlin with West Germany. The Soviet Communist leader's words also seem at odds with a pronounced hardening of Moscow's position on Berlin in the last two meetings of Big Four ambassadors in the former German capital.

title: Botanical Garden Is Given Right to Grant Certificates
description: The New York Botanical Gar den in the Bronx reported yes terday that the New York State Department of Education has given its approval for the gar den to grant staterecognized certificates to its horticulture students.

title: 21 Hurt as Bus Overturns
description: SHARON, Mass., Nov. 1 (AP) Twentyone high school and junior high school pupils were injured this morning when a school bus ran off a slippery road near here and overturned.

title: Montreal Forgets Woes to Hail Grey Cup Champions
description: MONTREAL, Nov. 30  Not since before the Black Monday of Oct. 5, when separatist zealots kidnapped a British diplomat and fol lowed a few days later with the kidnapmurder of a Cab inet minister, has Montreal shone and sparkled in its wellknown joie de vivre im age as it did today.

title: Aide Denies Kennedy Danced Night Before de Gaulle Rites
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) A spokesman for Senator Ed ward M. Kennedy today denied as preposterous a report in British weekly newspaper that the Senator went to nightclubs with an Italian princess the night before he attended the memorial service for de Gaulle.

title: SOVIET IS WARNED ON BERLIN TIEUP
description: BERLIN, Nov. 30The United States, Britain and France have warned the Soviet Union that East German harassment on Berlin's vital access routes endangered the success of the current fourpower talks aimed at improving the situation in and around this isolated city, it was disclosed today.

title: Right to Jury Trial Ruled Retroactive
description: A Federal judge here ruled yesterday that when the United States Supreme Court ordered the city's Criminal Court to give jury trials last June 22, its order should have benefited defendants who had been con victed without a jury in the two years before that.

title: Two Pet Llamas Are Shot
description: KENT, Conn., Nov. 30 (UPI)  The Connecticut State Police were investigating today the shooting to death of two pet llamas owned by Cyril H. Moore Jr., a New York City lawyer. he found the 300pound animals Mr. Moore told the police that early Saturday morning. Both had been shot at close range with a shotgun. He said he heard the shots and ran from his house in time to see a man run from a fence enclosing the llamas, jump into a car, and drive off. The animals were worth $400 to $500 each, Mr. Moore said.

title: BLACKPOWER CHIEF IN BRITAIN RESIGNS
description: OXFORD, England, Nov. 30 (AP)Britain's most prominent black power leader quit the movement today, saying his new aim was friendship be tween black and white.

title: Senate Backs Compromise On MutualFund Regulation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) The Senate approved today a compromise bill intended to provide increased protection for investors in the $50billion mu tual fund industry.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Intelligence. The President appointed former Gov. John B. Connally Jr. of Texas to his Foreign Intelligence Ad visory Board. The board is composed of 10 members and is headed by Adm. George W. Anderson jr., re tired, former Chief of Naval Operations.

title: ROCKFFELLER SAYS NIXON IS WEIGHING STATE AID PLANS
description: Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that President Nixon was reconsidering the whole question of revenue sharing, and will be coming up with meaningful recommendations to enable the states and mu nicipalities to continue essen tial local services.

title: Italy's First Divorce Law Is Approved by Parliament
description: ROME, Tuesday, Dec. 1 The Italian Parliament gave final approval early this morn ing to the institution of divorce in Catholic Italy, where such legislation has been one of the most bitterly contested changes of the postwar period.

title: A Catholic Leader Says Ethnic Work Will Be Continued
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The principal planner of the Roman Catholic Church's ef forts to develop social and eco nomic programs for the urban ethnic communities said today that the work would be un diminished despite recent or ganizational changes in the United States Catholic Con ference.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL IN CAPACITY CUT
description: The Bethlehem Steel Cor poration indicated yesterday that it would reduce permanently the capacity of its mill at Lackawanna, N.Y., by about 28 per cent.

title: PROFITS SET MARK AT CARRIER CORP.
description: The Carrier Corporation achieved record sales and earn ings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31, according to the an nual report issued yesterday by the leading diversified air con ditioning producer.

title: Rentzel Charged in Morals Case
description: DALLAS, Nov. 30Lance Rentzel, the Dallas Cowboys wide receiver, today was charged with indecent exposure and released on bail.

title: Bridge:
description: HOUSTON, Nov. 30The Reisinger knockout team championship, the conclud ing event of the American Contract Bridge League's fall nationals at the Rice Hotel, ended in a technical tie early today between the world champion Dallas Aces and a group led by Peter Pender of Sausalito. Calif.

title: $650Million Credit
description: The McDonnell Douglas Cor poration announced yesterday that it had reached an agree ment for a $650million revolv ing credit with 17 banks head ed by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: POLICE WILL CLEAR DISABLED VEHICLES
description: The Police Department will help, free of charge, to unsnarl traffic tieups caused by dis abled vehicles during the morn ing and evening rush hours on both the East River Drive and the West Side Highway.

title: AN ATTORNEY MISSES TATE TRIAL SESSION
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 The TateLaBianca murder trial limped along today, even though one defense attorney was miss ing, presumably trapped by flooding at a mountain spa where he had spent the week end.

title: HELEN M. SPENCER
description: SMITHTOWN, L. I., Nov. 30  Helen Mitchell Spencer, retired teacher, died at her home here yesterday after short illness. She was 83 years old.

title: Lindsay Inagarates A Methadone Center
description: Mayor Lindsay went to the Washington Heights District Health Center on West 168th Street yesterday afternoon to officially open one of the first of the city's 20 new neighborhood  based metha done maintenance centers for heroin addicts. He described the treatment program as a breakthrough in the large scale attack on the plague of narcotics.

title: Ribicoff introduces 2 Bills
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) Senator Abraham A. Ribi coff introduced today two bills that would tie the suburbs to the inner cities in a nationwide school integration plan. The (school measure would require that suburban school districts as well as those in the inner city be integrated over a 10 year period. Under the housing proposal, communities where new Federal, Federalcontrac tor and state installations are about to be built or expanded would be required to guarantee adequate housing.

title: HANUKKAH FESTIVAL HELD IN THE GARDEN
description: At the 20th annual Hanukkah Festival in Madison Square Garden last night, Sophie Mas low offered one Biblical recita tion and two situations from the 20thcentury Jewish experi ence, exile and imprisonment. The story of Samson was clearly the strongest.

title: Two Views on the Welfare Plan
description: WASHINGTONSo great is the aversion to welfare ht the minds of many American people and Congress men that we seem all but powerless to reform it. On the one hand, there is no groundswell in Congress to cut back benefits now being provided. But nei ther can members of the Senate Fi nance Committee convince themselves that added investments are necessary as They would be in the case of a failing businessto put the welfare system on a sound basis.

title: Washington Says Its U2 Flights Over Suez Ended 3 Weeks Ago
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 The United States halted flights of U2 photographic planes over the Suez Canal area three weeks ago, officials here dis closed today.

title: Teachers in Hartford Vote To Continue Their Strike
description: HARTFORD, Nov. 30 (UPI) A strike by 700 members of the Hartford Federation of Teach ers entered its third week to day after the members voted unanimously yesterday to con tinue the walkout.

title: Financial Programs, Inc., Is Suspended by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)The Securities and Ex change Commission today sus pended, for 30 days beginning tomorrow, the brokerdealer registration of Financial Pro grams, Inc., Denver, end sus pended Thomas J. Herbert, the concern's president, from as sociation with any broker dealer for 30 days.

title: No Strategy for Growth
description: For the past thirty years our population has been growing and shifting. The result is exemplified in the vast areas of rural America, emptying out of people and of promise. A third of our counties lost population in the sixties. The violent and decayed central cities of our great metropolitan complexes are the most conspicuous area of failure in American life today.

title: Judge Backs State In Ban on Selling Crocodile Items
description: A state has a right to protect endangered wildlife, even far from its borders, a Federal judge ruled yesterday in effect, as he refused to enjoin New York State restrictions on the importation and sale of articles made from the skin of such animals.

title: Venezuelan Salaries Stolen
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 30 (UPI)Thieves made off today with the salaries of President Rafael Caldera and highranking government officials. Some 500,000 bolivars ($110,000) were taken from a safe in the White Palace building, facing the presidential palace.

title: Panel on Aging Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)  Representative David H. Pryor, who drew national at tention to conditions in nurs ing homes last month, an nounced today that he would ask Congress in January to create a House select commit tee on aging. The Arkansas Democrat sponsored a national forum in October at which variety of witnesses testified that many nursing home pa tients lived amid filth, bru tality and neglect.

title: Fete to Celebrate UNICEF Birthday
description: Danny Kaye will cut birthday cake on the stage after his Dec. 11 performance of Two by Two for every one who takes part in the theater party that evening at the Imperial Theater in be half of the United Nations Children's Fund.

title: American Embassy Damaged by a Bomb In Pnompenh Blast
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tues day, Dec. 1 (UPI)  A bomb rocked the United States Em bassy this morning, ripping through five rooms and knock ing out the front section of the white threestory structure.

title: British Soccer
description: British Soccer

title: Police Seek Information On HitandRun Car Here
description: The Police Department yes terday asked for the help of the public in trying to apprehend the driver of a car that killed a 58yearold man in midtown over the weekend.

title: Blackman and McDonald to Get East CoachofYear Awards
description: Bob Blackman, whose un defeated Dartmouth team won the Ivy League cham pionship, was named by the Football Writers Association of New York yesterday as the East's universitydivision coach of the year, and he will receive the first Joseph M.

title: HILL OF LANDFILL BACKED FOR S.I.
description: The City Planning Commis sion yesterday recommended the mounding of landfill rather than the use of super incinerators as the best imme diate answer to the city's awe some refuse disposal problem.

title: SOYBEANS ARE HIT BY SELLING SPREE
description: Heavy profit taking sent soy bean futures prices down yes terday on the Chicago Board of Trade In a wild spree of selling after prices had risen slightly at the opening of trading. The same was true of corn and wheat futures prices.

title: Judge Assails Young Lords, Orders Them From Church
description: The partial takeover of the First Spanish Methodist Church in East Harlem by the Young Lords was criticized by a state judge yesterday as interfering with the most precious con stitutional rights of the parish ioners.

title: Reagan to Freeze Costs To Meet Threat of Deficit
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 30  Gov. Ronald Reagan de clared today what amounted to a state of fiscal emergency to cope with the prospective deficit of $150million threat ening to wipe out the thin sur plus left in the current year's state budget.

title: U.S. Aid Official Visits Pakistani Cyclone Area
description: DACCA, Pakistan, Nov. 30 (Reuters)An American offi cial arrived here today to dis cuss projected aid of $100 million for survivors of the tidal wave and cyclone that struck East Pakistan on Nov. 12. The official toll has been put at 175,000, but some estimates are twice as high.

title: Bill Rates Register an Advance At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: FARM SUPPORT BILL IS SIGNED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) President Nixon signed today a threeyear farm bill that estab lishes for the first time a ceil ing on the amount of Federal subsidy payments a farmer may receive.

title: Stock Market Surges
description: The stock market surged dramatically yesterday in the heaviest trading in al most two months. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.74 points to close at 794.09, its best level since the market rout in May. A total of 17.7 million shares changed hands. Details on Page 67.

title: GARCON DEFEATS CAKEWALK EASILY
description: Robyn Smith, a 24yearold graduate of Stanford Univer sity, who plays touch football as well as she rides horses, had an eventful day at Aqueduct yesterday. She guided Garcon of the Hobeau Farm to a front running victory in the third race on the card, and many in the crowd of 25,166 cheered her accomplishment. Her mount had a margin of 1 lengths over the runnerup, the longshot Cakewalk, in the sixfurlong sprint.

title: Books of The Times
description: AMERICAN GROTESQUE. An Account of the Clay ShawJim Garrison Affair in the City of New Orleans. By lames Kirkwood. 669 pages. Simon & Schuster. $11.95.

title: 3D BASEMAN GOES IN GRABBAG POOL
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 The Washington Senators, who recently acquired Denny Mc Lain and Curt Flood, added an other celebrated difficult case to their roster today when they drafted Joe Foy from the New York Mets.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Murtagh Lets Panther Jury Hear Two Recordings
description: Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh yesterday permit ted the jury at the conspiracy trial of 13 Black Panthers to hear a tape recording that he had previously banned.

title: Upset Stirs Jet Playoff Hopes, But One Loss Will Dash Them
description: As incredible as it may seem, the New York Jets have mathematical opportunity to qualify for the National Foot ball League playoffs as the secondplace team with the best record in the American Conference, but it will require a combination of several cir cumstances.

title: Head of SST Program Replies to Economists
description: A document said to reflect the views of key Administra tion officials accuses a group of antiSST economists of a basic lack of comprehension of how the industry works.

title: Italian Movie, 'The Seducers' Is at Embassy
description: That affluent Italians have problems not common to the lower classes is amply illustrated in a film aptly titled "The Seducers," a teasing skin flick masquerading as social comment and adventure. It was exposed yesterday at the Embassy. But despite its dubbed-in English dialogue and its largely undraped dolls, this Italian import simply proves that surface sex, not the problem, really, is being purveyed here. Unfortunately it's not too rousing a gimmick, in view of all the explicit fare that's been exhibited hereabouts in the recent past.In essence, all the angst in "The Seducers" is generated by Maud de Belleroche, playing a Medusa-like, oil-rich matron with exotic sexual appetites, who has brought Maurizio Bonuglia, a hip, blond oprator; his wife, Rosalba Neri, and their equally free-swinging girl friend, Edwige Fenech, aboard her yacht to arouse the manly instincts of her 20-year-old son, Ruggero Miti, who still plays with his toy trains.Despite all the pairing off, there are complications, naturally, when a simple peasant girl, Ewa Aulin (she played the title role in "Candy," it may be recalled) is enticed aboard from her island home to have a go at the son, who seems to admire her. And there's her loutish fisherman-husband, who fouls things up when he turns up seeking his missing wife and ends up being seduced and knocked off.Those plot convolutions are unimportant actually. The ladies, to be specific, as well as the men, may be uncomfortable with the rudimentary dialogue and the melodramatic problems, but they're photogenic and seem at ease with their sex simulations. It would not be ungallant to indicate that it all ends tragically, like an ancient Italian opera, with the confused, addled son dispatching mama and his girl friend. His I.Q. couldn't have been that low, considering all the disturbing improbabilities of "The Seducers."

title: Stallworth, Bench Living Up to Raves Of Knicks'
description: There were 15,000 basket ball fans at Madison Square Garden for the preseason game with the Milwaukee Bucks in October of 1969, and before the game most of them stood up and cheered. The shouting was for David Allen Stallworth, the 29yearold Knick forward. who had sat out two seasons recuperating from a heart attack he suffered on March 7, 1967, in San Francisco. There were tears in Stallworth's eyes that night. Stallworth played in all 82 regular sea son and 19 playoff games in the Knicks drive to their first National Basketball Associa tion championship last sea son. At first, it was obvious that Red Holzman, the Knick coach, allowed him only a few minutes playing time, but it didn't take Stallworth long to prove he was back to stay.

title: POLICE WILL UNIFY INTELLIGENCE ARM
description: The separate and sometimes competing Police Department units collecting intelligence on organized crime, gambling and subversive organizations will be merged in a single organiza tion.

title: Buying Furniture For Child's Room
description: The Children's Workbench and its grownup counterpart, the Workbench, have just opened another branch in midtown, and it is the largest, and one of the handsomest of its seven stores. There are three selling floors in the store on the corner of Park Avenue South and 32d Street, and about half the space is devoted to furniture for children. Among the newer things are odd  shaped tables that can be used separately or fitted together for numerous purposes. One shape is rectangular, the other a trapezoid. They are each $45, and have red matte linoleum tops and are made of natural birch. There are also chairs ($22.50) and stools ($17.50) to go with them, with orange lacquered seats.

title: GEN. FREDERICK, LED 45TH DIVISION AT 37
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 30 (AP)  Maj. Gen. Robert T. Frederick. the Army's youngest division commander in France during World War II, died last evening of a heart ailment at Stanford Hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: SAFETY STEPS TAKEN ON DEADLY PESTICIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI) The Agriculture Department announced today a series of mostly voluntary safety precau tions to protect against acci dents with parathion, a deadly bug destroyer that also kills people when carelessly handled.

title: Discount Rate Cut to 5% For 2d Drop in 3 Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Federal Reserve Board an nounced today the second re duction in the discount rate in thee weeks, from 5 to 5 percent.

title: Ling Is Beginning From Alpha Again
description: DALLAS, Nov. 30A new business entity with the sym bolic name of OmegaAlpha, Inc., will be used by financier James J. Ling as the vehicle for a fresh start.

title: SENATE APPROVES $2.2 BILLION IN AID
description: WASHINGTON. Nov. 30 The Senate voted 44 to 31 to day to approve a $2.2billion appropriation for economic and military foreign aid in the cur rent fiscal year.

title: Amex Index Posts Biggest Advance Since September
description: The American Stock Ex change scored its biggest ad vance in more than two months yesterday as volume swelled to its highest level in more than a month.

title: City Planning Board Asks 1.6Billion Capital Budget
description: The City Planning Commission, stressing that inflation was preventing some major construction, proposed yester day a capital budget of $1.6billion for fiscal 197172 It gave top priority to education, mass transit and improvement of the environment, as urged by the Mayor.

title: Baylor on Shelf 3 Months
description: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 (AP)Elgin Baylor will under go surgery for a torn Achilles tendon that may sideline the Los Angeles Laker captain un til March 1, the National Bas ketball Association club an nounced last night.

title: Cuozzo, Not Seriously Injured, Hopes to Face Bears Saturday
description: Minnesota's Gary Cuozzo, quarterback of the team with the best record in pro football, does not have a broken right ankle and will attempt to play on Saturday against Chicago. Cuozzo twisted the ankle absorbing a Jet blitz in the first period of Sunday's game. Bob Lee.

title: Restaurant That Originated With a Harem Wife's Bad Temper
description: MARRAKECH, MoroccoOne of the most intriguing, one of the smallest and potentially one of the most enchanting hostels in the world will open to the public here next year. It is in the heart of the Medina, the bustling Old City here, and the new residence will be part of a restaurant called La Maison Arabe, which has been praised by two French critics, Henri Gault and Christian Mil lau, authors of restaurant guides, as being the greatest restaurant in the world.

title: Devaluation Alternative For Danes: Jobless Rise
description: COPENHAGEN, Nov. 30 Danish authorities have ruled out another currency devalua tion to resolve what has been called the intractable bal anceofpayments deficit and are trying to prepare the nation for the alternativewhat could be a steep rise in unemploy ment.

title: FUND IS APPROVED FOR JAIL REPAIRS
description: Following up earlier action by the Board of Estimate, the City Council yesterday agreed to amend this year's capital budget to add an appropriation of $1million to pay for damage done by rioting prisoners in city lails this year.

title: MRS. HAROLD P. DENTON
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Mrs. Eliza Peachy Denton, widow of Harold Pomeroy Den ton, who had been managing editor of The World in New York and The Washington Eve ning Star, died yesterday at her home. She was 95 years old.

title: Report of Treatment for Sickle Cell Anemia Evokes Guarded Optimism From Researchers on Disease
description: Doctors conducting research into possible cures for sickle cell anemia expressed guarded optimism yesterday in reac tion to the announcement that a treatment for the incurable, hereditary blood disease had been found.

title: Miss Kilborne, J. P. Cornwell Plan Wedding
description: Miss Katharine Skinner Kilborne and James Perry Cornwell plan to be married next June.

title: Dean Orders Closing Of C. W. Post Radio In Obscenity Airing
description: BROOKVILLE, L. I., Nov. 30 C.W. Post College's student :run FM radio station was closed down today at 2 A.M. by Dean Julian Mates to protect our station license after ob scenities had been broadcast. The shutdown came at the end of the station's regular program schedule.

title: Up the SST
description: Writing a prosupersonic transport article for this paper is like playing Stravinsky at a rock festival. The op position on that page to the left has been playing so steadily and its ampli fiers are so high I wonder if softer, albeit still dissonant, music will reach the audience's ears. Here's a try:

title: Batsheva Dancers Debut to Aid AmericaIsrael Cultural Fund
description: Members of both the AmericaIsrael Cultural Foun dation and the Israel's Bat sheva Dance Company will attend a champagne recep tion next Tuesday night at the AmericaIsrael Culture House. 4 East 54th Street.

title: DATE ON RAIL STRIKE MOVED UP TO DEC. 10
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) Four railroad unions today moved their threatened nation wide strike date up by one day to Dec. 10 if they are unable to reach a peaceful wage settle ment covering nearly 500,000 workers.

title: Howard Gains in Soccer, Beating Phila. Textile by 10
description: PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 Howard University of Washing ton qualified today for the semifinal round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer championship by ending Philadelphia Textile's unbeaten streak. 10.

title: Heavy Hand at Interior
description: Further depressing events in the Interior Department confirm the view that the recent firing of Secretary Hickel was essentially a blow at conservation and only incidentally the settling of a personal account. Hardly had the pilot been dropped when his last orders were countermanded and an Assistant Secretary dedicated to wildlife conservation made to walk the plank.

title: Solzhenitsyn Explains Change in Plans
description: MOSCOW, Nov. 30  Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn has told the Swedish Academy that he changed his mind about going to Stockholm to receive the 1970 Nobel Prize because he assumed, from the suppression of his books, that he would not be permitted to return.

title: $163,367 Awarded Girl Hurt in Cannon Accident
description: NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 30 (AP)A coed who lost an eye five years ago when she was hit by a blast from a cere monial cannon fired during a football game at the college she now attends has won a $163,367 settlement for the injury.

title: German Amends To Yiddish Poets
description: Two East Germans, a poet and a graphic artist, have joined in an unusual publish ing venture to honor Jewish victims of Nazi extermination with a richly illustrated de luxe edition of German trans lations of Yiddish poetry.

title: TRACK ATHLETES ASK LIBERATION
description: A liberalization of the rules governing track and field in the United States will be sought by a group of top athletes at the annual national convention of the Amateur Athletic Union starting today in San Francisco.

title: Sy Oliver Takes His 7071 Band To the Village
description: The 197071 version of Sy Oliver's ninepiece band was in troduced to the jazz world by the New York Hot Jazz Society at the Village Vanguard on Sun day. The band is currently play ing during the week at the Riv erboat, where it alternates with a rock group.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: Market Summary

title: Stocks in London Turn Steady In a Session of Quiet Trading
description: The London stock market was steady yesterday with a firm undertone in very quiet trading. Selective small buying of leading issues helped stabi lize the market.

title: N .B.C. PrimeTime Schedules On 5 Nights Are Being Revised
description: The National Broadcasting Company Television network announced yesterday that it was altering the primetime schedules of five of its seven weekly broadcasting nights, be ginning in January. Two of its current programs will be can celed and three others will be shifted to different time slots.

title: T.W.A. Cargo Jet Hits Plane in Israel, Killing 2
description: TEL AVIV, Nov. 30 (UPI) A Trans World Airlines 707 jet cargo carrier taking off on a flight to Europe crashed early this morning into an Israeli Air Force propeller driven Stratocruiser being towed on the runway of Lydda Airport. Both planes were destroyed by explosions and fire.

title: Advertising: Finger on Washington's Pulse
description: It'll be sort of an early warning system, said Wil liam G. Kaye, a man who obvi ously had his radar turned on.

title: Tiny Nuclear Pacemaker For the Heart Developed
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 30 The development of a nuclear powered heart pacemaker about the size of the eraser on pencil has been announced by the Cox Heart Institute.

title: GUINEANS ASSERT 50 INVADERS DIED
description: ABIDJAN. Ivory Coast. Nov. 30 (Reuters)  The Conakry radio reported today that more than 50 mercenaries had been killed in fighting around Koun dra in northwest Guinea.

title: HomeMortgage Rates Follow Mixed Pattern
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)Interest rates charged for conventional mortgages for the purchase of new homes in creased slightly in October, but the rates on mortgages for older houses declined to the lowest point in five months, the Federal Home Loan Board reported today.

title: Football Poll
description: WRITERS RATINGS

title: FARMERS ADVISE ON CLOUD SEEDING
description: With representatives of Florida tomato farmers at their elbows, radar operators have been able to guide cloudseed ing planes to increase rainfall sevenfold on selected areas without drenching the tomato crop.

title: Treasury Statement
description: Special to The New York Times WASHINGTON, Nov. 30Cash deposits and withdrawals, close of business, Nov. 24:

title: Passengers or Pigeons?
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30Congress, the Nixon Administration and Secre tary of Transportation John Volpe have made a small, shaky start on redeem ing intercity rail passenger service from the limbo into which American railroads and national policy have cast it. The designation of a basic national passenger network, to be operated by a single corporation, offers hope for the futurebut at the same time it sug gests the immense problems remaining.

title: Harris Poll Reports Nixon Trails Muskie First Time
description: The Louis Harris organiza tion reported yesterday that its poll had found President Nixon trailing Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, for the first time since Mr. Nixon had taken office.

title: B.O.A.C. Profits Decline
description: LONDON, Nov. 30 (UPI) The stateowned British Over seas Airways Corporation to day reported a $19.6million decline in pretax profits to $33.6million for the first half of the year. Group profit for the AprilOctober period was $20.4 million, against $28.08million in the yearago period.

title: ExSpy Says Army Furnished Liquor for Role as a Protester
description: A former Army intelligence officer says the Army gave him an expense account, provided him with liquor and offered to supply him with marijuana if it were necessary while he was assigned to infiltrate antiwar groups.

title: The Theater: Carmilla
description: Carmilla is a 19thcen tury ghost story by J. V. Le Fanu, which Wilford Leach has transformed into a lov ingly gothic chamber play. Or, since every word is sung, is it an opera? A musical? Since there is film flowing through the entire play, is it a movie? In any case, like Gertrude, although in many ways it is unlike Gertrude, it is a distinctive theatrical gem from Mr. Leach and his company. The composer, Ben Johnston; the musical direc tor, James Cuomo: the ex quisite little orchestra and the cast.

title: Moonshine Trade Ain't in the Best of Health
description: SAPPHIRE, N.C.One crisp morning last week, a tooth less old man hobbled up the steep path behind his house to a decrepit little shed, put his shoulder to the sagging door and shoved it open with a grunt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: No Solution in Federal Aid

title: Envoy and Wife Suicides, Bonn Aide in Lisbon Says
description: LISBON, Nov. 30 (UPI)The West German Ambassador, Dr. Hans SchmidtHorix, 61 years old, and his wife, Barbara, 56, committed suicide early Friday,

title: HOOVER PRESSED ON PLOT CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30A Tennessee Congressman, who visited the Rev. Daniel Berri gan and the Rev. Phillip F. Berrigan three times in prison after reading their antiwar writing, demanded today that J. Edgar Hoover prove or re tract his charges that they are part of a kidnapping and sabo tage plot.

title: CHLOE OWEN GIVES ATTRACTIVE RECITAL
description: Chloe Owen, soprano, sang radiantly at Tully Hall Sunday night, and she had the stage presence of a grand lady, all grace and ease.

title: Big Board C.C.S. Service Delivering Shares of Amex
description: Computerized intraindustry delivery of American Stock Exchange shares through the New York Stock Exchange's Central Certificate Service has been started, the exchanges announced yesterday.

title: U.S. JUDGE UPHOLDS INMATES ON RIGHTS
description: A Federal judge yesterday barred the New York County District Attorney from asking jail inmates to waive their right to legal counsel in an in quiry of recent riots unless they are fully advised of [their] constitutional rights.

title: DellaFemina, Travisano Gets Westclox Account
description: After six years (by the clock) with MacManus, John. & Adams the Westclox Divi sion of General Time will be moving Jan. 1 into Della Femina, Travisano & Part ners.

title: Rockwell Killer's Conviction Is Upheld By Virginia Court
description: RICHMOND, Nov. 30 (UPI) The Virginia Supreme Court upheld today the conviction and 20year prison sentence of John Patler for the slaying in 1967 of George Lincoln Rock well, the American Nazi party leader.

title: 5 POLICE OFFICERS SUE OVER INQUIRY
description: Two deputy inspectors and three captains of the Police De partment assigned to the same midtown command filed suit yesterday to prevent a special commission investigating al leged police corruption from questioning them about their personal finances.

title: Davis, First Black General, Buried in Arlington Rites
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UPI)Brig. Gen. Benjamin O. Davis Sr., the first Negro to become a general in the armed forces of the United States, was buried today in Arlington National Cemetery with full military honors.

title: Schenley Agrees to Sell Guild Wine Some Assets
description: Schenley Industries, Inc., a leading liquor producer, an nounced yesterday it had signed a letter of intent wjth the Guild Wine Company of San Francis co that provided for the sale of certain assets of Schenley's California wine operations to Guild. Financial details of the transaction were not disclosed but trade sources estimated that Merger Guild Wine would News pay in excess of $10million for the Schenley assets it would acquire if the deal was consummated.

title: Television
description: Inger Stevens appears in Run, Simon, Run, Ch. 7 at 8:30 P.M.

title: U.N. Supports Halt in the Atomic Race
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30The Soviet Union, in an unexpected move, voted in favor of a resolution today calling on all nucleararmed nations to halt the nuclear arms race immediately and to cease all testing as well as de ployment of nuclear weapons.

title: FISCHER PLAYS DRAW IN MAJORCA TOURNEY
description: PALMA, Majorca, Nov. 30 After completion of the 15th round yesterday and most ad journed games today, Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the eighttime United States cham pion, led the 24man knockout roundrobin qualification tour nament for the world challenge matches with a score of 104 and one adjourned game.

title: U.S. DOCTORS URGED TO FIGHT POLLUTION
description: BOSTON, Nov. 30  The medical profession was called on today to take an active role in reducing pollution and other environmental hazards.

title: U.S. SUBSIDY SET IN LFC TAKEOVER
description: The Government has formal ly agreed to pay $20million to the Great Western Financial Corporation on Jan. 4, sub1 ject to no conditions or limi tations, as an advance on its commitment to subsidize Great Western's takeover of the troubled LFC Financial Cor poration.

title: New Roads to Labor Peace
description: The wild rush of the wageprice spiral and the eco nomic disruption caused by major strikes have made it plain that the conventional processes of collective bar gaining need shoring up. This substantial public stake in more constructive labormanagement relations adds importance to the announcement that five A.F.L.C.I.O. vice presidents have been designated by George Meany to cooperate with five top industrialists and three public representatives in a study aimed at applying the prin ciples of arbitration to settling contract disputes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Senate Finance Committee rewrote the Housepassed trade bill yesterday in an effort to please the Administration and freetrade forces. The committee did, how ever, keep the bill tied to Social Security legislation. Among other changes, the com mittee dropped the import quota on shoes, but kept the textile quota. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: Bernardine Dohrn Letter Pledges Wave of Attacks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 30 (AP)A letter signed with the name of Bernardine Dohrn, a Weatherman leader on the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation's most wanted list, threatened today a wave of attacks on po lice and Federal installations.

title: Four Plead Guilty in a Raid On Draft Office in Illinois
description: PEORIA, III., Nov. 30 (AP) Four antiwar protesters ac cused of breaking into a Pon tiac, Ill., Selective Service of fice July 29 and taking records pleaded guilty today in United States District Court.

title: Top Farm Editor Named
description: CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (UPI) J. Alan Swegle, 24yearold farm editor of The Cedar Rapids (Iowa) Gazette, has been named Newspaper Farm Editor of the Year in a contest sponsored by the Newspaper Farm Editors of America and the Fertilizer Institute.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Echeverria Names Cabinet in Mexico Headed by Envoy
description: MEXICO CITY, Nov. 30 (UPI) Presidentelect Luis Echever rfa Alvarez tonight named Emilio O. Rabasa, Mexican Am bassador to the United States, as Foreign Minister in the Gov ernment that takes office to morrow.

title: Farm Prices Fell By 1.5% in Month As Expenses Rose
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  Prices paid farmers for raw products dropped 1.5 per cent in November and av eraged 4 per cent less than a year ago, the Agriculture De partment announced today.

title: Author of Divorce Bill
description: ROME, Nov. 30Five years ago, shortly after he intro duced the divorce bill that has just become law in Italy, Loris Fortuna was questioned by his 10yearold son.

title: Aqueduct Entries
description: Aqueduct Jockeys

title: JURY IS SELECTED IN COLOMBO TRIAL
description: The trial of Joseph Colombo Jr. and two others accused of conspiring to melt silver coins began in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday after a fourth codefendant pleaded guilty to the charge.

title: Hairdos Join the 1970's Costume Party
description: Whither hair this season? With no great hairdressing star, such as the early Alexandre or the Sassoon of the geometric cut to create a revolution, or idols such as Jacqueline Kennedy Onas sis or Faye Dunaway to imitate, hair dressers have been left to their own devices.

title: Niger and Nigeria, Discarding Colonial Barriers, Start to Trade as Geography Dictates
description: NIAMEY, Niger, Nov. 20 On a map of West Africa, the dry, landlocked Republic of Niger looks like a natural ally and trading partner for Nigeria, her more prosperous neighbor to the south.

title: Soviet Space Base Named Star City
description: The Soviet Union used a name last week for a previ ously unidentified city in the steppes of Kazakhstan from which the Russians launch their manned flights into space.

title: Ridgewood Planning Public Garbage Collections
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 30  This. Bergen County com muter town of 28,000 is going reluctantly into the business of collecting and disposing of its garbage because private collec tors have declined to bid on the work.

title: Older Issues Dawdle
description: Underwriters continued to bid aggressively for new offer ings of longterm bonds yester day, indicating a belief that prices were headed for anoth er upswing. However, trading in outstanding issues displayed little trend.

title: JOHN FEDOR
description: LINDEN, N. J., Nov. 30 John Fedor, a realtor, banker and developer, died last night in Rahway Memorial Hospital, Rahway. He lived at 2204 Or chard Avenue and was 91 years old.

title: J. L. Berkowitz Fiance Of Elaine S. Klurfeld
description: SYOSSET, L.I., Nov. 30 Miss Elaine Susan Klurfeld, whose father, Herman Klur feld, is a writer, plans to be married in June to Jeffrey Lee Berkowitz, whose father, Paul Berkowitz of Miami Beach, is president of the Old Mr. Boston Corporation, liquor distillers.

title: Pontiff, Deeply Tired, Visits Australia And Maintains His Crowded Schedule
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 1Pope Paul VI, his face deeply lined with fatigue, pre sided for more than three hours today over a working session of 65 Roman Catholic Bishops from all over Australia, New Zealand and Oceania.

title: Classes Reopen in Kingston As Pay Talks Make Gain
description: KINGSTON, N. Y., Nov. 30 (AP)Classes resumed at Ul ster County Community College today with negotiators putting the accent on progress in a contract dispute that had closed the school two weeks ago.

title: JOHNSON RAISES GIANTS OPTIMISM
description: Ron Johnson, whose slightly sprained left ankle kept him out most of the second half in Sunday's 2724 victory at Washington, should be 100 per cent by this Sunday, the Giants said yesterday.

title: Vietcong Plan Truce at Christmas, New Year and Tet
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 30 (Reuters)  The Vietcong said today that they would cease fighting for three days both at Christmas and New Year and for four days at Tet, the lunar new year.

title: City Bans Sale of Berets Because of Flammability
description: The city's Health Commis sioner has warned wholesalers and retailers to remove some 24,000 Italianmade women's and children's chenille berets from sale because of the hats' flammability.

title: SCHOOLS BACKED ON LICENSE TESTS
description: The extreme unavailability of eligible blacks and Puerto Ricans  not discriminatory practices by the city school system  is the reason why there are relative few minority group members serving as school supervisors here, a mem ber of the Board of Examiners declared last night.

title: Lorna Luft to Be in Lolita
description: Lorna Luft, the 18yearold daughter of Judy Garland and Sid Luft, will make her Broad way debut this season in the new musical based on Vladimir Nabokov's Lolita.

title: BARGE BLAST KILLS 3 NEAR WATKINS GLEN
description: WATKINS GLEN, N. Y. Nov. 30 (UPI)An explosion and fire on a gasoline barge being prepared for unloading took thre lives early today near the resort community of Watkins Glen on the southern tip of Seneca Lake.

title: 100th Birthday Hailed
description: ARLINGTON, Mass., Nov. 30 (AP)Mrs. Elizabeth McKay, who was born at Spear, Nfld., observed her 100th birthday to day. President Nixon, Queen Elizabeth II and Premier Joseph R. Smallwood of Newfoundland sent greetings.

title: P. C. Wilmot Jr. to Wed Mrs. Mollie Bostwick
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Nov. 30 Mrs. Mollie Netcher Bost wick plans to be married next month to Paul C. Wil mot Jr., an account executive with Norman, Craig & Kum mel in New York.

title: Englewood Blacks Help Police To Patrol Area Hit by 15 Fires
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 30 Members of the black com munity joined the police in a cooperative firewatch patrol of the streets of a blighted sec tion of this city tonight after 38 persons were left homeless last night by the 15th suspicious fire there in nine days.

title: ExConvicts Aided by Men Who Know
description: A retired captain from the Department of Correction and a staff of 1714 of whom are former convictsare in volved in a rehabilitation program that they say has drastically reduced the recidi vism rate.

title: U.S. Said to Offer A New Justification For Raids in North
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 High Administration officials privately acknowledge that the United States is establishing and reinforcing a new rationale for American air strikes against North Vietnam.

title: Vancouver, B.C., With BigCity Problems, Hears LawandOrder Slogan in Mayoral Race
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, Nov. 25After years of expansion and prosperity, this modern West Coast port city is falling prey to the anxieties and problems of other big cities.

title: Dow Up 12.74 to 794.09 As Volume Rises Sharply
description: Stock prices moved drama tically into high gear yester day, bursting through the top of a narrow threemonth trad ing range to finish at their best level since the market rout in May.

title: Ball to Raise Funds For Nassau Hospital
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 30The annual Yuletide Ball of Nassau Hospital will be held on Saturday in the Gar den City Hotel. Mrs. Harlan L. Strader is general chairman.

title: Kleiner, Bell Restricted By S.E.C. and Exchanges
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York Stock Exchange and the Ameri can Stock Exchange announced a series of stringent disciplinary actions yesterday against Klei ner, Bell & Co. and two of its principal officers.

title: Final 1970 Census Figures
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30The following table shows the final 1970 resident population census figures and the changes for each slate in population since 1960 and in representation in the House:

title: FLAGSHOW CASE AIRED BY PANE
description: The case of the Judson Three,) a new cause celebre in local art circles, was aired and dis cussed last evening by a special panel and an audience of more than 100 at Museum, an exhibi tion loft that serves as head quarters for the Art Workers Cnalition at 729 Broadway.

title: National Stock Exchange
description: Toe following Is a selected list of stock transactions on the Monday, Nov. 30, 1970

title: Liberal Democrats Press Senate Seniority Reform
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 Liberal Democratic Senators met today to organize a reform campaign that would weaken the seniority system and give them more of the influence in the Senate now held largely by older, more conservative South erners.

title: FREEHOLD'S SEASON ENDS ON RECORD NOTE
description: FREEHOLD, N.J., Nov. 30 On a day more suitable for an opening, the curtain rang down this afternoon on a spec tacularly successful har ness racing year at Freehold Raceway.

title: Toure Called Disappointed
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Nov. 30Informed sources said today that President Sekou Toure of Guinea and members of his Government had made it clear to the United Nations factfinding mission last week that they were deeply disap pointed that their call for United Nations troops had not been heeded.

title: BLACKS PRESENT VIEWS ON K.E.T.
description: Everything of value in the black community we must control, the bearded, African garbed Imamu Amiri Baraka shouted into the microphone.

title: Ottinger Campaign Cost Put At Minimum of $2.7Million
description: ALBANY, Nov. 30 (AP)  Representative Richard L. Ot tinger spent at least $2.7mil lion on his unsuccessful cam paign to win election to the United States Senate, according to statements on file with the Secretary of State.

title: LAIRD SEES NO CUT IN FORCE FOR NATO
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird declared today that the United States intended to make no substantial cuts in its force of nearly 300,000 troops in Western Europe over the next 19 months.

title: Passenger Service Is Cut Under Rail Network Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Nixon Administration out lined today its proposed basic network of passenger train routes that would be kept run ning when a new quasigovern mental corporation takes over the troubled intercity service next spring.

title: TAX ON EMPLOYERS LOOMS IN NEWARK
description: TRENTON, Nov. 30Gov. William T. Cahill told Mayor Kenneth B. Gibson of Newark today that there were not enough votes in the Legislature to approve a 2 per cent city payroll tax to be collected from employes.

title: Executive Changes
description: Edgar T. Higgins has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Beneficial Cor poration. Mr. Higgins, who currently is vice thair man, succeeds DeWitt J. Paul who will retire De cember 30.

title: First Suit This Fall Is Filed in the South Over Desegregation
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP)  The Nixon Administration filed today its first school de segregation suit in the South since the beginning of the cur rent school year.

title: 7 UTILITIES IN STATE WILL UNIFY POWER
description: ALBANY, Nov. 30  Joseph C. Swidler, the chairman of the State Public Service Com mission, said today that the state's seven major utility com panies had committed them selves to working together to develop a longrange plan for an integrated statewide power system.

title: REVISION DELAYED ON OIL SPILL CODE
description: WASHINGTON, Nov. 30  The Nixon Administration planned to issue relaxed regu lations on oil spills tomorrow, but pulled back late to day when William D. Ruckel shaus, the director of the new Environmental Protection Agency, protested that he should have some voice in the matter.

title: Hague's Adopted Daughter Gets Custody of Her Son
description: The adopted daughter of the late Mayor of Jersey City, Frank Hague, was awarded cus tody of her 12yearold son yes terday.

title: Sports of glo gimes
description: For much too long the theory has been allowed to go unchallenged in football circles that the New York Jets are nothing without Joe Namath. It becomes Increas ingly apparent, however, that the New York Jets are still a tremendous football team even without their highly publicized superstar, sidelined for the rest of the year with his wristbone broken but his ego un damaged.

title: Marketplace:
description: Acting in concert, the Big Board, the Amex and the S.E.C. appear to have halted permanently the stock ticker of Burt S.Kleiner, flamboyant Beverly Hills purveyor of securities to movie stars.

title: COPPER PRICE CUT BY PHELPS DODGE
description: The Phelps Dodge Corpora tion cut the basic price of American primary copper late yesterday for the second time in less than six weeks. The latest move was a reduction to 53 cents a pound from 56 cents.

title: Panel Vote Keeps Quota On Shoes in Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1The Senate Finance Committee, re versing a dayold tentative deci sion, voted today to retain a quota on shoe imports in the controversial foreian trade bill.

title: Y.W.C.A. WILL OPEN DAYCARE CENTERS
description: The Young Women's Chris tian Association, in cooperation with the Young Men's Christian Association of Greater New York, plans to open compre hensive day  care centers in parts of the city next year.

title: Architects Get New Course
description: Secondyear students at the College of Architecture and Planning of Ball State Univer sity in Muncie, Ind., take a graphics course, Graphic Com munication, designed to in crease awareness of social ex pression, symbol formation and visual design, the magazine Architectural Record reports. The course aims at relevancy.

title: Rams'
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 I intend to be coaching the Rams in 1971, George Allen, the controversial Los Angeles coach, said without qualifica tion today.

title: Maryland Doctor Reports Rejecting Egeberg Position
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 1 (AP) Maryland's Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene said to night that he had turned down a White House offer of the nation's top health post now held by Dr. Roeero Eeebere.

title: ANTITERROR BILL VOTED IN OTTAWA
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 1After four weeks of debate, the House of Commons today approved Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau's limited emergency powers bill to replace the war time measures invoked in Octo ber to combat the separatist Front for the Liberation of Ouebec.

title: Illinois Newsmen Stay Out
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., Dec. 1 (AP) Members of the American Newspaper Guild striking Rock, ford's two daily newspapers since Nov. 8 ignored today's deadline set by management for a return to their jobs. The newspapers informed the em ployes by letter Nov. 25 that it would be necessary to replace any employe who failed to re port to work Tuesday, Dec. 1.

title: Whither the Midi? Even at Harvard Business School, It's an Insoluble Problem
description: BOSTON, Dec. 1  The battle of the mini and the midi came to Harvard today, but it was all academic.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1970

title: DOW RISES BY 0.20 IN HEAVY TRADING
description: The stock market's easy money rally kept roaring for ward in early trading yesterday but slowed to a near standstill by the dosing bell.

title: Grief Voiced by Pope on Divorce Law
description: ROME, Dec. 1Pope Paul VI voiced deep grief at the final passage of Italy's divorce law this morning, and Roman Cath olic opponents of the legisla tion announced plans to seek a popular referendum to void the law.

title: Downwind From the SST
description: As the Senate nears its critical vote on the money for the supersonic transport, its advocates are making desperate efforts to assure approval.

title: U.S. DISAPPOINTS CANADIANS ON OIL
description: OTTAWA, Dec. 1A Cana dian Government spokesman said today that the Nixon Ad ministration's decision to raise Canadian crudeoil imports to the United States would: not alter agreements reached at last week's United StatesCan ada ministerial meeting.

title: Diallo Accuses Other Nations
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 1 (Agence FrancePresse) Diallo Tell, Secretary Gen eral of the Organization of African Unity, charged here to day that several European and American nations are im plicated in last week's inva sion of Guinea.

title: A TRACE REMAINS OF AMEX ADVANCE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange managed to finish slightly higher yesterday, al though many early gains were wiped out as the session pro gressed.

title: New World Bank Controller
description: PARIS, Dec. 1 (Reuters)K. George Gabriel has been ap pointed controller of the World Bank group to succeed M. Fran cis Poore, who will retire at the end of this year, the World Bank announced today. Mr. Gabriel, the present deputy con troller, is a 42yearold West German who joined the Interna tional Bank for Reconstruction and Development in 1967 after working in Caracas and with :he United States High Commis ;ion in Germany.

title: U.S.C. Gives McKay 2d Job
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 (UPI)Coach John McKay of the University of Southern California was appointed co director of athletics today. He will continue as head football coach.

title: MRS. JAMES R. H. BOONE
description: Mrs. Muriel Harmar Wurts Dundas Boone, wife of James R. Herbert Boone, a retired financier, died Monday evening in her home at 755 Park Ave nue. She was 66 years old.

title: TEXTILE `MONOPOLY IS SEIZED BY CHILE
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 1 (UPD  The Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens expropriated its first Chilean monopoly today  Bellavista Tome, the nation's largest fabric manufacturer, which had said it was on the verge of bankruptcy.

title: BOYS TOWN MEETS DELAY ON LICENSE
description: OMAHA, Dec. 1Boys Town, founded by the late Rev. Ed ward J. Flanagan in 1917, has operated without a state child care license since June 30 but is expected to have the license by Jan. 1, an official of the Nebraska Department of Wel fare said today.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Man Dies in East Side Fire
description: A fire in a lower East Side apartment claimed the life of its occupant yesterday. The victim had apparently been smoking in bed, fire officials reported. The fire broke out about 4 P.M. killing Albert Saunders, 52, years old, of 571 Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

title: SETON HALL UPSET BY LOYOLA, 9673
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J. Dec. 1Loyola College of Baltimore spoiled Coach Bill Raftery's debut as Seton Hall University basketball coach with a 96731 upset tonight.. It was only the Greyhounds seventh victory in the 38game series.

title: Nixon May Widen Scope Of RevenueSharing Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1The Nixon Administration considering expanding, from $5billion to as much as $20 billion, the scope of the Federal revenue sharing plan that it will resubmit to Congress next year.

title: 2 Arraigned in Holdup Slaying of 4 Here
description: Two suspects were arraigned in Criminal Court here yester day on murder charges as result of the slaying of four persons on Nov. 23 during the robbery of a bar in the East Village.

title: Samuel Mitchell, Manufacturer And Philanthropist, Dead at 85
description: Samuel Mitchell, a philan thropist and a retired blouse manufacturer, died on Monday in his home at 3 East 69th Street. He was 85 years old.

title: Textile Negotiations Lag
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 1 (AP)

title: 1 Billion NATO Plan Set By 10 European Members
description: BRUSSELS. Dec. 1Ten European nations of the North Atlantic alliance agreed today on a defense improvement program calling for the expenditure of close to a billion

title: Chopin Piano Medalist To Visit White House
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI)Garrick Ohlsson, the pianist who won the 1970 Chopin competition in War saw, will perform at the White House Dec. 17 before two fellow pianists of sorts President Nixon and visit ing Prime Minister Heath.

title: PLEA TO PROTECT PRISONERS OF WAR IS ADOPTED IN U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1A United States pro posal aimed at getting protec tion for American war prison. ers in Vietnam was approved today by a committee of the General Assembly.

title: Outcome of Reapportionment Rests On a Variety of Conflicting Factors
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1  In Florida, a key factor may be a state legislator who has de signs on a seat in Congress. In Texas, a Congressman who is under Federal indictment may see his district dismembered. In Alabama, the Democrats are out to get a Republican in cumbent, but the voters may not cooperate.

title: FUTURES IN COCOA UP 2D DAY IN ROW
description: Cocoa futures prices ad vanced again yesterday in mod erate trading for the sec ond day in a row after drop ping last Friday.

title: Texas Oil Leases Awarded
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 1The School Land Board today awarded oil and gas leases to high bidders on 68,438 acres of school land. High bids totaled $3,274,910.79, an average of $47.85 an acre, up $5 from the last lease sale. The Superior Oil Company was high bidder on a 200acre tract in Ward County at $976.51 an acre, the day's high bid.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: BOB ASPROMONTE JOINS NEW YORK
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1The New York Mets traded Ron Herbel to the Atlanta Braves today for Bob Aspromonte, the last of the old Brooklyn Dodgers, as a bull market in players developed at the winter baseball convention.

title: Cambodians Open Drive 20 Miles From Pnompenh and Retake Ferry Crossing
description: PNOMPENH. Cambodia, Dec. 1 (AP)A military spokesman said Cambodian troops opened a drive today 20 miles north of Pnompenh and pushed enemy forces from positions they seized two days ago.

title: Chicago Airport Study Set
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 1 (AP)A $280,000 contract for a study of the possible need for a third Chicagoarea airport has been awarded jointly to the Riph M. Parson Company of Los Angeles and Systems Analysis and Research Cor poration of Washington, Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie announced today.

title: Removed From City Junior High Post, Black Principal Resists
description: The new school superintend ent of Community District 3 in Manhattan, saying that he did not like the discipline and tone of Joan of Arc Junior High School, removed the principal yesterday and ordered the school closed today for consul tations with parents and staff.

title: Thurmond High Blacks Sue for a Name Change
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 1 (UPI)A group of blacks filed suit in Federal court to day asking that their school, Strom Thurmond High, get a new name.

title: Stravinsky Ready to Sell His Papers
description: Igor Stravinsky's carefully husbanded collection of his manuscripts and other pa pers has been thrown on the market at an asking price of $3.5 million. Byzantine man euvering is reported to be going on among such pro spective purchasers as the Library of Congress and the Soviet Union. The archives include the complete, cor rected score of Le Sacre du Printemps, about 7,600 ad ditional pages of manuscript and perhaps 17,000 docu ments.

title: Yugoslavia. Star Ailing, Is Out of Federation Cup
description: PERTH, Australia. Dec. 1 (AP)  Yugoslavia has with drawn from the women's Feder ation Cup international tennis tournament scheduled here Dec. 26 to 29.

title: Suspect in Securities Fraud Faces New Charges
description: Michael Hellerman, who was indicted by a grand jury last month on charges of being the prime mover of a scheme to take over a Florida investment company with the assistance of three reputed Mafia leaders, pleaded not guilty yesterday in Federal Court, and then faced new charges of fraudulent securities sales and price1 rigging.

title: 3 Students to Visit Nixon
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Dec. 1 (UPI)President Nixon extend ed a White House invitation to day to three Villanova Univer sity students who organized a national campus drive that collected more than 200,000 Christmas cards for United States servicemen in Vietnam. The students, who will visit the President at noon tomorrow, are Robert J. Breslin Jr. and Thomas Creagh, both of Men hasset, L. I., and Tom Treacy of Plainview, N. J.

title: 1,526 Out of 1,985 Candidates Pass State Bar Examination
description: The State Board of Law Ex aminers announced yesterday that 1.526 of the 1,985 persons who took the state bar exami nation last July 30 and July 31 had passed. The examiners said that of the 1,802 candidates who took the examination for the first time 1.425 had passed.

title: The Right of Asylum
description: The United States Coast Guard sinks into everdeeper waters as it tries to explain its incredible cooperation with Soviet seamen in their forcible return of a defecting Lithuanian to his fishing vessel off Martha's Vineyard. The commandant now says the hapless defector would have had a better chance of receiving sanctuary if he had leaped from his ship into the water rather than directly onto the Coast Guard cutter Vigilant.

title: Albatross Is Selected
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 1 (UPI)A nationwide poll of harness writers elected Alba tross and Quick Pride as the 2yearold champions of 1970, the United States Trotting As sociation announced today.

title: A Candidate Finds Free Radio Time Not Too Effective
description: A writein candidate who won a Federal ruling for free radio time worth perhaps $10, 000 received a total of four votes in the 19th Congressional District contest, the Board of ,Elections reported yesterday.

title: Giants'
description: The man from the Buffalo Bills was in town yesterday, supposedly to talk about his team's upcoming game with the Giants, but he said he had a more pressing problem to discuss with the television people.

title: Walden School Plans Fair
description: The Walden School at West 88th Street has ar ranged its scholarship fund benefit fair for Friday and Saturday from 10 A.M. to P.M. at the school. Adult ad mission is 50 cents; children will be admitted free.

title: Gun Control Exemption Voted by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee unanimously ap proved today a measure to exempt sales of .22caliber rimfire ammunition from Fed eral gun control registration requirements.

title: Pennsy Land Sale Cleared
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (UPI)Federal Judge P. Fullam granted the Penn Central rail road permission today to sell 260 acres of land in four states for $2.1million.
