description: FLORENCE, Mass., Dec. 8 Dr. Philip E. Smith, a pioneer in research on the pituitary gland in this country, died to day at his home here. He was 86 years old.

title: SLIGHT DROP NIPS MARKET ADVANCE
description: The DowJones industrial av erage did something different yesterday. It went down, thus breaking a string of 12 straight gains that had rolled up a phenomenal advance totaling 64 points. Normal profit taking after that huge gain, commented a broker in midManhattan. Analysts also used such words as digestion and con solidation in interpreting the slight setback in stock prices that came finally after the mar ket kept overcoming earlier profit taking tendencies. The bluechip Dow, spending the day in minus territory, fin ished with a slippage of 3.56 points at 815.10. This marked the lowest level of the halfhourly readings, but the decline was both gentle and orderly. The New York Times com bined average eased 1.41 points to 460.89. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange also ebbed somewhat, underscoring the orderly nature of the decline. Turnover of 14.37 million shares compared with Monday's 15.53 million shares. On Monday, the Dow ended at 818.66its loftiest closing figure for 1970. Last week's volume, moreover, ran a rec ord 92.28 million shares. Blue Chips Affected Blue chips and glamour issues shared in the slide. General. Motors fell 2 to 77 ranking as the biggest point loser on the active list. G. M. traded at a yearly high of 80 on Monday, climaxing a 10 point gain over the last five weeks. American Telephone & Tele graph eased  to 47 in brisk trading. It had climbed 3 points last week. Among the glamours, Bur roughs and Memorex each fell 2 points. American Research and Development dropped 3 Natomas gave up 1 Walt Dis ney Productions was down  Royal Dutch dropped a point to 43 to rank as the most active issue on turnover totaling 227,700 shares. It also account Continued on Page 96, Column 3 ed for the largest block of the session188,600 shares at 44 with Salomon Brothers handling both sides of the transaction.

title: Police Send Up Copiers In Fight on Urban Crime
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  At 38th Street and Mersington on a chilly, dark afternoon recently, three teenage boys stalked an elderly woman as she walked home carrying a bag of groceries.

title: Untaxed Booty Decried
description: SWANSEA, Mass., Dec. (AP)  The acting director of the Internal Revenue Service in the Boston district says that more than $1billion in untaxed money was funneled nationally by organized crime into legiti mate businesses this year. The official, Elmer H. Klinsman, made the statement to a forum sponsored by the Southeastern Massachusetts Chapter of the Society of Certified Public Ac countants.

title: A WESTBANK PLAN DERIDED BY ARABS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, Dec. 8  Spokesmen for the Jordanian Government and the Palestinian guerrillas, in separate state ments today, rejected a pro posal that the westbank area of Jordan be granted autonomy while under Israeli occupation.

title: Reactions Vary for Playoff Contenders
description: The tortuous road to the Super Bowl has brought forth varied reactions among the 14 teams still in contention for the eight playoff posi tions.

title: If Wallace Decides To Campaign in 72 He'll Seek Electors
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Any Presidential campaign that George C. Wallace runs in 1972 will have the avowed purpose of paralyzing the Electoral Col lege machinery and forcing a political bargain on a major party candidate.

title: Issues in the Taxi Dispute
description: PARTIESLocal 3036 of the New York City Taxi Drivers Union, representing 36,000 drivers and 1,200 inside workers; the Metropolitan Taxicab Board of Trade, repre senting 69 of the 72 fleet owners who operate 6,816 cabs; the. CityiCouncil, which has the responsibility for setting taxi fares, and Mayor Lindsay, who recommended a fare increase at an earlier stage in negotiations.

title: Treasury Cites Dumping Of Japanese Capacitors
Mixed Marriage Law In Alabatna Overturned
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 8 (UPI)  Federal Judge S. C. Painter Jr. today declared Alabama's antimiscegenation laws unconstitutional and or dered officials to quit en forcing them.

title: Treasury Statement
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8Cash deposits and withdrawals, close of business, Dec 3

title: HUSSEIN CONFERS AT WHITE HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  President Nixon met with King Hussein of Jordan today for talks that were thought to have centered on their mutual desire for resumption of the Middle East peace talks and on Jor dan's hopes for further military assistance.

title: U.S. Cites November's Index, 0.1% Lower, and October's Volume
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The decline in wholesale prices in November was not so large as estimated earlier but the index of wholesale prices neverthe less, did go down during the month, the Labor Department reported today.

title: EDUCATOR TO AID CITY DELINQUENTS
description: In an effort to Improve schools at the city's troubled juvenile detention centers, Fordham University will begin next month a Federally fi nanced program to provide spe cial training for 20 teachers in the Spofford and Matilda Cen ters fin the Bronx.

title: Conservationists Rally to Help a Boycotted Friend
description: LINCOLN, Mont., Dec. 8 More than 100 conservation ists braved icy roads and drove distances of up to 300 miles the other day to do Christmas shopping in Cecil Garland's Town and Country Store.

title: Six Indicted Here in a Bomb Plot by Weathermen
description: A grand jury indicted three men and three women yester day as participants in a Weath erman conspiracy to bomb such targets as the offices of Presi dent Nixon's former law firm here, a New York University building, two police stations and a bank on the Upper East Side.

title: New Treatments Aiding Victims Of a Mysterious Muscle Disease
description: New treatment methods are saving the lives of the vast majority of victims of a mys terious neuromuscular disease, myasthenia gravis, even though doctors know little about its Cause or cure.

title: JOHN W. DEHART
description: MADISON, N. J. Dec. 8 John W. DeHart of 17 Madison Avenue, an accountant for many years with the New York Telephone Company, died yes terday at his home. His age was 72.

title: Arlene Dahl Has a Son
description: HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 8 (AP) Arlene Dahl, wife of Rounse ville Schaum, a television exec utive, gave birth yesterday to a son, the couple's first. He has been named Rounseville Andreas. Miss Dahl and Mr Schaum each has a son and daughter by their previous marriages.

title: POLICE INSPECTOR FIGHTS SUBPOENA
description: The commanding officer of three Manhattan precincts has been called to testify before the special commission investigat ing allegations of police cor ruption, but he has moved in court to prevent the commis sion from questioning him.

title: GRANTS ANNOUNCED BY FORD FOUNDATION
description: The Ford Foundation has an nounced grants for programs designed to increase the quan tity and quality of food produc tion in Asia, Africa and Latin America.

title: Oxford Upsets Cambridge
description: TWICKENHAM, England, Dec. 8 (Reuters)Oxford University provided one of the biggest up sets of the English Rugby Union season today by defeat ing Cambridge, 143, in the an nual varsity match.

title: Head of Stockholm Opera Favored to Succeed Bing
description: Goran Gentele, 53yearold head of the Stockholm Opera is the leading contender to succeed Rudolf Bing as gen eral manager of the Metro politan Opera. Mr. Bing's contract expires at the end of next season. Although the choice of the Swedish stage director and administrator was reported in opera circles here to be imminent, the Metropolitan's president, George Moore, said the deci sion had not yet been made.

title: I.C.C. REFUTES CRITICS AS IRRESPONSIBLE
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission, in its first public response to widespread criti cism in Congress, charged yes terday that much of the criticism leveled against the Government agency was 'bi ased, political or uninformed, or has taken the shape of irrespon sible and illfounded carp and fulmination.

title: CHANGE OCCURRED AFTER LOSS HERE
description: If the Giants listen to Larry Wilson, they'll find out they have only themselves to blame for the criticial situation they're in.

title: Taxi Talks at a Standstill
description: Efforts to resolve the four dayold taxi strike were at a standstill yesterday as New Yorkers appeared to be getting accustomed to streets without the yellow cabs.

title: LAY TEACHERS JOIN NATIONAL UNION
description: The 2500.lay teachers in the Roman. Catholic schools of the New York Archdiocese have joined an independent local of the American Federation of Teachers.

title: Gould, E., and Mr. Nixon
description: It is entirely possible that historians of future generations will come to re gard Richard Nixon's Presidency as the exquisite irony of the twentieth century. Back in 1970, they will point out, amidst the chaos of change, there ruled a relic, the vast Victorian cham ber of his mind composing passe rhet oric to be announced, on behalf of his fearshocked constituency, over one tinny megaphone from some White House window. Irony? Absolutely, the historians will agree.

title: Democrats'
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7The Democratic party ran more strongly in last month's elections than it initially seemed. That is the principal conclusion that emerges from a detailed analysis of precinct returns compiled from boards of elec tions, party headquarters, the National BroadcaSting Com pany election unit and other sources.

title: Democrats Organize Fete for McCormack
description: WASHINGTON, Dec: 8 (AP) House Speaker John W. McCormack's Democratic friends and associates turned out tonight for a big recep tion to bid him farewell. He, in turn, wished them success in efforts, to elect a Democrat to, the White.House in 1972.

title: .and First Test for Restraint
description: The threat of a nationwide railroad strike at midnight tonight provides a crucial test of the willingness of the Nixon Administration and Congress to grapple forth rightly with the wageprice challenge.

title: Syracuse Athletics Charged With 'Chronic Racism' in Report on Football Suspension of 8 Blacks
description: The suspension of eight black athletes who boycotted football practice at Syracuse University last spring was an act of institutional racism unworthy of a great univer sity, a special investigative committee at Syracuse has concluded.

title: Formula A Purses Go Up 75%; Wider Distribution Is Planned
description: The Sports Car Club of America's professional series for Formula A carsopen wheel racers with a single seat in an open cockpitwill run next season with a 75 per cent increase in guaran teed purses. The series will have the same sponsor but a mouthful of a new name the L&M Conti nenta1.5000Cham pionship (the pre vious name was the Continental The 5000 refers to the Maximum engine displace ment5,000 cubic centime tersused in Formula A, and is also recognition of the fact thatoutside the United States these cars are known as Formula 5000.

title: Ecology Is Only Academic Problem for Students at New Wisconsin Campus
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The problems of the environment seem far away from the spar kling new buildings on the Uni versity of Wisconsin campus on 600 rolling, wooded acres here.

title: Rogers Sees a LongTerm Need For Military Aid to Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Secretary of State William P. Rogers told Congress today that the United States must assume a longterm program of assist ance in Cambodia, but he em phasized that the Administra tion was intent on avoiding direct military involvement there.

title: Britain Agrees to Speed Market Transition Time
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 8Britain told the sixnation Common Market today that, if accepted for admission, she would agree to a fiveyear transition period for tailoring her industry and agriculture to the market's standards.

title: MET'S MASKED BALL OFFERS THREE BOWS
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 10th performance this season of A Masked Ball shifted focus somewhat as three sing ers assurhed important roles in the Verdi work for the first time with the company.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P. O. Box 557, New York, N. Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organi zations that certify these cases:

title: Incomes Policy Backed By Reserve Chief Here
description: The overriding concern of the Federal Reserve System's monetary policy in 1970 has been to encourage moderate expansion of money and bank credit to help the economy stage an orderly and gradual recovery, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

title: Merger Bid At Harvard Is Rejected
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 8A special committee of top officials of Harvard Uni versity and Radcliffe College reported today that a merger is not desirable at this time.

title: Brink's Guard for Gold Is Seized As Impostor With Police Record
description: A Brink's armored truck scheduled to pick up a $1mil lion gold shipment at Kennedy International Airport arrived yesterday with a guard who, the police said, was using a false name, had a police record for burglary, and was carrying a pistol with the serial number filed off.

title: Wildlife Officials Protest Feeding of 300,000 Geese
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 (AP) About 300,000 Canadian geese that stopped off for din ner in Iowa and Missouri have stayed there instead of flying South  to the dismay of wild life officials in Louisiana and Texas.

title: WALTER J. CURLEY, TRANSIT EXECUTIVE
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8Walter J. Curley, founder in 1919 of the PennConley Tank Car com pany, of which he became presi dent, died Saturday at his home in suburban Fox Chapel, after long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Networks to Televise Nixon News Conference
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 President Nixon will hold his first news conference in four months at 7 P.M. Thursday, the White House announced. It will be nationally televised on all three networks.

title: Man Charged With Arson And Homicide in Fire Here
description: A 37yearold unemployed man was charged with arson and homicide yesterday in a twoalarm fire Monday night at the apartment building where he lived. A young fire man fell to his death while trying to control the flames.

title: Fischer Tightening Grip on First Place In Majorca Chess
description: PALMA, Majorca, Dec. 8 With three rounds to go, Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles, the eighttime United States chess champion, has all but clinched first place in the knockout chess round robin. He defeated Dun can Suttles of Canada in the 20th round today. His score is 134, with two adjourned games, which he is likely to win.

title: WOMEN LAWYERS  CITE OBSTACLES
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 8When Mrs. Eleanor Jackson Piel, a former deputy attorney genera of California, finished her sum mation of a criminal case in Federal court recently, the judge warned the jury not to be mis led by her beauty and charm when delivering the verdict in the case.

title: PRICE OF 71 FORDS RAISED THIRD TIME
description: DETROIT, Dec. 8The Ford Motor Company raised the prices today on its 1971 cars an average of $15, its third price increase since the 1971 model cars went on sale. The price rise means that a typical car buyer will pay more than $200 for his new car than he vauld have paid for a, similar cat last year.

title: Day of Auld Sang Longer
description: New Yorkers will have four extra hours to celebrate. the start of the New Year, accord, ing to Bess Myerson Grant, the city's Commissioner of Con sumer Affairs. The licensed cabarets, catering establish ments and public dance halls that obtain special permits will be allowed to remain open till 8 A.M. on Jan. 1.

title: FACSIMILE NETWORK OPENS NATIONAL LINE
description: Facsimile Transmission Net work, Inc., announced yester day the establishment of highspeed facsimile, network that covers more than 200 cities throughout the United States and Canada.

title: JERSEY MEADOWS GET LOW BUDGET
description: TRENTON, Dec. 8New Jer sey officials and planning con sultants have agreed that the plan to develop the Hacken sack Meadows into New Jer sey's third largest urban center could begin without any mas sive infusions of state or Fed eral funds.

title: The Accord of 1970
description: In the past days economic policy speeches by President Nixon and Chairman Arthur F. Burns of the Federal Reserve Board we are witnessing the emergence of what should go down in the history books as the Accord of 1970.

title: Washington Store Bargains Draw InflationWary Shoppers
description: WASHINGTON  Men's suits tagged at $175 are not selling well at Julius Gar finckel's, the capital city's most prestigious store. High priced goods have been hard hit at famous Woodward & Lothrop's. A few days ago, the Hecht Company drew thousands of priceconscious shoppers with a bargain sale of sheets and linens from a mill with a glutted inventory. And Lansburgh's, whose downtown store clientele is 70 per cent nonwhite, is pushing a Tuesday Stand Out Value promotion.

title: Court Hears a Hughes Faction Challenge Voting Proxy
description: LAS VEGAS, Dec. 8One set of Howard Hughes's execu tives set the stage today for an attack on the signature on a document used as an author ization by a competing set of executives in a struggle for control of Mr. Hughes's $150 million properties here.

title: Coast Guard Aide Critical on Defector
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) The chief counsel of the United States Coast Guard told a House committee today that Soviet ship captain's allegation that a wouldbe Soviet defector had stolen 3,000 rubles ($3,333) was no ground for returning him to the Russians.

title: Pompidou: IIIEurope
description: PARISThe most significant devel opment in French foreign policy since Georges Pompidou succeeded Charles de Gaulle at the helm is a genuine desire to bring Britain into the Euro pean Common Market and an absolute conviction that this will occur.

title: Fulbright Questions Reasons for Raid on Reported P. O. W. Camp
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) Senator J. W. Fulbright said today there were indications that United States officials knew that no prisoners were in an alleged P.O.W. camp at Son tay, North Vietnam, and that rescue attempt there last month had other purposes.

title: Harvard Backs Chavez
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. (AP)  Harvard Univeisity has announced that its dining halls will serve only lettuce picked by members of the United Farm Workers. L. Gard Wiggins, the university administrative vice president, said the action had been taken in support of a na tionwide boycott of nonunion lettuce led by Cesar Chavez, the Chicano farm workers leader who has been jailed for con tempt of court for failing to call off the boycott.

title: PIANIST APPEARS IN ARTISTS SERIES
description: Is it possible in these days of Women's Lib to speak of a pianist's playing as being wom anly, and intend it as praise? It is a quality that could be attributed to the artistry of the late Myra Hess. It made her performance special and valu able, and never detracted from her eminence in the music world.

title: Island Prepared Early
description: PARADISE ISLAND, The Bahamas, Dec. 8Preparations for the arrival of Howard Hughes on this island started at least 12 days before he flew here in the middle of the night on Nov. 26.in front of which sits, 24 hours a day, a uniformed guard.

title: A Governor's Wife Is Applauded for. Her Interest in the Past
description: It's a wonder I don't get my head chopped of for the things I do, the wife of Gov. Robert E. McNair of South Carolina said laughingly. The auburnhaired First Lady was recounting her recent efforts to raise .money for the resto ration of the Governor's man sion and a nearby guest house in Columbia, S. C.

title: GORDON REELECTED TO HEAD GOLF UNIT
description: Kenneth T. Gordon of Mont clair was renamed president of the Metropolitan Golf As sociation yesterday at the 73d annual meeting of the organiz ation at the Biltmore Hotel.

title: Recession Making Tipping a Part of Christmas Past
description: For those who live in the land of the open palm apartment supers, doormen, delivery boys  Christmas looms a little colder this year. The specter that haunts them is not the ghosts of Christmas past, but the ghost of their Christmas presents.

title: TARGET DATE SET AS FEB 15 OR 22
description: The potential of tit $2million gate from an audience of 70,000 spectators and a $200,000 tax saving has pro jected the Houston Astrodome ahead of Madison Square Garden as the site of what looms as the most compelling bout in boxing historya world heavyweight title showdown be tween Muhammad All and Joe Frazier.

title: Slight Decline Is the First in More Than Two Weeks
description: Prices closed lower yesterday on the American Stock Ex change, marking the first de cline in more than two weeks.

title: Hulan Jack and 5 Others Indicted for Labor Fraud
description: Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack and L. Joseph Overton, a union business agent who is regarded as one of the most powerful men in Harlem, were indicted with four other persons yesterday on charges of participation in a labor management fraud that has been operating in the. Harlem community for approximately five years.

title: NETS LOSE BY 120116 AS BARRY RETURNS
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 8Mike Maloy scored 18 points,. 12 in the last quarter, to lead the Virginia Squires to a 120116 victory over the New York Nets in an American Bas ketball Association game to night at the Island Garden.

title: Economists View 1971
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 8The econ omy is expected to resume its growth ih. 1971 after a mild recession in 1970, a panel of economists said here today. They also predicted a continued decline in the rate of inflation, a further drop in interest rates, a steel strike next summer and an unemployment rate above 6 per cent before it begins to drop next year.Speaking at a luncheon spon sored by the University of Chi cago Graduate School of Busi ness were Beryl W. Sprinkel, senior vice president and econ omist of the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago; Wal ter D. Fackler, professor of business economics and direc tor of management programs at the School, and Irving Schwei ger, professor of marketing at the School and editor of The Journal of Business.

The numbers and types of nuclear weapons go on increasing. And danger of a nuclear war grows.

State education establishments share with local school bureaucracies a tendency to be parochial and fearful of change.

description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8 (AP)  Greg Polis, the Pittsburgh Penguins top rookie, scored one goal and set up two others as he led his team to a 4.0 vic tory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League tonight.

description: SUWEILIH, Jordan, Dec. 8 In the fourth day of fighting, Jordanian troops and Palestini in guerrillas clashed near this crossroads town today while army cleanup operations con tinued in Jarash.

(UFOJacksonville University, behind the 31 points and 26 rebounds of Artis Gilmore, handed Florida State its first defeat, 114108, tonight and won the Sunshine Classic bas ketball tournament. Gilmore scored 71 points in the two night tournament. George Washington defeated Southern Mississippi, 9590, for third place.

title: Land Use on Long Island
description: From Long Island, where open spaces are so rapidly vanishing, it is refreshing to hear of plans, however local, to arrest that deadly process. Southampton, a re sort and rural town at the eastern end of the island, is considering a new ordinance to preserve its farms in perpetuity while allowing for the inevitable boost in population.

description: Henry Varnum Poor, the art 1st, died yesterday at his home in New City, N. Y. He was 82 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (Reu ters)  The Senate approved funds today to build an Ameri can assembly line for the Brit ishdeveloped Harrier jet fighter plane.

title: Film: Very Middle-Class Friendship:Cassavetes, Falk and Gazzara in 'Husbands'
description: "Husbands," John Cassavetes's first film as a director since "Faces," is a personal, almost private movie that is devoted to the exploration of the mysteries of a very middle-class American friendship. Like "Faces," which was rambling and funny and accurate, and which I admired, the new film demonstrates a concern for panicky, inarticulate squares that is so unpatronizing that it comes close to being reverential in a solemnly religious sense."Husbands," however, also puts one's tolerance of simulated cinma vrit to the test. It is almost unbearably long. It is a narrative film without any real narrative, and although it is a movie about three characters, those characters are seen almost exclusively in terms of their limiting relationship. It's as if someone decided to photograph a tug-of-war and photographed only the rope between the contestants.Gus (Cassavetes), Harry (Ben Gazzara) and Archie (Peter Falk), commuting cronies from Port Washington, L. I., meet at the funeral of the fourth member of their group, a man taken off before his time by a coronary. They are shaken up, not only by the loss of their friend and the awareness that it could have happened to any one of them, but also by their own survival into imminent middle age, that dreadful time when it is suddenly apparent that what is, probably is the way it's always going to be. Archie would have liked to be a professional athlete "You get sweaty and feel good and you're with guys you like."In a four-day bender that follows the funeral. Gus and Harry and Archie start drinking and talking in New York and wind up in London, where they drink and talk some more and make out with three unusually attractive pick-ups. They continue to drink and talk and, finally, come to the end of a very expensive weekend. Archie would like to stay on, but Gus points out that among them they have "three garages, five kids and two lovely wives." The only problem, he adds bleakly, "is going home and making love to them.""Husbands" seems not only to be about friendship, but also a product of friendshipthat of the three stars who react to one another with an extraordinary intensity that seldom is as meaningful to us as it is to them. As the movie rolls on, through scenes of epic non-communication, including one extended interlude in a men's room where Gus and Archie take turns vomiting up a night's worth of beer, a kind of frustration settles over the movie, like that experienced by the three friends.Harry beats up a telephone booth and then turns to his friends and admits that although his wife is good in bed, he loves Gus and Archie more. Archie almost ruins his night out in London when he recoils in horror to the open-mouth kiss offered by his girl. In Port Washington, that sort of thing is frowned upon, at least between strangers. They are frustrated not only by the dim present, but also by attitudes established in the past.The movie, in turn, becomes frustrated by the form chosen by Mr. Cassavetes. He lets every scene continue long past closing time, as if in hopes of grabbing, perhaps accidently, some found truth. The effect of "Husbands" eventually is like that of being at a party, after the liquor and wit have run out, and when nobody can quite bring himself to leave.With the exception of Harry, who is seen briefly in very funny, uproarious battle with his Wife ("I'm just not comfortable in front of you," she tells him, adding "it's nothing personal"), Mr. Cassavetes doesn't let us see the men except as a team, as effectively isolated from wives and family as Arctic explorers. This explains, I think, the sudden relief and effectiveness of a closing scene in which Gus returns home, where he is met by his 11-year-old son and his 2-year-old daughter who, for no visible reason, bursts into tears. It may not be the only spontaneous moment in "Husbands," but it is tender and sad, and it affected me more than anything else in the film.It affected me, I suspect, because like Gus, I was exhausted by the manic horse-play with which the husbands react to one another, and which is the ritual that represents the exchange of their love. Gus and Harry and Archie cuff one another a lot, and, when drunk, they are given to sloppy kisses. When they swim, they dunk one another under the water, and when it's all over, they are tired, but not much wiserwhich is pretty much the sum and substance of "Husbands."

title: 2 Doctors and 2 Druggists Arrested In Big Prescription Fraud in Bronx

Calley Jr. late today after rigorous crossexamina tion by defense counsel failed to shake the testimony of two witnesses who said they had seen the lieutenant fire into a ditch filled with South Vietna mese civilians during an alleged massacre at Mylai.

description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. S  Mrs. Lucy Davis Cailler, widow of Arthur G. Calller, an essential oils broker, died yes terday in Misericordia Hospital, the Bronx, where she was taken after a sudden illness. She was 80 years old and lived at 39 Sycamore Avenue.

title: Lions Subdued, 7461
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 7With Bob Wenzel lead ing the way with 19 points, Rut gers handed Columbia its first basketball defeat tonight in three games, 7461.

title: Jersey to List Tenants by Race
description: TRENTON, Dec. 7A con troversial regulation that re quires landlords of apartment houses with 25 or more units to file annual lists that desig nate their tenants by race was promulgated today by the State Division on Civil Rights.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UPI) The 8upreme Court, by a 4 to4 lie vote, upheld today 1968 acrosstheboard railroad freight increase authorized by the Interstate Commerce Com mission.

title: Talks to Resume on Monday With Pilots of Idle Mohawk
description: UTICA, N. Y., Dec. 8 (AP) Federal midiation officials In Washington informed Mohawk Airlines today that talks with striking pilots would resume. Monday after a twoweak breakdown.

title: Rob Bronx Bank of $48,0001
description: Three gunmen escaped with more than $48,000 yesterday in a holdup at a Chase Manhattan Bank branch in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, bank of ficials reported. The three fled the Washington Bridge branch at Ogden Avenue and Univer sity Avenue in a white Mustang with New Jersey plates, said bank spokesman.

title: Solti Leads the Chicago in Bruckner's 8th
description: Georg Solti brought down his baton to conclude the Bruckner Eighth Symphony, an hour and 10 minutes after he started it, and Carnegie Hall erupted on Monday eve ning. There were cheers and rhythmic stampings a la the Russians. The acclamation was not necessarily for An ton Bruckner. Mr. Solti, the music director of the Chicago Symphony, has established hitnself as a favorite in New York, with the kind of faith ful following George Szell or Arturo Toscanini had.

title: Student Volunteer Corps Urged in Ohio by Gilligan
description: KENT, Ohio, Dec. 8On the other side of the hill where four students were killed by the, National Guard last May, the Governorelect of Ohio met the students of Kent State Univer sity today.

title: Westmoreland Mutes Reveille Bugler
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 The timehonored Army prac tice of having a bugler call soldiers out to stand reveille in the cold dawn is about to disappear by order of the Army Chief of Staff, Gen. William C. Westmoreland. A directive from General Westmoreland today does not eliminate the bugler, but it does do away with reveille formations except for cere monies and training. When the formations are held, the general added, they should be musters of all officers and enlisted men from the com mander on down.

title: Pentagon States Goal of Raid
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8A Defense Department spokes man, asked about Senator Ful bright's comments, reiterated gat the purpose of the search and rescue mission was to free Americans held captive in the north.

title: SHANGHAI EXHIBIT ABOUNDS IN GOODS
description: SHANGHAI  In the main hall at the Shanghai Industrial Exhibition, a huge white statue of Chairman Mao Tsetung surveys a display of wellpol fished heavy machinery.

title: Black Boy's Writing Dream Is Fulfilled
Plywood Profit Drop Seen
description: U. S. PlywoodChampion Pa pers, Inc., expects its 1970 prof its to be down by at least 44 per cent from last year's results. The forestproducts company also disclosed yesterday that it may have to drop its planned lumber project in Central Amer ica.

title: Lindbergh Plane' s Broken Part Is Presented to the Smithsonian
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) A broken part of Charles A. Lindbergh's Spirit of St. Louis plane, replaced just before take off on the historic first solo crossing of the Atlantic, has made its way to the Smithsonian Institution after 43 years.

title: 2 Tuna Brands Found Tainted By Mercury in Broome County
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8  Two brands of canned tuna obtained from supermarkets in Broome County during the last week have been found to contain mercury level higher than the allowable maximum set by the Federal Food and Drug Admin istration, the State Health De partment said today.

title: $333,810 for Drug Program
description: ALBANY, Dec. 8The State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission has approved a grant of $333,810 to Odyssey House for operation of a drug abuse program for youths.

title: Government Printing Office: Technology Enlivens a Staid Image
description: Just three years ago the Government Printing Of fice, a venerable redbrick fortress that stands in the Swampoodle area north of the Capitol and whose long, musty corridors are pungent with Ben Franklinesque memories, was one of the more staid enter prises in the Washington laby rinth.

title: Bulls Set Back Warriors
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI)Bob Love celebrated his 28th birth day with a 30point perform ance tonight to lead the Chi cago Bulls to a 9887 victory over the San Francisco War riors.

title: SOVIET KEEPS FUND FOR DEFENSE HIGH
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 8The So viet Union announced today that defense spending next year will remain unchanged at the current record level but that the military share of the, budget will be the lowest in postwar years.

title: BUCKS TURN BACK HAWKS BY 125104
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 8 (UPI) The Milwaukee Bucks defeated the Atlanta Hawks, 125104, tonight for their 21st victory against only three National Basketball Association setbacks.

title: VIETNAM RIOTERS STONE AMERICANS
description: QUINHON, South Vietnam, Dec. 8 (AP)Demonstrators chanting Yankee go home! hurled rocks at American sol diers and burned a jeep today in protest against the fatal shooting of a Vietnamese high school boy by a United States soldier.

title: P.O.W. Appeal in Phone Bills
description: ALBUQERQUE, N. M., Dec. 8 (UPI)  The Mountain Bell Telephone Company said yes terday that it would urge its 2.1 million telephone users in its eightstate area to ask Hanoi for humane treatment of Amer ican prisoners of war. A com pany spokesman said it would make the appeal in an insert to be mailed with December tele phone bills.

title: Fuel Drivers Reach Pact, Ending a 13State Dispute
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (UPI) Teamster's union members in the gasoline and fuel oil tank truck industry reached an agreement today on a new threeyear contract, ending drivers strike in two states and heading off a threatened walk out in 11 cities.

title: WILLIAM PREYER, EXHEAD OF PICK
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Dec. 8 William Yost Preyer, presi clent of Vick Chemical, now RichardsonMerrell, Inc., the large pharmaceutical manufac turer and distributor, for 10 years, died today after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: MOST HAPPY FELLA IN SECOND PLACE
description: Voting for harness horse of the year resulted in a landslide victory for the Americanbred, Canadianowned Fresh Yankee, the first mare to gain the honor since Emily's Pride, also a trot ter, took top honors in 1958. Fresh Yankee is owned by Dun can MacDonald of Sydney, Nova Scotia, and is trained and us ually driven by Joe O'Brien.

title: Basque Defense Restricted by Court
description: BURGOS, Spain, Dec. 8 The courtmartial of the 15 Basques accused of terrorist activities resumed here today after a oneday recess, but with the presiding officer cut ting off the kind of defense testimony he had permited on Sunday.

title: PARLEY TO DEBATE IDEAS ON CHILDREN
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8  Stephen Hess, national chair man of the White House Con ference on Children, said today that expert reports prepared for the 4,000 delegates indict the nation for its vast neglect of its children and shatter the myth that this is a child oriented society.

title: LIQUIDATION HITS GRAIN FUTURES
description: With liquidation hitting near ly all commodity futures on the Chicago Board of Trade yes terday, soybean, corn and wheat declined in fairly active trading.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON MANPOWER BILL
description: WASHINGTON; Dec. 8Sen ate and House conferees agreed today on a multibillion dollar bill to train the unemployed and underemployed that some supporters feared might face a Presidential veto.

title: Plan to Alter Indian Bureau Gets Mixed House Reaction
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP)A proposed overhaul of the Bureau of Indian Affairs got a mixed reception at a House committee hearing to day, with some members coin plaining that tribes had not been consulted.

title: A SOLID NO CITED ON AIRPORT PLAN
description: Borough President Sidney Leviss of Queens said yesterday that there was overwhelming opposition on the Board of Esti mate to expansion of Kennedy International Airport into Ja maica Bay.

title: Opulence Becoming a Way of Life for the Middle Class
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 Roger McRea is not wealthy, not on a Seattle schoolteach er's salary. So when his old second car broke down last spring, the remedy seemed obvious: a small economy car. But he promptly bought a fullsize $3;500 station wagon.

title: Royals, Reds Swap Players
description: KANSAS CITY, Dec. 8 (UPI) The Kansas City Royals and Cincinnati Reds swapped utility infielderoutfielders today for their TripleA franchises. The Royals obtained Jay Ward for Omaha and the Reds got Bill Harris for Indianapolis.

title: Nassau Sheriff Named
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 8 (UPI)  Michael Seniuk, a 55 yearold lawyer from New Hyde Park, L. I., will become Nassau County Sheriff on Jan. 1. County Executiveelect Ralph G. Caso announced the appoint ment of Mr. Seniuk to the $31,900ayearjob today. Mr. Seniuk is currently associate counsel to the New York State Liquor Authority.

title: BankHolding Bill Gets Final Accord In Joint Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8The joint SenateHouse Conference Committee completed work to day on the onebank holding company bill, adopting wholly new language to resolve the controversy over the grand father clause, which is intended to exempt from the prohibitions of the bill acquisitions outside the banking field prior to a specified date.

title: Money
description: Tuesday, Dec. 8, 1970

title: Official American League Pitching Records for 1970
Top Nixon Aide Says Congress Is Cool to RevenueSharing Plan
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 8  Presi dent Nixon's top domestic pol icy adviser, John D. Ehrlich man, told a convention of Mayors and other local offi1 cials today that it would take an extraordinary effort to push the Administration's rev enuesharing program through, the next Congress.

title: Congress Receptive to Ban On Rail Strike Tomorrow
MINE UNION VOTES IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 8Can didates of the rebel faction of the late Joseph A. Yablonski in the United Mine Workers of America took an unexpected lead tonight in a bitterly con tested election for control of the union's District ,Five in Western. Pennsylvania.

title: For Men, Too
description: Don't laugh. Men are buying pantyhose. What's more, they're wearing them.

title: T.W.A. Sees Loss of Up to $65Million
description: Top management of Trans World Airlines conceded to its creditors last night that the troubled carrier was going to suffer a doss this year of be tween $60million and $65 million. However, the airline sought to reassure the creditors that rumors that the company faced collapse are completely unfounded.

title: Phelps Dodge to Cut Outlays
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, which led two recent American copper price cuts, yesterday an nounced plans to trim its plans to expand capacity during 1973 and 1974. The new program will involve substantially lower expenditures for mine develop ment in 1971 and 1972. This is designed to improve the com pany's cash position.

title: Q.E. IS ENTERING SHOW BUSINESS
description: General Electric, the world's largest manufacturer of elec trical and electronics equip ment, announced plans yester day to enter the entertainment production business.

title: COFFEY OF ARKANSAS NEW VA. TECH COACH
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Dec. (AP)  Charles E. Coffey, defensive coach at Arkansas since 1966, became head foot ball coach at Virginia Tech to day. He succeeded Jerry Clai borne, who resigned Nov. 25 after a 10year tenure.

title: Survey Praises and Criticizes Broadcast Journalism
description: Broadcast journalists in the United States were applauded for their saturation coverage of sweeping national and interna tional events during the 1969 1970 broadcast year, but chas tised for often reacting with timidity to outside criticisms such as those offered by Vice President Agnew.

title: TRADING SLOWS ON LONDON BOARD
description: Trading on the London stock exchange was almost at standstill yesterday due to slowdown by electrical work ers, who are seeking wage in creases, that sharply reduced the power supply to homes, offices and industrial plants.

title: MINORPARTY ROLE DISTURBS LEADERS
description: Concerned over the growing power of the Conservative party and the continuing in fluence of the Liberal party, the state's Republican and Demo ratic leaders are jointly, work ing on legislation and other measures to crimp the power of the two minor parties.

title: Suspected Is Extradicted
description: CLEVELAND, Dec. 8 (UPI) Claude E. Vealey, 26 years old, one of five suspects in the slay ings of Mr. Yablonski and his wife and daughter, was taken to Pennsylvania today to face murder charges. The four other suspects remained in Ohio jails. Mr. Vealey's reques for an ap peal of extradiction was denied by Judge John M. Manos of the Ohio 8th District court of ap peals in Cleveland.

title: BLACKS CRITICIZE A SCHOOL GROUP
description: The president of the Council of Supervisory Associations last night urged black public school officials to join his organization because unity would give all supervisors strength.

title: VANDERBILT HAILS TURF OPERATIONS
description: Alfred :Gwynn Vanderbilt expressed himself, as quite sat sfied yesterday with the opera tion of the New York Racing dissociation, which terminated the thoroughbred season In this state on Monday. Bear in mind though that it was Dreyfus's year, and only my month, said he.

title: Move to Clear Omnibus Social Security Bill Is Gaining in the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8A move to abandon all but the central core of the mammoth Sooial Security trade welfare bill, which is still growing in committee, gained strength in the Senate today.

title: CELTICS TROUNCE BRAVES BY 122102
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 8 (UPI) John Havlicek scored 34 points, 17 in each half, as the Boston Celtics trounced the Buffalo Braves, 122102, tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Protesting Caseworkers Describe Frustrations
description: Robert Jorlett, a 30yearold, welfare caseworker, opened a file cabinet holding records of the 91 relief cases that are his responsibility yesterday. He selected the 16 most routine ones, withdrew their bulky ma nila folders and, placing them on his cluttered desk, tied them together with a green cord.

title: CARDINAL GUT. DIES; HEADED. CURIA UNIT
description: ROME, Dec. 8 (AP)  Benno Cardinal Gut, a Swissborn member of the Roman Curia and the prefect of the Vatican Congregation for Diyine Wor ship, died tonight in a hOspital. He was 73 years old and had been suffering from a. circula tory ailment.

title: Trial Set in Armory Raid
description: BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP)Judge Frank J. Murray of Federal District Court has set Feb. for trial of William M. Gilday Jr., 41 years old, of Amesbury, on a charge of stealing Gov ernment property in a raid on the Newburyport Armory Mr. Gilday is one of five persons charged with murder of a Bos ton policeman and bank rob bery last September.

title: Martha Graham Wins Cultural Unit's Award
description: Martha Graham, the dancer and choreographer, received a special award from the AmericaIsrael Cultural Foun dation last night at the open ing of the Batsheva Dance Company of Israel at the City Center.

title: 20 Die of Cholera in Ghana
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Dec. 8 (Agence FrancePresse)  At least 20 persons have died in second outbreak of cholera in Ghana, it was announced. here today.

title: Aerial Sensor Is Shown Here For Spotting Water Pollution
description: A helicopter with electronic sensing gear crisscrossed the waters of the metropolitan area yesterday, trying to track down some of the thousands of potential water polluters.

title: DIVORCE RISE TIED TO 20YEAR SLUMP
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 8 (AP)The sevenyear itch, tra ditionally a scapegoat in the story of the climbing divorce rate, may have to share top billing With a new culpritthe 20year slump.

title: BUFFALO VOTES BAN ON LEAD IN GASOLINE
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 8The Com mon Council adopted an ordi nance today requiring every gasoline station in Buffalo to have at least one pump sup plying lowlead gasoline by next Sept. 1, and prohibiting the sale of all leaded gasoline in the city after Jan. 1, 1980. Councilman William B. Hoyt, sponsor of the ordinance, said it was the first of its kind in the nation.

title: School Trustees Elect Head
description: Edwin J. Beinecke Jr., vice president of the Sperry and Hutchinson Company, has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Human Re sources School, Albertson, L. I. The school provides an ac credited educational curriculum to 190 disabled children, from preschool through senior high school.

title: HOUSSEIN REQUEST FOR FURTHER AID BY U.S. REPORTED

title: City on the Neva
description: ANGELS holding candelabra kneel around the Byzantine dome of St. Isaac's. Three slender gold spires echo across the Neva and Moika. Everywhere lions, griffons and sphinxes stand guard over treasurehouses, or sleep. Victory, drawn by her six horses, gal lops atop Rossi's ingenious crooked arch. Porti cos by the hundred, thousands of pillars, pranc ing horses, straining bulls . . .

description: PARIS, Dec. 9 (UPI)Am bassador Arthur K. Watson complained today that Ameri ca's European allies sometimes turned a deaf ear when the United States wanted to dis cuss the important and press ing problem of United States trade policies.

title: The Impact of U.N. Resolutions
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 9The Security Council's con demnation of Portugal Tuesday for her alleged invasion of Guinea and its demand that she pay reparations was one of the strongest actions ever taken by the Council against a member of the United Nations. But it was not unique.

title: Saigon Orders OneDay Holiday Truces
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Dec. 9The South, Vietnamese Gov ernment has decided on one day truces for Christmas and New Years despite Washing ton's officially expressed inter est in an extended holiday ceasefire.

title: They Take Time Out to Help Others
description: Sheila Davis recently spent three months working with children in a leper village near Katmandu, Nepal, She hated to leave but she was due back at her job. Miss Davis is a stewardess on the DallasNew York route of Braniff International.

title: Screen: A War Mission:Rock Hudson Starred in 'Hornet's Nest'
description: Phil Karlson's "Hornet's Nest," which opened yesterday at the Victoria and neighborhood theaters, pits Rock Hudson along with 15 young boys against a significant portion of the Nazi forces occupying Italy in 1944. Rock Hudson wins, and thereby saves not only himself and the boys but also Sylva Koscina, a German army doctor who proves her goodness by shooting fellow Germans when the chips are down, and Sergio Fantoni, a German captain who proves his goodness by a) hating the SS, b) admiring Rock Hudsons military genius and c) evidencing a kind of sly fondness for the boys, who are rapidly cutting his troops to ribbons.The importance of Hudson's mission (he has been parachuted behind the German lines in order to blow up a dam) is never really made opaque, let alone clear. And this is merely one of so many faults on almost every level you can imagine, that I could understand anybody's temptation to dismiss "Hornet's Nest" as a bad movie that does not even satisfy its own fairly modest ambitions.A bad movie, perhaps, but interesting enough in its characters (though always faintly ridiculous in its actions) and with a sufficiently complex performance from Rock Hudson to merit attention and some respect.Although Miss Koscina trails along for, I guess, sexual as well as medical purposes, and although Hudson has at her in one very perfunctory rape, the real interest in "Hornets' Nest" has to do with the antagonism, acceptance and, ultimately, love that passes between Hudson and the boys  especially their leader, Mark Colleano.The Phil Karlson movies I most admireout of a long and active career these include "The Phenix City Story" (1954), "The Brothers Rico" (1957), "Hell to Eternity" (1960)are strong in their understanding of male relationships that in some cases are also family relationships.If "Hornets" Nest' is about anything, it is about such relationshipsin effect, about the difficult and uneasy bringing together of a father and a son. And on this level, as opposed to all other levels, the film is alive and responsive to the emotional potential of its dramatic progress.Christmas is coming, at least at the neighborhood showcases, some of which unveiled "Horror House" yesterday. This atrocious hack-'em-up bundle from Britain involves a group of young Carnaby Street parasites in the mysterious butchery of a haunted mansion outside London. The young swingers actually get outswung by a glistening butcher knife."Teddibly noisy in hyah," murmurs one of them, shortly before getting a seasonal carving.Customers at the New Amsterdam on West 42d Street weren't spared after The End. In a pell-mell rush came three successive previews of coming attractions, retaining the spirit. First we saw a sailor quartering crewmen with an axe. Next was a peek at a goody about the transplanting of living human heads.In the third tantalizer, mother was a vampire, bidding her son farewell with a tender chomp on the neck. Deck the halls and run.

title: Severe Quake Strikes PeruEcuador Border
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP)An earthquake almost as strong as one that killed an estimated 50,000 persons in Peru last May struck a border area of Peru and Ecuador last night.

title: STEWART'S GOAL EARNS DEADLOCK
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 A makeshift line comprised of Rod Selling at left wing, Jean Ratelle at center and Ron Stewart at right wing rescued the Rangers late in the third period tonight to give New York a 22 tie with the Los Angeles Kings.

description: A school in the Jamaica sec tion of Queens was the target at 2 A.M. yesterday of home made fire bombs that caused slight damage. Seven hours later, stones and eggs.were thrown at a nearby school by some of the 150 pupils and adults who have been conduct ing a boycott.

description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, arranged yesterday for a new mediation session in the taxi strike, which is now in its sixth day.

description: Directors of the Bohack cor poration authorized yesterday a threefortwo common stock split to be distributed Jan. 29 of record Dec. 29. This will in crease 778,580 outstanding com mon shares to 1,167,870 shares.

description: BELLMORE, L. I, Dec. 9 George W. Mortimer, a retired postal employe, died today at his home here, 1985 Bergen Street, after a long illness. He would have been 92 years old next Wednesday. He retired from the Post Office in 1933.

title: Heir to Bing's Post Plans More Contemporary Met
description: The Metropolitan Opera yesterday chose Goeran Gen tele, 53yearold head of the Royal Opera House in Stock holm, to replace Rudolf Bing as general manager. The rud dyfaced Swedish adminis trator and sta??e director im mediately said that be planned to modernize the Metropolitan's repertory, and to stress the theatrical and dramatic aspects of opera as much as the music.

description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 9Louis Antal, the candidate of a rebel group in the United Mine Workers of America, held a 514vote lead here today in a bitter contest with Michael Budzanoski, the incumbent, for presidency of the union's Dis trict 5.

title: The Bamboozle Bill

They also wanted it to carry their own version of President Nixon's welfare reform plan. Knowing that Social Security improvement traditionally the final measure to be considered before adjournment and no Senator likes to vote against it, Senator Long reportedly said, This is going to be the last train and everybody better be aboard it.

title: Issues in the Rail Dispute
description: PARTIESAbout 80 per cent of the 500,000 railroad employes, including 220,000 represented by three unions the Brotherhood of Railway and Airline Clerks, the Brother hood of Maintenance of Way Employes and the Hotel and Restaurant Employes Union. Also, 180,000 brakemen, train men, conductors, engineers and firemen represented by the United Transportation Union are on strike, but 100,000 railroad employes belonging to various shoperaft unions are not. Also involved are more than 150 railroads that employ members of these unions, including 69 of the na tion's 71 class one railroads (the Long Island Railroad and the Florida EastCoast Railroad are not affected)

title: `I. Walter Smintheus Opens ANTA Series
description: There appears to be no end to the supply of young, vital black playwrights. At the ANTA Matinee Series on Tuesday afternoon at the Theater de Lys, Edgar White offered The Life and Times of J. Walter Smintheus. Mr. White, a West Indian who has had a number of plays showcased by the New York Shakespeare Festival, has here tackled a still unusual black theme. The problem of the black bourgeoisie. Blacks in the ghetto we know about, but how about the pressures on comfortable middleclass blacks?

Stehle, a vice president and general manager of the com pany's appliance and tele vision sales division, said prices of all models of G.E. and Hotpoint gas and electric clothes dryers would be raised by 3 to 4 per cent.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Dec. 10 (AP)An enemy force blasted a South Vietnamese command post in the Fishhook area just inside Cambodia, killing or wounding at least half the defenders and destroying several trucks, the military command reported to da??

description: Two stockholders of Brown Company filed a $16.8million damage suit Tuesday in Fed eral District Court in New York against that company, its direc tors and Gulf & Western Indus tries. Inc.. which controls it.

title: Cow Sets Milk Record
description: WASHINGTON; Dec. 9 (UPI) The Agriculture Department said today that a 1,450pound cow named Ballard had broken the world's milkproducing rec ordrmore than 4,765 gallons during the 12month period ending Monday. The 5yearold Holstein is owned by the Glen Lu Knoll farm at Frederick, Md.

title: 1 CIRCUIT PACKAGE INTRODUCED BY G.E.
description: The General Electric Company announced here yesterday a new process for automatic mass pro duction and packaging of in tegrated circuits. The company's integrated circuits department also showed the first two prod ucts in the line.

title: Swiss President Is Chosen
description: BERN, Switzerland, Dec. 9 (AP)The two houses of the Swiss Parilament elected De fense Minister Rudolf Gnaegi today as President of Switzer land for 1971. By tradition the presidency rotates among the seven members of the Cabinet.

title: ST. JOHN'S POSTS 66T053 TRIUMPH
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9  Sevenfoot Bill Phillips, who played only 23 minutes last sea son, was the big star for St. John's tonight as the Redmen defeated highly regarded St. Joseph's, 6653, before 5,000 at the Palestra.

title: Negotiators Fail To Agree on Rules In Theater Dispute
description: The League of New York Theaters agreed yesterday to submit its contract dispute to arbitration, but Actors Equity Association declined to accept the proposal unless several con ditions were excluded from arbi tration.

title: The United States Abstains
description: The United States suffered a serious erosion of credi bility with Africa and the Third World when it abstained as the United Nations Security Council condemned Portugal for the recent invasion of Guinea.

title: Cars Getting Hot Under the Collar
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 The mili tancy of the automobiles Is rising. Anyone who still does any walking must surely have noticed.

title: Pregnancy Discharge By Air Force Backed
description: SAN FRANCISCO. Dec. 9 (UPIThe Air Force has the right to discharge an unwed officer who becomes ?? nant a united States Appeals Court ruled today.

title: Job Bias on Rails Charged
description: WASHINGTON; Dec. 9Wil liam H. Brown 3d, chairman of the Equal Employment Oppor tunity Commission, accused American railroads today of job discrimination in violation of the Civil Rights Act of 1964.

title: Books Of The Times
description: Viva may just be the girl Vice President Agnew is warning us against. Her first novel, Superstar, concerns the life and times of an actress named Gloria in those permissive underground movies, but the reader will immediately smell a roman clef in the woodpile. Let's not be coy about it: it hits you in the face like a custard pieor, to be faithful to the underground imag ery, like a panful of those brownies that Alice B. Tok las used to bake. Viva is, of course, an actress in a number of films by Andy Warhol as is her heroine, Gloria (Gloria in excelsis deo, to give her the full title accorded by A, lion of the art world, King of the underground movie, and undis of the misfits). Gloria Is not the product or a permissive home, however: she came out of a strict upstate New York Catholic girl hood. Such a girlhood would shock Mary McCarthy herself.

title: JOSEPH H. M'INTOSH
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Dec. 9. Joseph H. McIntosh, a reporter of The Plainfield CourierNews, The Newark StarLedger and The Elizabeth Daily Journal, for more than 50 years, died last night in a nursing home in Elizabeth after a brief ill ness. His age was 78 and he lived at 135 Madison Avenue.

title: Kentucky Forward Hurt
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 9 (AP)Kentucky's 6foot5inch starting forward, Larry Steele, suffered a fracture of his right thumb in basketball practice today. He was expected to be out of the lineup for at least two weeks.

title: Market Place.
description: A Market That Grew and Grew

title: U. S. Field Trial Championships Go to EnglishBred Springers
description: Englishbred dogs owned on opposite sides of the con tinent, Saighton Sizzler and Misty Muffet, have become this year's national cham pions in English springer spaniel field trials. Mrs. Ev elyn Monte of New York, secretary of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association and judge and owner handler in the breed, told about the victories yes terday,

title: A Glimpse Into Hughes's Hidden Life
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 9 The struggle for control over Howard Hughes's $150 million investment in Ne vada has cracked the shell of secrecy around the ec centric billionaire and pro vided new insights into his mysterious style of life.

title: Controversial Israeli
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 9With a quick goodby to his col leagues, the Israeli Minister of Defense hurried out of a Cabinet meeting a few Sun days ago on his way to some delicate negotiations deep in the Arab quarter of Old Jerusalem.

title: President Accused of Pressure On Census Bureau to Aid G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The chairman of the House Census Subcommittee accused the Nixon Administration today of trying to rejuggle the release of 1970 cens??s data in order to benefit lameduck Republicans in Ohio, Florida and other states.

title: Southern but Not Strategic
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9In the 1970 elections, the Republicans lost gover norships in Florida and Arkansas, failed to win Senate seats they had avidly sought in Florida and Texas, gained only one House seat through out the Old Confederacy, suffered sig nificant losses in the Legislatures of North Carolina and Tennessee, and watched helplessly as George Wallace was returned to the Alabama gover norship. Nevertheless, first indications Suggest President Nixon is clinging to the famous Southern strategy that pro duced such a dull thud last month.

title: Nixon Aids Wichita State
description: WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 9 (AP) President Nixon has contrib uted $500 to a fund for surviv ors of a Colorado plane crash that killed 31 players, officials and boosters of the Wichita State University football team. A fund spokesman said that Carroll Rosenbloom, owner of the Baltimore Colts football team, had sent a check for $50,000, Mr. Rosenbloom also gave $50,000 to Marshall Uni versity. Thirtyseven Marshall players died in a, plane crash.

title: Casper, Gary Player Favored In Argentine Pro Golf Today
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 (UPI) Billy Casper, Gary Player and a young Australian, David Gra ham, will be among the favo rites tomorrow when 72 golfers tee off in the annual Argentine Masters tournament. The home town player, Roberto de Vicen zo, will also be high on the odds list over the 6,542yard, par70 Olivos Golf Club course. He is a threetime winner of the event.

title: DEMOCRATS OF LEFT TO MEET SATURDAY
description: WASHINGTON. Dec. 9Fif teen to 20 members of the Democratic party's left wing are planning to meet in Chicago Saturday to discuss their future approach to politics.

title: Official Says Postal Corporation Will Act to Speed Business Mail
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The Post Office plans to introduce new services to improve the handling of business mail after it becomes a public corporation next year, a top official has disclosed.

title: Flight From Civic Reality
description: The police and fire forces so vital to New York City's safety have displayed both their best and worst sides recent days.

title: I.C.C. Calls Meeting Dec. 17 To Discuss Jersey Central
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday invited Government, labor and railroad officials to attend a Dec. 17 conference in Washington on the faltering Central Railroad of New Jersey.

title: Education Board Curbs Use of Nonofficial Flags
description: The Board of Education di ??cted yesterday that only the American, state and city flags could be flown on school buildings.

title: Letters by Mishima to Friends Foretold Suicide
description: Shortly before his ritual sui cide last month, Yukio Mishi ma, the renowned Japanese novelist, wrote letters to friends here foretelling his death.

title: Yugoslays to Publish Memoir
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9 (AP)A Yugoslav Publishing company will soon publish the purported memoirs of Nikita S. Khrushchev, the former Soviet leader, now appearing in Life magazine, the Zagreb daily Vjesnik reported today. The paper said Otokar Kersovani, a publishing company in Rijeka, had signed a contract with Lit tle, Brown & Co., acquiring rights to publish the memoirs in SerboCroatian.

title: Sports of The Times
description: So Far So Good

title: MISS HELLER GIVES HER PRIZE RECITAL
description: Marsha Heller's oboe pro gram at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night was a model of how an event of this sort should be. It was varied in mu sical style, in instrumental and Vocal color, and each work cre ated an expectant atmosphere for the next.

title: DRESSER PROFITS RISE IN QUARTER
description: Earnings Set Mark in Year Sales Also at Record

title: THOMAS RAYNOR, 70, GREENWICH REALTOR
description: GREENWICH, Conn.; Dec. Thomas H. Raynor, a Mem ber of the Greenwich Planning and Zoning Commission since 1956 and a leading real estate man, died today at Greenwich Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived on Grove Lane here

title: UPROAR DISRUPTS IRISH PARLIAMENT
description: DUBLIN, Dec. 9The Irish Parliament was adjourned in uproar today over Prime Min ister John Lynch's explanation of a reported kidnapping con spiracy and his threat to intern extremists.

title: FIVE NEW DANCES BY PAT CATTERSON
description: Choreographer Uses Her Troupe With Intelligence

title: Hugo Weisgall Conducts Own Works
description: Hugo Weisgall's music was the subject of the Com posers in Performance con cert in Rogers Auditorium at the Metropolitan Museum on Tuesday night, and Mr. Weis gall was on hand to conduct the two works presented. The first was Fancies and Inven tions, a cycle of 10 songs to poems from Robert Her rick's The Hesperides, and the other was The Strong er, his oneact opera of 1952 based on Strindberg's clay.

title: DIFFICULT MAHLER SHINES FOR SOLTI
description: 7th Symphony Played by Visiting Chicagoans

title: SUPREME SOVIET DEBATES BUDGET
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 9  Pre mier Aleksei N. Kosygin alter nately fingered a pencil, smiled broadly at remarks whispered to him by another Soviet leader, and clasped his hands and listened, as members of the Supreme Soviet today discussed the economic plans and budget for 1971.

title: 1 Rescued, 1 Is Dead, 1 Still Trapped in Mine
description: ANJEAN, W. Va., Dec. 9 (UPI)One of three miners trapped by a massive rock fall was rescued in good con dition tonight from a coal mine in this southern West Virginia village. Another was brought out dead.

title: Air Force Jet Crash Kills 2
description: EDENTON, N. C., Dec. 9 (AP) An Air Force F4E jet crashed in Phelps Lake on a training mission yesterday, killing two crewmen. Seymour Johnson Air Force Base, where the fliers were stationed, identified them as Capt. William F. Rogers, 28 years old, of Mankato, Minn., the pilot, and Capt. Edward J. Gallaher, 33, of New York City, the navigator.

title: Airman Leads Manila Golf
description: MANILA, Dec. 9 (UPI) M/Sgt. Ken Davis of the United States Air Force from Colorado shot a course record 6under par 62 today to lead 185 golf ers in the first round of the 21st FilAmerican tournament at the United States John Hays Base course at Baguio, 150 miles north of Manila. Davis, who has three fingers missing on his right hand, had six birdies in his round.

title: NAZARETH ELECTION PRODUCES NO SHIFT
description: TEL AVIV, Dec. 9 Israeli Arabs who have cooperated with the Israeli Government and those actively hostile to it retained their relative strength in the local election held yester day in Nazareth. The polling was for the Municipal Council in the predominantly Arab Galilee city of more than 30,000 people.

title: STOCKS REBOUND; ATTAIN EVEN KEEL
description: Early ProfitTaking Decline Is Erased by Late Rally Dow Industrials Up 0.14

title: Tito Puts Off Italy Trip, Apparently Over Trieste
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 9  Yugoslavia and Italy have agreed to an 11thhour post ponement of a state visit Pres ident Tito was to have made to Rome tomorrow, according, to a joint announcement this evening.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY

description: OPENING TONIGHT

title: On a $200aDay Safari in Kenya: Caviar and 6Course Meals

title: Man Sentenced for Murder
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 9 (UPI) Jay T. Pobllner, a textile ex ecutive, was sentenced today to 25 yearstolife imprison ment in Sing Sing Prison for the murder of his wife, Brenda, in their Merrick, L. I., home in December, 1968. The sentence was imposed by Nassau County Court Judge Paul Kelly.

title: Maida Million Is 5 to 2 in Rich Pace
description: WESTBURY, L. I., Dec. 9 Because Maida Million won both her preliminary starts in the fall pacing festival at Roosevelt Raceway, the 6yearold Aus tralianbred mare had the high est average earnings in the series. Since berths were deter mined on the basis of average moneywinning, this distinction automatically placed her in the No. 8 post for Saturday night's $25,000 final at the Nassau County course.

title: Group of Lawyers Fights a City Ban On Debt Notification
description: A group of lawyers who col lect bad debts asked yesterday for a State Supreme Court or der nullifying a part of the city's Consumer Protection Law that prevents them from get ting in touch with a debtor's employer before obtaining a final court judgment against him.

title: Film: Costa-Gavras Depicts a Believer's Betrayal by His Belief:Montand and Signoret Star in 'Confession' Other Movies Arrive on Local Screens
description: Costa-Gavras's "The Confession," which opened yesterday at the Beekman Theater, is not, I think, a better movie than his prize-winning "Z," with which it will inevitably be compared, not only by the critics but also by those members of the public who may look for a repeat performance. The earlier film was a nearly perfect topical thriller whose form pretty much defined the substance of its liberal politics.However, because the subject of "The Confession" is much more complex, much more human, I find it vastly more interesting than "Z," even when one is aware of the way Costa-Gavras manipulates attention by the use of flashy cinematic devices that sometimes substitute for sustained drama. It is a horror story of the mind told almost entirely in factual and physical terms, which is something of a contradiction.These are, however, the terms of which Costa-Gavras is a movie master, and in which Artur London originally wrote his book, adapted for the screen by Jorge Semprun, who also wrote the script for "Z.""The Confession" is the real-life story of Artur London, a loyal Communist who certified his credentials by serving with the International Brigade in Spain and with the Communist anti-Nazi underground in France, and by a long term in a Nazi concentration camp. In 1949, Mr. London returned to his native Czechoslovakia from France to become Under Secretary for Foreign Affairs in the Communist Government of President Klement Gottwald. Two years later, along with 13 other leading Czech Communists (11 of whom were Jewish), Mr. London was arrested for treason and espionage and found guilty in what became known as .the "Slansky trial."The Slansky trial, named for the secretary general of the Czech Communist party, who was also a defendant, was one of the last major gasps of the Stalinist purges that began with the Moscow trials in the 1930's. All of the Slansky defendants were found guilty and all but three, including Mr. London, were executed.Mr. London lived not only to see the defendants rehabilitated and to write his book but also to return to Czechoslovakia on the day in August, 1968, when Soviet troops invaded his country to end the short Czech spring."The Confession," with Yves Montand playing Mr. London and Simone Signoret his wife Lise, is the story of a believer's ultimate betrayal by his belief, of intolerable physical torture and psychological harassment (London is urged to confess to crimes he did not commit to prove his loyalty to the party), and, finally, of survival.It is a harrowing film of intellectual and emotional anguish, dramatized by the breathless devices of melodrama. Costa-Gavras employs abrupt jump cuts and flashes forward as well as back. He underscores the desperation of the meeting of some hunted men in a private apartment with the sounds of children roughhousing in the next room. It may, in fact, be one of the most aurally resonant movies I've ever seen. It is full of ordinary sounds made somehow ominous, like the slamming of doors (car, house, prison) and footsteps (on wood, brick, concrete).Its color photography by Raoul Coutard is also fine (natural overhead light in all the interiors), even when resorting to the zoom, which can be a legitimate tool in melodrama. Beginning with Mr. Montand and Miss Signoret, it is perfectly cast. One really responds to the faces, the attitudes and gestures in a Costa-Gavras film, as when, during the trial, the trousers of one of the emaciated defendants fall to the floor and he turns to the court with an expression of hopeless, perfectly confused laughter and despair."The Confession" is a film of movement and sensation, as was "Z," but there is at its center a complex human being. Like the book, it is an anti-Stalinist rather than anti-Communist polemic (Mr. London has written that he is interested in putting "a human face" on national socialism). One tends to forget the context, of the Londons' experiencethe totality of a belief that would prompt a wife to denounce a husband that she has loved for almost 20 years, simply because the Party had to be right.You might not know it from the film, but the Londons are different from you and meand from Arthur Koestler, whose disenchantment came earlier (1937) and was more complete. In a recent interview, Mr. Koestler recalled the blind party discipline that he eventually denied as he quoted Andr Malraux: "A life is worth nothing, but nothing is worth a life." Because this is also the essence of "The Confession," I liked it very much, even when its form is in combat with its substance.

title: Mr. Nixon and the Press: A Few Questions
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 President Nixon will hold his first news conference in 19 weeks tomorrow evening, and the event has raised many more questions here than he can possibly handle in the allotted 29minute television slot. When the President last submitted to public questioning, there was

title: Clarkson Six Wins, 41
description: POTSDAM, N. Y., Dec. 9 Clarkson College defeated St. Lawrence University, 41, to night. Jerry Kemp scored two goals for Clarkson and Larry Fleetham and Mike Conroy also connected. Glenn Johnson reg istered for the losers. Clarkson now has an 801 wonlosttied record.

title: Ethics Board Assailed in Postel Case
description: The city's Board of Ethics was assailed yesterday as un ethical.

title: Corporate Bond Offering Holds to a Rate of 7.85%
description: The corporate bond market, shouldering a heavy sched ule of new financing, held yesterday the ground it gained in its recent monthlong rush toward lower interest notes. The Gulf States Utilities Com pany sold a $30million issue of highgrade bonds and un derwriters priced them to yield 7.85 per cent, the same as the return on a similarly rated issue of Southern Cali fornia Edison Company bonds marketed last Thursday.

title: CHI CHENG TO RUN TODAY IN BANGKOK
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 9 (AP)  Chi Cheng, the, track star from Nationalist China concerned about how much her injured left leg would hamper her in the Asian Games, took a day of rest today for her first race tomorrow.

title: Advertising: Europeans Doing Own Thing
description: Just back from a triumphal, whirlwind tour of the Con tinent and a sojurn in Merrie England, John E. O'Toole, the top knocker of Foote, Cone & Belding, was ready yesterday to share his philosophical overview of the advertising scene.

title: British Council Safeguards Freedom and Standards of the Press
description: LONDON, Dec. 9  Brit ain's Press Council, a model for a similar council recom mended in Canada today, is a voluntary organization that was set up in 1953. It has the dual role of preserving the freedom of the press and safe guarding professional standards.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Poor Need Railroads

title: RESERVES OF BANKS DEFINED BY BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP)  The Federal Reserve Board held today that a member bank may count as reserves only the currency or coin that it has an unrestricted right to use.

title: Marine's Medal Restored
description: McALESTER, Okla., Dec. (UPI)Randall Herrod of Cal vin, a former marine who had his Silver Star medal taken away from him when he was originally charged in the slay ings in Mylai 4, will get his medal back tomorrow. A court martial in Vietnam has ac quitted the marine. He will get the medal at the Naval Depot here.

title: Civil Service Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UPI) The Civil Service Commis sion chairman, Robert E. Hampton, appointed Fernando E. C. DeBaca today as the top advisor for a new program to help Spanishspeaking Ameri cans find Federal Government jobs. Mr. DDeBaca, 32 years old, is Commissioner of Motor Vehicles for the State of New Mexico..

title: HARLOW RESIGNS AS AIDE TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9  Bryce N. Harlow, counselor to President Nixon and a longtime friend, resigned today from the White House staff to return to private life.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: A Reminder of When Homemade Flies of Goose Feather Had Trout Biting

title: LESLIE CANNON, LED BRITISH TRADE UNION
description: LONDON, Dec. 9  Leslie Cannon, president of the 365, 000member Electrical Trades Union, died of cancer today at Northwood, Middlesex. He was 50 years old.

title: Planners Approve $57Million Complex in Lower Manhattan.
description: A $57million highrise and townhouse residential complex of 1,320 housing units in the Washington. Street urban re newal area of lower Manhattan was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.

title: Personal Finance
description: Keeping of Careful Records Can Enable Businessmen to Deduct Christmas Gifts

title: NIXON IS SCORED ON OPEN HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 9The National Committee Against Dis crimination in Housing accused the White House today of blocking efforts by George Romney and other ??icials to open suburban comn??nities to lowincome families.

title: CERF STEPS DOWN AT RANDOM HOUSE
description: Bennett Cerf stepped down yesterday as chairman of the board of Random House, a post he has held since 1965. He will be succeeded as of Jan. 1 by Donald Klopfer, who has been vice chairman of the board for the last five years. Mr. Cerf and Mr. Klopfer were cofounders of the publishing house in 1927, and Mr. Cerf had been its president until 1965.

title: Johnson Declines an Offer To Be Fellow at Yale Now
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 9 (AP)  Former President Lyn don B. Johnson has declined, for the time being, an invita tion to become a Chubb Fellow at Yale University, a spokes man said today.

title: COPELAND OFFERED A BANKRUPTCY DEAL
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 9 A Federal bankruptcy referee today approved a transaction in Which Lammot du Pont Cope land Jr. would give the Michi gan National Bank title to an undeveloped tract of land in Houston, and the bank would cancel Mr. Copeland's $500,000 debt under a mortgage the bank held.

title: Cecil MontgomeryMoore, Decorated in World War
