description: Meteorologists of many na tions are drawing up plans for what promises to be the most ambitious study of the weather ever undertaken.

title: But What Are You Doing New Year's Day?
description: EXHAUSTIVE attention has already been given to the variety of New Year's Eve entertain ment available to New York ers, but virtually nothing has been written about the excit ing possibilities that await them on the morning after.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND FOR THE NEEDIEST
The Christmas Tree, With Roots in Germany, Is Still the Favorite There
description: BONN, Dec. 19  The greenery that goes with Christmas and with other celebrations was never ex clusively German, but the Christmas tree, still the cen ter of the celebrations here, is German in origin, accord ing to the. Encyclopaedia Britannica and Willi Pfeffer. Willi is one of the country hucksters who sell the trees in the Munsterplatz here.

title: Behind the Polish Crisis
description: The outbreak of foodprice riots in agricultural Poland after a quartercentury of Communist rule testifies both to the discontent of a misgoverned nation and the bank ruptcy of a politicoeconomic system.

title: NEGRO AIDE WARNS OF G.I. RACE TENSION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UPI) The Pentagon's topranking Negro civilian said today that it was possible that racial dis crimination in the nation's armed forces could impair their combat effectiveness.

title: MARC BOEGNER, 89, CLERGYMAN, DIES
description: PARIS, Dec. 19The Rev. Marc Boegner, for several dec ades a leader of the Protestant Church in France, died at his home here last night at the age of 89.

title: AutomaticElevator Buttons Activated by Finger's Heat called Fire Hazard
description: Some automatic elevators might be death traps in a fire drawn by heat to the floor where the flames are raging.

title: Basil Edward Keiser Fiance Of Antonia BromleyDavenport

title: Art
description: THE Guggenheim Mu seum has a surprise waiting for you if you are accustomed to thinking of Joaquin Torres Garcia as a minor but secure member of the constellation of artists who, with Picasso at the radiant center, lit the way to modern art. Minor he looks, without question, in this survey of his work. But secure? That becomes a ques tion indeed. There are 65 paintings, 7 drawings, 12 sculptures, and a cluster of wooden toys in the show, and do you know how they look? They look amateurish, that's how they look.

title: Margaret Roscia Wed
description: PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., Dec. 19Miss Margaret Tay lor Roscia, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Jay Roscia, was married here this after noon to Timothy Kirk Erga nian. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kirk Erganian of Glendale. The ceremony in St. Matthew's Episcopal Church was performed by Canon Kenneth Cary.

title: Roster of Winners of Individual and Team Championships During 1970
How Crooked Apollo Led Young Tolya to Marijuana
description: MOSCOW Dec. 19 (AP)  A Moscow weekly magazine tells how Tolya Meshcheryakov, a normal Soviet teenager from Tashkent, fell in with Crooked Apollo and his crowd of mari juana smokers. It is the first indication by the Soviet press that a drug problem has de veloped in the Soviet Union.

title: At Wedding In Houston Pageantry Flourishes
description: The trend in weddings, as virtually everybody knows by now, is toward the informal. But the message apparently isn't getting through to Houston's aris tocratic upper echelon, a group that considers elegance a way of life.

title: BLUE CROSS TO ASK 19% RATE INCREASE
description: Blue Cross announced yester day that it would seek an aver age increase of 19.3 per cent in hospital insurance rates on its standard, or socalled commu nity rated, policies covering 3.4 million people in New York City, in the lower Hudson Val ley and on Long Island.

title: Ferro Appointed to Head City Building Department
description: Joseph Ferro was appointed yesterday the new Commission er of the Department of Build ings by Mayor Lindsay.

title: On Christmas Day No More Current Events
description: ISTARTED teaching poetry writing at P.S. 61, which is in Manhattan on East 12th Street between Ave nues B and C, in 1968. I hoped to find a way of teaching the subject that would make children as happy to write poems as they are to draw and paint, and after a few months it seemed to me that I had found it.

title: Day Care? In France, It's a Science
description: PARIS  While American mothers, Government officials and industry exec utives are just awakening to the neces sity for day care centers, French work ing mothers have had a place to leave and educatetheir preschool children since 1887.

title: Ussery Completes Triple Aboard Lion Sleeps in Coral Gables at Tropical
Gus Could Be Harry, Harry Could Be Archie ...
Carnival Spirit Engulfs Brazil
description: Evoking a spontaneous celebration by Latins round the world, the free wheeling Brazilian squad captured the World Cup at Mexico City with a 41 victory over Italy.

title: Billy Taylor's Big Economy Jazz Band
description: BILLY TAYLOR: OK Billy (Bell 6049). The orchestra that Billy Taylor leads on TV's David Frost Show, is, by customary standards, an economy version of a big band  only three saxo phones, two trumpets and a single trombone. This may be a blessing in disguise because the heaviness and the piling of overloaded section on overloaded section that has been the bane of much big band jazz recording curing the past 20 years is happily missing in these loose, swing ing performances. Sheer mas siveness is replaced by the power and presence that can be drawn from a fiveman rhythm section (using both drums and percussion) with the strong cushion of an elec tric bass, and from recording of such clean, balanced clar ity that it puts everything right in the listener's lap.

title: Barbara H. Newman Is Fiancee Of John Moorhead Trainer Jr.
description: FAIRMONT, N. J., Dec. 19 The engagement of Miss Barbara Holmes Newman, a Vassar senior, to John Moor head Trainer Jr., a student at Marietta College, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Allen Newman, par ents of the future bride. Her fianc is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Trainer of Sewickley, Pa., and Muskoka, Ontario.

title: Sarah Myers To Be a Bride
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 19  Miss Sarah Elizabeth Myers and John Edward Mc Ginty plan to be married here July 31.

title: Raid at Caesars Palace Spurs a Gambling Inquiry
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. Dec. 19 (UPI)The Clark County Li quor and Licensing Board has ordered an investigation into the gambling operations of Caesars Palace Hotel in the wake of a Federal raid at the hotel last weekend.

title: Going Rural
description: COZAD, Neb.  From the windwhipped point where this town's tiny main street begins, it is possible these days to see two towering grain elevators, an alfalfa processing plant, an enor mous cattle feeding lot, and the squat, windowless build ings of the Monroe Auto Equipment Company.

title: A Brooklyn Center For Arts Is Opened In Bank Building
description: Several hundred neighbor hood residents and visitors at tended the opening Friday night of The Bank, a cultural and recreational center at 1 Front Street, Brooklyn.

title: India:
description: NEW DELHI  A New Del hi newspaper cartoon the other day showed a politician address ing a turbaned maharaja. May I address you, your temporary highness? the politician asked. The cartoon touched a polit ical nerve.

title: South Carolina Five Wins
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Dec. 19 (UPI)Tom Riker's second re bound shot as time ran out gave secondranked South Carolina a 7876 victory over Virginia Tech tonight.

title: Carolann Galante Sets Marriage to Importer
description: LOUDONVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 19Miss Carolann Galante and Charles Jacobson, a San Francisco importer of Euro pean fashions, will be mar ried Jan. 23.

title: Bartow H. Underhill Dies at 71; Started Career as Artist at 52
description: MADISON, N. J., Dec. 19 Bartow H. Underhill, a sculptor and painter, who began as an artist at the age of 52 after a career in communications and with the State Department, died today in the Pine Acres Nursing Home. He was 71 and lived in Flanders.

title: Brazil Ambassador to U.S., 52; Acted as Envoy to Free French
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Mozart Gurgel Valente, Brazil's Ambassador to the United States, died today of an appar ent heart attack.

title: City Preparing for Strike By Its Uniformed Forces
description: There is a sixinchthick looseleaf book on the corner of Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio's desk with detailed contingency plans for use if the city's firemen, policemen and sanitationmen strike on New Year's Day.

title: To Betty Ottinger, Ecology Is a Fighting Word
description: Betty Ann Ottinger takes showers rather than baths, carries her own canvas tote bag when she shops and is wrap ping her Christmas presents in news papers. She'd like other women to do the sameto become as ecologically aware as she is herself.

title: MEXICO STARS TOP MESABI STATE, 76
description: MEXICO CITY, Dec. 19 (UPI) Plagued by penalties, fumbles and pass interceptions, Mesabi State Junior College of Vir ginia, Minn., lost, 76, today to the Mexican College AllStars in the Aztec Bowl.

title: IRVINGTON HOUSE TO SHUT HOSPITAL
description: Because of financial troubles, Irvington House, which per forms research on rheumatic fever and related diseases and treats sufferers, particularly children, will close its hospital next week and gradually end its outpatient clinic.

title: New York Can Capture Eastern Crown
description: The profusion of possibilities that have bewildered partici pants as well as football fans for the last two weeks begin to turn into a few hard reali ties at 1:05 P.M. today when the New York Giants face the Los Angeles Rams at Yankee Stadium on the final day of the National Football League's regular season.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The salutary influence of technology on the bewilder ing, fragmented societies of the late 20th century and thereafter depends in a large way upon the waxing of the minds of its overseers. To go a step further, the suc cess of technology in itself, and even the survival of its best forms, is hinged to the extension of what could be described as the multiple vision of the sophisticated, urban mind.

title: I'm for Mama and Taken Aback Take Divisions at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 19A frontrunner and a late closer won divisions of the Poquessing Handicap, in thrilling finishes today at Liberty Bell Race Track, where the crowd of 19,142 included 65 busloads from New York and Northern New Jersey.

title: ALABAMA BAPTISTS GETTING CHARTER
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 19 More than 300 Baptists who left their downtown church when Negroes were barred from membership have formed a new congregation dedicated to an in terracial ministry.

title: Democrats Named to Pick Site of 1972 Convention
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP)  The Democratic National Chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, has named six members and four officers of the National Committee to recommend a site for the party's 1972 convention.

title: Sue Blagden Wed To Henry Blagden
description: LIME ROCK, Conn., Dec. 19Miss Sue Rich Blagden and Henry Harrison Blagden of Matinicus Island, Me., who are cousins onceremoved, were married here this after noon at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs, Augustus Silliman Blagden. The cere mony was performed by the Rev. Mr. Arthur Lee Kinsolv ing, retired rector of St. James Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Tower Plan Stirs Battle at Gettysburg
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa., Dec. 19Four score and seven days ago, Thomas R. Otten stein, a wealthy Washington news dealer and real estate promoter, brought forth upon this hallowed ground a plan for a 300foothigh tourist tower at the Gettysburg Na tional Military Park.

title: Knicks Spotlighted in Sport's Boom
description: The melodramatic triumph of the New York Knickerbockers, who won the National Basketball Association cham pionship despite an injury to their key player, Willis Reed, was only one facet of the most eventful, most prosperous and most extensive season professional basketball ever had.

title: Kentucky Five Upset, 8983
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 19 (AP)  Bill Franklin sparked Purdue to an 8983 upset of Kentucky tonight in the Wild cats' invitation tournament.

title: Ens. James Brandi Weds Linda Beard
description: St. James's Episcopal Church was the setting yes terday afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Linda Osborn Beard and Ens. James Howell Brandi, U.S.N.R. The cere mony, performed by the Rev. Dr. John D. Verdery, head master of the Wooster School in Danbury, Conn., was fol lowed by a reception at the Union Club.

title: Bay State Licenses Fishing
description: BOSTON, Dec. 19 (AP)All commercial fishermen in Mas sachusetts will need licenses after Jan. 1, the commissioner of natural resources has ruled, under legislation approved this year. The permits range in price from $100 for yearround lob ster fishing and 100foot fishing boats to $5 for rodandreel fishing.

title: Cat Naps on a Sofa, Clear Across Country
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass. Dec. 19 (AP)When Mrs. Dolly Hayden packed up in West Covina, Calif., two weeks ago to move East, she couldnt find her pet kitten, Harvey.

title: 4 U.S. AIRCRAFT LOST IN INDOCHINA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Dec. 20 (AP)  The United States command an nounced today the loss of four aircraft, including an Air Force F4 Phantom fighterbomber shot down over the Plaine des Jarres in Laos. Four Americans were reported killed and 19 wounded.

title: Judge Fines Judge
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 19 (UPI)  A Municipal Court judge addressed the defendant as sir and proceeded to hand down a fine of $2.75 plus costs for failure to display a current auto safety sticker on his car. The defendant in Judge Francis E. Thomanson's court this week was Judge Roger O. Debruler of the Indiana Supreme Court.

title: Prague Court Sentences 3 In Theft of Rare Stamps
description: VIENNA, Dec. 19 (AP)  A Prague court has sentenced three brothers to prison terms in the theft of a sheet of 80 rare Blue Mercury stamps is sued by the former Austro Hungarian empire and valued at more than $200,000.

title: Harlem Orchestra, In Debut, Seeking To Develop Talent
description: The toofrequently expressed myth that symphony concerts are white man's music was exploded anew Friday night at the McMillin Theatre of Colum bia University. The occasion was the debut of the Harlem Philharmonic Society, a train ing orchestra made up pri marily of members of the black, Oriental and Spanishspeaking communities in New York, and devoted to finding, developing and displaying worthy minor itygroup talents.

title: Mets Falter, Yanks Surge
description: The Mets did not march to the moon in 1970. They marched into third place in the National League's East while the Baltimore Orioles and Cincinnati Reds dominated baseball on the field. But as the seventies began, the game was

title: Mary E. Hetzler Will Be Bride Of R.F.Pierce3d
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., Dec. 19 The engagement of Miss Mary Evelyn Hetzler to Regi nald Franklin Pierce 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Jr. of Greenwich, has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Theo dore Hetzler Jr. A wedding in June is planned.

description: Whitney M. Young Jr., ex ecutive director of the National Urban League, became a life member last week of the Na tional Association for the Ad vancement of Colored People.

title: Clown at Home, Winner in Ring
description: He's a clown at home but all business in the ring, said Mrs. Patricia V. Craige of Monterey, Calif., describing her Nor wegian elkhound, Ch. VinMelca's Vaga bond, the topwinning dog in America, according to the Kennel Review system.

title: Treasury:
description: New game plan, new team. Last week President Nixon, un happy over the political costs of his economic policy, eased David M. Kennedy out of his post as Secretary of the Treas ury. This was no surprisebut the shocker was the President's choice of a Texas Democrat, for mer Gov. John B. Connally Jr., as Mr. Kennedy's successor.

title: HUDSON HIGHWAY NOT HISTORY YET
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 19  The Hudson River Expressway, the controversial project that many Westchester County resi dents believe was effectively killed by the United States Su preme Court last week, has not yet been abandoned by Gover nor Rockefeller.

title: Music
description: IT'S the season, and what better time to talk about Santa Claus? The great work by William Henry Fry, that is: Santa ClausA Christmas Symphony. It had its world premiere in New York on Christmas Eve of 1853, performed by the Jullien Orchestra (then tour ing the country), and it is safe to say that it was unique. No American composer had ever composed such a work. None other ever has. Who would tangle with the strains of the Santa Claus Symphony? What im mortal hand or eye could match its fearful symmetry?

title: 1970 YEAR OF DECISIONS
description: In the slowest winning time ever re corded for a mileandonequarter horse racetwo years, seven months, seven daysDancer's Image was declared by a Federal Court the money winner of the 1968 Kentucky Derby. The action, which will be appealed, was coolly ac cepted in evidence by fans that 1970 was, indeed, the year in court.

title: BRAZIL STILL AWAITS A LIST ON PRISONERS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 19 The Brazilian Government to day told the kidnappers of the Swiss Ambassador Giovanni En rico Bucher that it still insisted that it would exchange prison ers for him only if a list of their names was signed and dated by the envoy himself and sent to the Justice Ministry.

title: Autos:
description: In his bestseller, The Green ing of America, Charles Reich described traditional highway safety efforts as typical of What he calls Consciousness I mental ity  appropriate to the 19th century of small towns, faceto face relationships and individ ual economic enterprise.

title: Gardens
description: A LTHOUGH the custom of the decorated Christmas tree can be traced to Stras bourg, Germany, in 1605, the tradition did not reach this country until two hundred years later. The German im migrants who settled in Easton Pa., brought their be loved symbol of Christmas with them and by the end of the 19th century, the Christ mas tree had become a na tional feature of family holi day celebrations.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO KEEP CUBANS ISOLATED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The United States has opened a quiet but forceful diplomatic campaign in Latin America to block moves by Chile to lift the Organization of American States's ban on diplomatic re lations with Cuba.

title: Susan Persons Bride in South
description: DURHAM, N. C., Dec. 19 Miss Susan Lapsley Persons, a graduate of Duke Univer sity, where she is assistant director of undergraduate admissions, was married this afternoon to Paul Anthony Robell, foundation relations officer in the Duke Univer sity Office of Development.

title: Poll Finds Shift to Left Among College Freshmen
description: A survey by the American Council on Education on the current thinking of entering college freshmen shows that more than 36 per cent con sider themselves left or lib eral, while the conservatives are losing ground.

title: GUN ISSUE AIRED AT SOVIET TRIAL
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 19 (AP)In formed sources said today that a ballistics expert had testified that the gun used in an air plane hijacking attempt in Len ingrad last June was not in firing condition, and as a result the prosecutor had agreed to drop the question of firearms in the trial of 11 defendants.

title: Long Hair May Be Allowed For Delaware Guardsmen
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 19  Delaware National Guards men may be allowed to wear their hair long if they want, effective Jan. 1 under a six month experimental program started by the state's adjutant general.

title: Vietnam:
description: SAIGONThe rules set by Washington for the conduct of the air war in Indochina have long had a way of shifting be hind a screen of verbal ambi guity, and they seem to have shifted once again.

title: Mrs. Eda Anderson Wed
description: SUMMIT, N. J., Dec. 19 Mrs. Eda Brunn Anderson, widow of Howard W. Ander son, was married this after noon to Dr. Vincent D. Fran cis, a consulting internist at the Fort Hamilton Armed Forces Examining Entrance Station in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. Robert E. Stephens per formed the ceremony in the Central. Presbyterian Church of Summit.

title: SENATE DEFEATS MOTION TO CLOSE DEBATE OVER SST
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19The Senate voted 48 to 43 today against forcing an end to the debate on the supersonic trans port.

title: Linda Dwight Taylor Married To Prof. Virgil Everett Barnes
description: The marriage of Miss Linda Dwight Taylor to Virgil Everett Barnes, associate pro fessor of physics at Purdue University, took place in the Episcopal Church of the Res urrection here yesterday af ternoon. The ceremony, per formed by the Rev. Alan B. MacKillop, was followed by a reception at the Cosmopoli tan Club.

title: ROMANSKY SETS RECORD IN WALE
description: Dave Romansky of Penns ville, N. J., walked the fastest flatfloor indoor mile on record Friday night in a development meet sponsored by the Metro politan Amateur Athletic Union at the 168th Street Armory. More than 1,000 athletes from seven states competed in the 4hour meet.

title: Detective Kills Drug Addict Who Escaped From Hospital
description: A 20yearold narcotics ad dict who had escaped from a hospital was shot and killed yesterday afternoon by a de tective whom he had allegedly tried to stab with a stiletto in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn.

title: Indian Authority in Schools Is Urged
description: A federally funded study of 39 public, private and Govern ment school systems in 14 states has recommended that more authority and responsi bility for the education of Indian children be placed in the hands of the Indians

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONThe high reputation of Arthur F. Burns as an economist stems in good part from his work as an economic historian. Thus when Arthur Burns says that he has found something new at work, it is worth paying attention.

title: CHARTER CHANGE IS DUE IN BELGIUM
description: BRUSSELS, Dec. 19Belgium is about to amend her 140 yearold Constitution in an at tempt to end three generations of conflict between her two lan guage communities, the Dutch speaking Flemings and the Frenchspeaking Walloons.

title: Miles Shanahan Jr. Weds Valerie Rott
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 19Miss Valerie A. Rott, daughter of Mrs. Rose M. Rott of Brooklyn, was mar ried here this morning to Miles P. Shanahan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shanahan of Scarsdale.

title: Opera: Neglected Koan a of Frederick Delius
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Any nomination for the most unplayed opera of the last hundred years would have to include Koanga by the British composer Frederick Delius. It was composed in 1897, had a few perform ances, and promptly sub merged. Even the efforts of Sir Thomas Beecham could not keep it alive.

title: Vote for Women Favored
description: VADUZ. Liechtenstein, Dec. 19 (Reuters)Parliament ap proved a constitutional change yesterday allowing women among the principality's 19,000 inhabitants to vote. The deci sion will come into effect if en dorsed by male voters in a popular referendum to be held early next year.

title: CITY U. TIGHTENS RULES ON TENURE
description: An order by the chancellor of the City University aimed at limiting the number of teach ers on tenure has stirred up a controversy.

title: Susan Hadden Wedto D.T.Lawrence
description: WESTBURY, L. I. Dec. 19  Miss Susan L. Hadden and David T. Lawrence were married here this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Advent by the Rev. Her bert Beardsley, the rector. A reception was held at the home of the bridec' parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hamilton Had den in Jericho. Mr. Lawrence is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Lawrence of Hamil ton. Mass.

title: What's New at the Movies
description: HUSBANDS is discussed by Vincent Canby on Page 3.

title: A NEW PREMIER NAMED IN SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Dec. 19 President Chung Hee Park accepted today the resignation of Premier Chung II Kwon and appointed Paik Too Chin, a former Premier, to succeed him.

title: Filipino Folk Mass Here To Aid Typhoon Victims
description: A traditional Filipino mid night folk mass will be cele brated on Christmas Eve at the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Innocents, 128 West 37th Street

title: Army Calls Civilian Spying Minor
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 Army officials here attempted today to refute critics in Con gress who have charged that military intelligence operations aimed at civilians in the United States have become a threat to political liberty.

title: Connecticut Picks Casciola
description: STORRS, Conn., Dec. 19 Robert F. Casciola was named today to replace John L. Toner as football coach of the Univer sity of Connecticut. Toner will remain as the UConn athletic director.

title: ILLEGAL IMMIGRATION DECLINES IN CEYLON
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 19 A sharp drop in the number of persons illegally entering Cey lon from southern India has been reported since the pres ent Government of Mrs. Siri mavo Bandaranaike was elected last May.

title: Lavillon Morrison Is Wed in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 In the Presbyterian Church of the Pilgrims here today, Miss Lavillon Elise Morrison was married to John Walter Gussenhoven by the Rev. Dr. John Randolph Taylor.

title: Art in London
description: ONLY three years ago, London's National Por trait Gallery (just off Trafalgar Square, a few steps from the more fa mous National Gallery) was decidedly not the kind of place one often visited for amusement. Milton of Bernardsville and Tucson, Ariz., was married here this afternoon to kineon Goodhue Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Walker Jr. of Quogue, L. I., and Key Col ony Beach, Fla. title: Miss Blickwede to Wed
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Dec. 19  Dr. and Mrs. Donald J. Blickwede have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Blick wede, to Seaman Kimball James Knowlton of the Navy, son of Dr. and Mrs. James Q. Knowlton of Bloomington, Ind. An April wedding is planned.

title: Anne Leland Wed to Ian Benham
description: Miss Anne Bronson Leland was married yesterday to Ian David Benham. The Rev. David Cockcroft performed the ceremony in the River dale Presbyterian Church in the Bronx.

title: Susan Barker Will Be Bride Of R.T. DePree

title: Honduras to Restrict Her Role In Central America Trade Bloc
description: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Dec. 19Honduras, faced with a critical drain in foreign ex change, has decided to curtail her participation in the Central American Common Market.

title: Mr. Connally Comes to Town
description: WASHINGTONWhile John B. Con nally Jr. of Texas was considering President Nixon's offer to make him Secretary of the Treasury, he did notas popularly supposedconsult former President Lyndon B. Johnson. Knowledgeable associates Teport that Mr. Connally only informed Mr. John son after he had decided to accept.

title: Berenice Abbott, in the Nick of Time
description: THE COSTS of producing largescale exhibitions of painting, sculpture or any of the environment al forms of art now in fashion are becoming increasingly prohibitiveeven for sup posedly wellendowed insti tutions. In the past year or two, angels have had to be found for some grandiose, but worthwhile, museum ex hibitionsangels in the form of big  business corpora tions like Olivetti and Al coa which have begun spon soring museum exhibitions in a large way. One be gins to suspect that the museum field is becoming a hit like Broadway; it can only afford to take chances on big names and lavish productions  the kind of shows that draw large crowds and heavy financial backing.

title: A Bold Incursion From Canada
description: Canada made its presence felt in United States harness racing in 1970, chiefly through the efforts of two com petitorsa 30yearold driver and a 7yearold mare.

title: Albert Ayler 1934  70
description: IN one of his final inter views, John Coltrane re marked to critic Frank Kofsky that Albert Ayler was one of the most promising new stars in contemporary jazz. Certainly that state ment is as true in retrospect as Ayler's music was truth: the soulful embodiment of a boldly futuristic dream, root ed in a passionate, unyielding sense of morality and justice.

title: Natives in New Guinea Disturbed by Mannequin
description: PORT MORESBY, New Guinea, Dec. 19 (UPI)The appearance of the first man nequin in a store window in New Guinea's primitive east ern highlands has created havoc among natives.

title: New Peaks Far Afield
description: Like the midterm national political elections, 1970 in track and field be came a significant statistical yardstick for the public to assess goldmedal pos sibilities in theb ig races two years hence at Munich in the next Olympics.

title: Aid to Business:
description: Long before the concept of the welfare state emerged un der Franklin D. Roosevelt, con servative industrialists coined the term welfare capitalism to sum up corporate benevo lence in protecting both work ers and society. Last week the country got repeated reminders that a new form of welfare capitalism is emergingone in which giant corporations go on public welfare to stave off li quidation.

title: N.F.L. Season to End With 182d Game
description: The 182d and final game of the National Football League's season will be played at Oakland, Calif., today be tween the Raiders and the San Francisco 49ers. It will be seen on television here on Channel 2, starting at 4 P.M., and just about every place else in the United States,

title: AUDIENCE JOINS CHORAL SOCIETY
description: At the New York Choral Society's concert at Philhar monic Hall on Friday night, the audience sang 10 measures of music by Vivaldi five times. The program included that composer's Beatus Vir (Psalm 112), and it has a brief and simple but stately passage that occurred five times in the course of the work.

title: MISS MIR IS FIRST IN DOWNHILL RACE
description: VAL D'ISERE, France, Dec. 19It was the same old story: The French won another Alpine ski race.

title: Miss Carol Baker Is Married Here
description: Miss Carol Ann Baker and Charles J. Seidler Jr. of New York, son of Mrs. Walter W. Plankinton of Tequesta, Fla., and the late Mr. Seidler of Bellerose, Queens, and Can dlewood Isle, Conn., were married here yesterday.

title: The Times Is Granted Extension Of Order Restraining Its Drivers
description: Federal Judge Lloyd F. Mc Mahon yesterday extended until 2:15 P.M. Tuesday a tem porary restraining order en joining members of the drivers union and their officers from refusing to perform their nor mal delivery duties at The New York Times.

title: CONVICTIONS VOIDED IN CAROLINA PROTEST
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 19 The South Carolina Supreme Court has reversed the convic tions of two University of South Carolina students for trespassing and disorderly con duct during an antiwar demon stration on a visit to Columbia last year by President Nixon.

title: A.E.C. Detects Radiation 450 Miles From Nevada Test Site
description: MERCURY, Nev., Dec. 19 (AP)Lowlevel radiation re leased from an underground nuclear test at the Nevada test site was detected today by monitoring planes 450 miles away over central Utah, the Atomic Energy Commission said.

title: South Korea Beats Israel, 8167, in Asian Games Final
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 19 (AP)South Korea upset Israel, 8167, the defending champion, for the basketball title and Japan increased its goldmedal lead with five more triumphs today at the sixth Asian Ganes.

title: True Light Sect in Carolinas Bracing for End of the World
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 19 Having put enough money aside to see his family through, H. Flake Braswell closed his upholstery shop near Monroe, N. C., a year ago because of his belief that the world would end in 1970.

title: FilipinoSoviet Ties Possible
description: MANILA, Dec. 19 (Reuters) The Philippines may estab lish diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union next year, sources at the presidential palace have disclosed.

title: PUTNAM APPOINTED LAFAYETTE'S COACH
description: EASTON, Pa., Dec. 19Neil E. Putnam, an assistant at Yale for six seasons, was named to day head football coach at La fayette College. He succeeded Harry Gamble, who resigned earlier this month to become coach at Pennsylvania.

title: Engineer Weds Susan S. Perry
description: NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 19 Miss Susan Savier Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Merton Perry of Da rien, was married here today to Allan Robert Pike, son of James George Pike of Linden hurst, L.I., and the late Mrs. Pike.

title: Nationalism Is Muted Among Basques in Idaho
description: BOISE, Idaho, Dec. 19The annual Sheepherders Ball ended at 2 A.M. today and was smash hitbut then, it is every year for the 12,000 Basques who live around Boise.

title: Park Funds Bill Signed
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) President Nixon has signed a bill authorizing appropriation of an additional $2.1million for development of Wilson's Creek Battlefield National Park in Springfield, Mo., site of an early Civil War battle.

title: The Unholy Nonalliance
description: LONDONSoviet policy is using the Chinese threat of aggression as a diplomatic trump not in order to buy a rapprochement with the West at the cost of concessions, but to convince the West that they [the Russians] de serve concessions by virtue of their special position.

title: Arabs See Population Gain
description: CAIRO, Dec. 19 (UPI)The population of the Arab world will increase by more than half in the next 15 years to 168 million, according to the Cairo Demographic Center. The cen ter has told the Arab Cultural Conference here that the fig ure did not include Yemen, South Yemen or Palestine, for which no figures were available.

title: Kashmir Hemp Crop Burned To Curb Hashish Smuggling
description: SPRINAGAR, Kashmir, Dec. 19  The entire hemp crop grown this year on a wide area in Kashmir valley was de stroyed as part of government campaign against an increase in the smuggling of hashish. About 30 Government officials Were penalized for failing to prevent the cultivation of hemp.

title: Season's Blazing Finish
description: A more dramatic, and confusing, script could hardly have been devised for the windup of the world champion ship offshore speedboat season. With only the Key West, Fla., race to go, two drivers  Vincenzo Balestrieri of Italy and Tommy Sop with of England  were virtually tied for the crown.

title: Apollo 14 Test a Success
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Dec. 19 (AP)The Apollo 14 astro nauts and their launching team successfully executed today a flight readiness test for next month's liftoff toward the moon. The countdown went smoothly and the makebelieve launching of the Saturn 5 took place on schedule.

title: Curci Leaves Post at Tampa To Coach Football at Miami
description: MIAMI, Dec. 19 (AP)Fran Curci, a former University of Miami quarterback, accepted the job today as the school's head football coach.

title: Coins
description: ANIMALS and toys that warm the hearts of children at Christmas also bring great pleas, ure to numismatistsyoung and old. Coins, medals and paper currency from coun tries throughout the world carry a great variety of de signs drawn from animals and other figures associated with the Yule season.

title: Democratic Unit Finds G.O.P. Hurt by Nixon Tour
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 President Nixon's extensive 1970 campaign tours may have hurt rather than helped Repub lican House candidates, a Demo cratic election analysis in dicates.

title: ExGovernor Reported Sued
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 19 (UPI)Television station WJIT here has reported that the United States public relations agency of Norman Craig and Kummel has filed a $67,100 suit against former Gov. Roberto Sanchez Vilella and his People's party for unpaid bills owed for publicity expenses in curred during the 1968 election campaign.

title: CITY AIDE REPORTS ON FETUS SURVIVAL
description: The director of Maternity and Newborn Services for the city's Department of Health said yesterday that 26 fetuses had remained alive after legal abortions in the city since July.

title: James J. Power And Peak Mason Married Here
description: The marriage of Miss Martha Peak Mason to James J. Power took place in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday afternoon. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. John McLaughlin, was followed by a reception at the Cosmopoli tan Club.

title: Carole Ryan Wed Upstate
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 19  Miss Carole Ann Ryan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edward Ryan Jr., was married here today to Richard Michael Working, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Richard Working of Baltimore.

title: Miss. Anne Stilwell Vaughan Is Married
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 19 In the Princeton University Chapel this afternoon, Miss Anne Stilwell Vaughan and Rufus Eugene Hallmark. Jr., doctoral candidate in music history at the university, were married by the Rev. John H. Snow, the Episcopal chaplain.

title: Ira Matathia Weds Miss Julie Lawrence
description: Miss Julie Lawrence, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Lawrence of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was married last night to Ira Matathia, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Matathia of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz per formed the ceremony, at the Hillcrest Jewish Center in Flushing, Queens.

title: HaryouAct Expected to Lose Control of Head Start Program
description: HaryouAct, the controversial antipoverty agency in central Harlem, is apparently going to lose control of its Head Start program for preschool children because of complaints of fiscal mismanagement.

title: Victoria Pohle, John R. Price Jr., Nixon Aide, Wed
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., Dec. 19 John R. Price Jr., a special assistant to the President, and Miss Victoria Scott Pohle, a former Presidential aide he met at the White House last year, were married here this afternoon.

title: Tanzania Expected to Pass GrowthRate Target in 71
description: DAR ES SALAAN, Tanzania, Dec. 19 (Agence France Presse)  Tanzania's economy is ex pected to expand faster than the target growth rate of 6.7 per cent next year.

title: Karen Chazen Engaged to Martin Romm
description: NORTH BELLMORE, L. I., Dec. 19Mr. and Mrs. Na than Chazen have made known here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Sue Chazen, to Martin Romm, son of Mrs. Joseph Romm of Belle Harbor, Queens, and the late Mr. Romm.

title: Crews and Miss Middleton Capture Downhill Races
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Dec. 19 (AP)Paul Crews of Anchor age, Alaska, won the downhill ski competition today in Sun Valley's Holiday Classic meet that attracted more than 100 competitors.

title: Compromise on Division of Meter Fares Called Key in Cab Dispute
description: Taxi union negotiators and fleet owners reached tentative agreement yesterday on a new contract that could end the twoweekold cab strike today.

title: SEAMAN IN HIJACKING IS RETURNED TO U.S.
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 19 (AP) Alvin L. Glatkowski, one of two merchant seamen accused of hijacking the American arms ship Columbia Eagle to Cambo dia last March 14, was returned to the United States today.

title: 3 in Area Lead Regents' List; 2 Suburban Girls Tie for First
description: ALBANY, Dec. 19  Three students from the New York City area have achieved the highest scores in the State Regents Scholarship Examina tions.

title: Law
description: FORT BENNING, Ga.  First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. was wearing a broad smile at the end of last week, and well he might. For as his courtmartial, in which he has been charged with the premeditated murder of not less than 102 Vietnamese civilians, went into a Christmas recess last Thursday, it began to appear that it was not Rusty Calley who was on trial but his company commander, Capt. Er nest L. Medina.

title: Recordings
description: THERE is a refreshing new version of Bizet's Carmen on records. It comes from Angel (three disks, SCL 3767), and it reproduces the original spoken dialogue. It also in cludes two passages not gen erally known about or used. They are not of major im portance, but they give an extra piquancy to the per formance.

title: FORDHAM ROUTS SYRACUSE, 9875
description: Deadly outside shooting and a pressing defense enabled Fordham's basketball team to snap Syracuse's fivegame win ning streak with a 9875 victory before 4,021 home fans last night. The Rams extended their unbeaten string to six games.

title: On Christmas Day No More Current Events
description: ISTARTED teaching poetry writing at P.S. 61, which is in Manhattan on East 12th Street between Ave nues B and C, in 1968. I hoped to find a way of teaching the subject that would make children as happy to write poems as they are to draw and paint, and after a few months it seemed to me that I had found it.

title: Little Man's Big Score
description: A small man stole the thunder of the horses hooves this year. Bill Shoe maker, standing 4 feet 11 inches and weighing just over 100 pounds, rode 1,100 pounds of thoroughbred to vic tory after victory and, on Sept. 7, broke

title: Guinea Says Her Borders Are Threatened by Troops
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Dec. 19 (Agence FrancePresse)  Guinea said today that troops were massing on her borders with Portuguese Guinea and Senegal to attack nine Guinean towns.

title: Council Seeking to Curb Mayor On Capital Project Eliminations
description: A move to take away the Mayor's power to drop prom ised capital projects without public notice will be started to morrow in the City Council.

title: Moslems and Vatican Plan To Work for Understanding
description: ROME, Dec. 20 (UPI)Mos lems and Roman Catholics have agreed to establish regular con sultations at a high level to promote better understanding and to work toward peace, it was announced here today.

title: G.I.'s Delayed on Trip Home
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Dec. 21 (AP)The United States Air Force sent four military transports to Viet nam today to take 350 Ameri can soldiers home for Christmas after the South Vietnamese Government rerused to clear a commercial Boeing 747 jet for landing at Tonsonnhut Air Base. The 350 G.I.'s were delayed 12 hours after the 747the first jumbo jet scheduled to land in Vietnamwas denied clearance to pick them up.

title: Many Doctors Ignore U.S. List Of Hazardous or Useless Drugs
description: A list of 369 drug products considered ineffective or haz ardous by the Food and Drug Administration apparently is being ignored by a large num ber of doctors and their patients across the country. Some doc tors go so far as to say they consider the Federal agency's action in issuing the list unethi cal.

title: Boston Officials Joining Mrs. Hicks in Opposition to School Integration Law
description: BOSTON, Dec. 20  An in creasing number of public offi cials here are gingerly invading territory once held exclusively by Mrs. Louise Day Hicks, and there is less talk now that opponents of school integration are bigots or racists.

title: Taming of Adirondacks Feared
description: BLUE MOUNTAIN LAKE, N. Y.  In a hollow of the forest here in the middle of Adirondack State Park, the snow falls with a halfhiss ing, halftrickling sound on the trunks and branches of the trees as a solitary visi tor trudges through the woods.

title: Excerpts From the Speech by Gierek
description: WARSAW, Dec. 20Fol lowing are excerpts from the speech made tonight by Ed ward Gierek, the new First Secretary of the Polish Com munist party, as transcribed from a television broadcast and translated by The New York Times:

title: Gomulka Won Power in Spring in October of 56
description: For 14 years, since he be came First Secretary of the Polish United Workers party, the most powerful man in Po land . . . elected October 21, 1956, during Poland's spring in October . . . two days earlier, faced down a Soviet delegation headed by Khrush chev in secret Warsaw talks . . . told the party's Central Committee, Every country has the right to be sovereign and independent . . . a life long Communist and fervent Polish patriot . . . jailed in 1951 on Stalin's orders; re leased in April, 1956 . . . the June, 1956, riots in Poznan threatened to undermine the Communist hold in Poland, and Gomulka was known to be .popular for his determina tion that Poland remain inde pendent though Communist . . . I will not allow Poland to become the 17th Soviet Republic, he said once . . . this attitude led to his dis missal in 1949 from the party secretaryship . . . was Deputy Premier in the provisional government that worked with Stalin to place Poland under Communist control . . . in jail for Communist activities when Poland was invaded in 1939 . . . fought in the de fense of Warsaw . . . organ ized the Polish party in 1942 . . . led a group of Polish partisans . . . active in the Communist underground throughout the war . . . born in February, 1905, near Kros no . . . joined a socialist youth organization at 17 . . . in 1926, joined the Com munist party . . . since 1956, has been forced to com promise his stubborn inde pendence with the realism of Soviet proximity and pow er . . . many of his 1956 re forms have been diluted out of existence . . . still believed to be personally popular . . . he and his wife live modestly . . . frail in appearance, shrewd, quiet and humorless, he survived until subsurface discontents broke into open violence once again last week.

title: 28 Dead, 27 Hurt in Tucson Hotel Fire
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 20 Fire raced through the upper stories of a 41yearold hotel today, killing 28 guests and permanent residents and in juring 27 other persons.

title: U. S. I. A. Chief Says Cambodia Drive Hurt U.S. Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20  Frank Shakespeare, the direc tor of the United States In formation Agency, said today that American prestige abroad had suffered as a result of the traumatic impact of the United States military incur sion into Cambodia last May and June.

title: No CostumesOnly Flowing Gowns
description: Mrs. Stanley Love smoothed the front of her bottle green jersey dress and said, I feel so comfortable.

title: 1 OF 15 SHOPLIFT, STUDY DISCLOSES
description: One out of 15 shoppers en tering four large department stores in New York, Boston and Philadelphia takes something without paying for it, accord ing to a recent study.

title: Medieval Service an Ecumenical One at St. Patrick's Cathedral
description: A Roman Catholic archbishop and an Episcopal bishop pre sided together in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday at a Christ mastime service that was devel oped by medieval nuns.

title: Protest in London
description: LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) About 1,200 Poles marched on the Polish Embassy today, car rying banners denouncing Com munism and the Soviet Union.

title: DualPurpose Funds
description: December 18, 1970

title: AIDE TERMS BONN ALARMED BY RIOTS
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, Dec. 20. (AP)Defense Minister Helmut Schmidt said today that the West German Govern ment regarded with alarm the disturbances in Poland, es pecially in the present phase of our Polish policies.

title: The Quality of Life
description: LONDON, Dec. 20The British Gov ernment has just started a new sta tistical publication with a distinctive aim. It is called Social Trends, and it is designed to throw more light than the usual figures of production, earn ings and the like on the changing nature of British society.

title: Oil Slicks Reach Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 20 (AP) Scattered oil slicks from a burning Gulf Coast drilling plat form were found today along 20 miles of Louisiana coastline. A spokesman for the Shell Oil Company?? which owns the burning oil platform, said a chemical agent had been sprayed along the coast in an effort to contain the slicks. The affected coast includes the fed eral Wisner Wildlife Manage ment Area, winter home of many species of birds. It was not known if there was any damage to wildlife.

title: Peterson Is Named Rice Football Coach
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 20 (AP) Bill Peterson, football coach at Florida State for 11 years, has become coach and ath letic director at Rice.

title: PennDixie Cement Corp. Sets Term Loan Accord
description: The PennDixie Cement Cor poration has signed a new term loan agreement of $27,075,000 with a group of commercial banks. The company also an nounced that it is arranging an additional $4million in new production payment loans to be utilized for its limestone units.

title: Armed Man Steals Clothing
description: LONG BEACH; Calif., Dec. 20 (UPI)A gunman who said that he was unemployed and that his children needed clothing, stole 10 coats for boys, 12 pairs of slacks; 12 overcoats for girls, twomaternity outfits, two cocktail dresses and a purse from a clothing store yesterday. The police said the thief told his tale of woe to two women clerks at the Kiddy Shop. He showed them an ammunition clip in his pistol to prove that the weapon was loaded. The merchandise was valued at $1,715.

title: Advertising: Looking for Modern Trends
description: We have this friend with a fetish. He reads ads and attempts to spot trends. Must be a farm of masochism since he's not even in the business.

title: Jerusalem Hit by 2 Rockets
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20 (AP) Two rockets were fired into residential areas of Jerusalem today  apparently by Arab guerrillas  and one exploded near a building soon to become the residence of President Zal man Shazar of Israel. The other missile damaged a building, the police said. No casualties were reported.

title: Poland's New Leader
description: In March, 1968, for the first time since Wladyslaw Gomulka came to power in Poland, his remarks to a group of party members were all but drowned out by the rhythmic chanting of another name, that of Edward Gierek.

title: Peking, Soviet Laud Front
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 20 (Reu ters)  Communist China and the Soviet Union expressed their support today for the Na tional Liberation Front of South Vietnam on the 10th anniver sary of its founding. The Peking radio broadcast a Peking rally supporting the Vietcong and Kremlin leaders in Moscow pledged continued support for the front.

title: Police Copter Stolen At Airport in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Monday, Dec. 21 (AP)Thieves slipped into a hanger early Sunday, filled, an Erie County Sheriff's Depart ment helicopter with fuel, rolled it, outside and flew away, dep uties reported.

title: Doctors Laud Diagnostic Test for Lymph System
description: VAIL, Colo., Dec. 20By in jecting into the skin between a patient's toes a dye that streaks his body blue, more doctors are now Xraying hid den areas of the body's com plex and mysterious lymph sys tem to improve diagnosis and then treat certain cancers and other diseases.

title: 49ers and Bengals Win First Division Titles
description: The Cincinnati Bengals and the San Francisco 49ers gained the first divisional championships in their histories yesterday, although those histories have covered contrast ing periods of time.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Seven years ago, a St. Louis Cardinal reserve linebacker earned $35 a night at Rotary meetings and high school sports banquets where he showed a highlight film with beer commercials and explained to his admirers: Football is just like life. Those of you who work the hardest and are the most dedicated will be the most successful. The competi tiveness of football is excellent preparation for the competi tion of life. He would end his speech by emphasizing that playing football developed the right values and attitudes.

title: Suburbs Accept Poor In Ohio Housing Plan
description: DAYTON, Ohio, Dec. 16 The white suburbs of Dayton, which range from very wealthy to bluecollar, have, agreed to provide housing for the poor, despite strong and outspoken opposition by many residents.

title: SecondHalf Spree By Bucks. Topples Braves, 131 to 101
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 20 (AP) The Miltvaukee Bucks outscored the Buffalo Braves, 254, in a sixminute span of the third quarter tonight en route to a 131101 National Basketball As sociation victory.

title: Boston to Add 50 Policemen
description: BOSTON, Dec. 20 (AP) Mayor Kevin H. White an nounced today that 50 police men would be added to the force later this month for as signment in all neighborhoods, especially where burglaries and street crimes are high: He said that those 50, plus 169 now in training at the Boston Police Academy would increase the street patrol by 219 men over the next four months.

title: Australia to Aid Cambodia
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Dec. 20 (Reuters) Australia will supply Cambodia with 100 long range radio sets worth $390,000 for use by the Cambodian Army, External Affairs Minister William McMahon announced today.

title: Dutch Report Engine for Cars That Emits No Noxious Gases
description: PARIS, Dec. 20  A Dutch company has taken a Scottish clergyman's invention of the early 19th century and come up with an engine that powers vehicles, the company says, without emitting noxious ex haust gases.

title: Burial Dispute Resolved
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (AP)  A Federal judge has ruled that a soldier killed in Vietnam will be buried in Ar lington National Cemetery after memorial services in Ontario.

title: 4 TOP U.A.R. AIDES FLY TO MOSCOW FOR WEEK'S TALKS
description: CAIRO, Dec. 20Vice Presi dent Aly Sabry and high. United Arab Republic officials flew to Moscow today for a week of toplevel talks with Soviet leaders.

title: Aquariums: Decorative, Restful and a Little Bit of Nature at Home
description: This may be the dawning of the age of aquariums.At any rate, a gurgling tank of tropi cal fish is fast becoming one of the newest decorating objects for the home.

title: Erik Bruhn Is Ill; Role to Ivan Nagy
description: Erik Bruhn will not dance at the American Ballet The ater opening tomorrow night at the City Center as sched uled, the company has an nounced.

title: BUCKS AND LAKERS IN TV TEST TONIGHT
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 20 (AP)  Flush with the success of its Monday night, pro football telecasts, the American Broad casting Company is looking to the National Basketball Associ ation to fill a sports void this winter.

title: Asian Games Completed With Japan Big Winner
description: BANGKOK, Dec. 20 (AP) The Sixth Asian Games ended today with most of the gold medals in Japanese hands, 49 new records on the books and Burma, the defending champion, and South Korea playing an overtime scoreless tie in soc cer. Both teams received gold medals.

title: BARRY SCORES 41 IN NETS DEFEAT
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 20Rick Barry set a club record for points in one half, but the New York Nets lost to the Texas Chaparrals, 118106, in the American Basketball As sociation tonight.

title: Daniels Wins 6Mile Walk
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 20 Ron Daniels of the New York Athletic Club won the sixmile walking race of the Philadel phia Athletic Club today by a wide margin in 49 minutes 37 seconds.

title: Late, Lamented Playing Fields
description: Superstadiums, most graphically represented in the Houston Astro dome, have been popularly accepted as a good thing. The dissent ex pressed here is based on a judgment that superstadiums are not mere playing fields for athletic events but rather facilities drastically modifying the nature and character of the sport ing events held there.

title: Blown Fuse Stops 49ers
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 20 (AP)A blown fuse in a micro wave relay station four miles east of here ended nationwide televising two minutes before the end of the San Francisco 49ers 387 rout of the Oak land Raiders today, a Pacific telephone Company spokesman said.

title: Misses Ripley and Aspegren Feted
description: Mr. and Mrs. S. Dillon Rip ley 2d of Washington and Mr. and Mrs. John B. Aspe gren of New York gave a reception and buffet supper dance at the Colony Club last night in honor of their daugh ters, Miss Julie Dillon Ripley and Miss Theodora Vantine Aspegren.

title: Books of The Times
description: So, here it comes at last, the book itself, Khrushchev Remembers. And what with the circumstances surrounding its arrival the haphazard way its pieces came to gether, the questions about its origins and

title: Vivian Barone, Ralph J. Dewey Marry on L.I.
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Dec. 20 The marriage of Miss Vivian Barone to Ralph James Dewey took place in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon. The Rev. R. Michael Reid performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Harry J. Sievers.

title: The Week's Votes In Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 Following are the votes of dele gations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major rollcalls in Congress during the week ended yester day:

title: HOTA TURNS BACK BLUE STAR. BY 30
description: New York Hota, undisput ably the best team in the area at this time, routed Blue Star, 30, in a GermanAmerican Soc cer League game yesterday, while Elizabeth of New Jersey tied Gotschee, 22. For un beaten Hota, the game was a tuneup for the New York final of the United States Challenge Cup next Sunday.

title: ILLNESS IS CITED
description: WARSAW, Dec. 20Wladys law Gomulka resigned today as leader of the Polish Communist party after a week of antiGov ernment riots over food price increases and general economic discontent.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Tass Says Lunokhod Roams
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 20Russia's moon rover, Lunkhod 1, roamed the Sea of Rains today, on its 10th reconnaissance mission of the lunar surface, sending back photos and data on the moon's soil. Tass?? the Soviet Union's press agency, said the remote controlled vehicle crawled over a plain that contained shallow potholes and, during a 3hour and 26minute session. transmitted pictures of the soil and sharply angular ston??s with a size of 20 to 30 centi meters, or 8 to 12 inches.

title: Entertainment Events
description: TONIGHT

title: SWISS CHALLENGES BANKING SECRECY
description: GENEVA, Dec. 20A young Socialist legislator, who is anathema to the Swiss estab lishment, has opened the first serious attack in Parliament on Switzerland's drastic banking secrecy laws.

title: Stage: Here Be Dragons
description: Don't ask me what is going on in the basement of St. Clement's Church on West 46th Street, underneath which the American Place Theater does its own particular dra matic thing! Or rather do ask mebecause if you don't ask me, I'll never get the column written.

title: What is John Gardner Up To?
description: In launching Common Cause, the new citizen's lobby he is sponsoring, John W. Gardner, the former Secre tary of Health, Education and Welfare and, chairman of the Urban Coalition, has read the country a lesson on its present disastrous course and on the urgent need for reform.

title: 3 Die in San Francisco Fire
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (UPI)  Three persons were burned to death and five others were injured early today in a fire that destroyed three build ings in Chinatown, at Grant Avenue and Washington Street.

title: 2 SOPRANOS BOW IN ORFEO AT MET
description: Ruza Baldani and Lilian Su kis assumed the title roles of Gluck's Orfeo ed Euridice for the first time at the Metropoli tan Opera in the performance given Saturday night

title: Reese Sets Back Nelson In Squash Racquets Final

title: ShakeUp Is Seen in U.S. As Move to Control Crisis

title: Treasury Announces Move To Thwart Securities Theft

title: Dublin: Rosc Seeks Poetry of Vision
description: DUBLIN  Rosc is an old Irish word of uncommon ver satility. In various loose translations it can mean an inflammatory speech, an in citement to deeds of valor, a spirited hymn in honor of Bacchus or the poetry or vision. It is as the poetry of vision that a boldly imagina tive group of Irish people has now given it a quite remarkable status in the world of art. The word first burst on the interna tional art scene three years ago When Rosc 67 was held. A panel of three experts selected 150 works, com pleted within the previous four years, by 50 artists of high repute. The jurors showed impressive thorough ness in exploring the con temporary field. Their choice included three creations by 35yearold Jim Dine and two by 89yearold Pablo Picasso. It embraced samples of car toon pop art by America's Roy Lichtenstein and of kinetic op art by Venezuela's JesusRaphael Soto.

title: PRAGUE CURBS POWER DUBCEK GAVE STATES

The 10,179ton Mitchurin struck the barge and then the 10,958 ton Hai Yeh, which suffered a 16foot dent on her port side.

Miss Muir, 18 years old, set a world mark when she was 12 in the women's 110yard backstroke. She also holds the 100meter backstroke record of 1 minute 5.6 seconds, set last year.

title: For Seasonal JobHunters, Tis Not the Season to Be Jolly
description: Isaac Purdue, 22 years old, a black student at City College of New York, looked for but could not find a Christmas job this year. I don't think it has anything to do with being a black man, he said. This time, the country is just too poor to be biased.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20The following is a list loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

description: HEIDELBERG, West Ger many, Dec. 17The tempo of military activity in Eastern Eu rope appears to be rising.

title: Israel Delays Decision
description: JERUSALEM, Dec. 20  The Israeli Government postponed today for at least another week any decision toward resuming peace talks with Egypt. The Premier, Mrs. Golda Meir, is clearly uneasy, according to qualified sources, at the Nixon Administration's reluctance to respond to Israel's request for political support.

title: Nap Rucker, 86, Ace Southpaw For Old Brooklyn Dodgers, Dies

Nonna lost only to Marty Wohl of Brooklyn College in eight final round bouts, Wohl finished third behind John Messing of the Lucia. Fencers Club.

description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Dec. 11 The leaders of Libya have be gun to show reserve toward the projected federation of their country with the United Arab Republic, the Sudan and Syria.

description: Tom Fleming of Paterson State (N.J.) College won the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union 30kilometer champion ship run yesterday at Van Cort landt Park, the Bronx. He was clocked in 1 hour 40 minutes 52 seconds.

title: Status of the Major Legislation Introduced in Congress
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The screen:2 Studies of Popular Music Groups Open
description: The last and, I suspect, the least among recent movie studies of popular music groups opened yesterday at the Evergreen Theater. A 50-minute film devoted to The Incredible String Band, written by The Incredible String Band (i.e. Mike Herron and Robin Williamson), and celebrating the imagination and life-style of the band and their two companions and colleagues, Rose and Licorice.The manner of film-making in "Be Glad . . ." is for the most part familiar enough, with bits of performance (poorly synchronized), snippets of interviews, extensive location shooting of the Incredibles at home among the fields and hedgerows of their native Britain, and even one rather elaborate musical montage, in the style of movie dance-band treatment in the 1930's. The film ends with a mimed playlet called "The Pirate and the Crystal BallA Fable," which is about what the title says it is about and which was written by the Incredibles, who also provide a background score of slightly exotic whimsey.My distaste for "Be Glad . . ." is a distaste for The Incredible String Band, and not for what the movie has made of themespecially since they seem pretty largely to have made the movie in their own image. That imagewith its dreadful incantatory poetry, its ready invocation of magical attitudes, its manufactured myth and mysticismsuggests a kind of Victorian pastoral dottiness, as if in aspiring to a Druidical world view they had fallen far short and come up, their garlands askew, with a fifth-rate imitation of Swinburne's "Hertha" instead.The Incredible String Band, all two of them (the young women seem mostly given to rhythm on stage and rustic handicrafts off), play a variety of instruments ranging from guitar and sitar, through violin and harpsichord, to recorder and lute. But I find their relation to these instruments approximately as convincing as their relation to natural magica promotion of meritorious display rather than a real commitment to the materials of an art.There is more art, more truth, more beauty, and infinitely better musicianship in "Blues Accordin' to Lightnin' Hopkins," a short film about the Texas blues singer Lightnin' (Sam) Hopkins, on the program with "Be Glad . . ." Built around what I gather was the return of Hopkins to his home town for a visit sometime in 1967, the film is, like "Be Glad . . .," as much a celebration of a mode of life as it is a study of a kind of music.It is also fairly conventional film making (the conventions of documentary poetic realism), but in Hopkins and his friends it has a quality of life rather than a fabricated group image for a subject.Almost everybody in "Blues Accordin' to Lightnin' Hopkins" seems to be a performer. But Hopkins himself controls the film's moods. Not so much in his exposition of the meaning of the blues as in what he makes of them when he sings and plays his guitar. In this he is very fine  with wit, virtuosity and the immersion in his medium that is a music maker's true exemplary magic.

title: Important Women Are in Many Fields
description: December is a great month for list making, a time of taking stock. One such com pilation, appearing in the January issue of Ladies Home Journal, out today, lists America's 75 most impor tant women.

title: Ens. Roy Coppedge 3d Marries Miss Susan Lyman Emerson

Roy Flemister Coppedge 3d, U.S.N.R. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald Bittsberger, and a re ception was held at the Coun try Club in Brookline, where the bride made her debut in 1967.

description: OTTAWA, Dec. 20 (AP) Arnold D. P. Heeney, former Ambassador to the United States and chairman since 1962 of the Canadian section of the International Joint Commission, died here today. He was 68 years old.

title: Is Discipline Bad for the Army?
description: Along with the Vice President, tra ditional military men lament the grow ing permissiveness of American society and the deterioration, of disci pline in today's army. They believe that since armies exist to win wars, the means to win them must be made available, and the most important of these means is discipline. Unfortunate ly, we have discovered of late that too much discipline is not only bad for the Army, but also disastrous for the na tion. If this, on its face, seems outra geous to say, let us turn for our proof to an outrageous eventthe My Lai massacre.

title: TAX LAW PERILS COLLEGE PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 College newspapers are having to choose between becoming financially independent of the schools they serve or submit ting to editorial guidelines.
