description: Wall Street traditionally swings from euphoria to despondency. A few years ago the securities industry was expanding I wildly. Today there are forced liquidations and mergers.

title: Kent U. Bars a Conference
description: KENT, Qhio, Dec. 20 (UP1) Kent State University officials have refused the National Stu dent Assotiation permission to hold a threeday annual leader ship conference on the Kent campus next month. The 1,000 delegates to the conference, students from the ration's unis versities and colleges, were to have met to discuss the Na tional Guard shootings on the Kent State campus last May, in which four students died, inter national students relations and other matters.

title: BERLIN'S JEWS MARK A 25TH ANNIVERSARY
description: BERLIN, Dec. 20West Ber lin's Jewish community today marked the 25th anniversary of its formal reestablishment aft er World War II and the Nazi persecutions in a ceremony at tended by Mayor Klaus Schtz and other officials.

title: Film: 'Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion':Suspense Melodrama Opens at Baronet
description: Elio Petri's complex, entertaining new Italian film, "Investigation of a Citizen Above Suspicion," which opened yesterday at the Baronet Theater, is a suspense melodrama with the moral concerns of angry satire. A psychotic policeman, the chief of the homicide squad who has been newly promoted to head the political intelligence unit, sets out to affirm, "in all of its purity," the concept of authority  that absolute power before which all men become servile children, if not idiots.One hot summer afternoon, the Inspector (Gian Maria Volonte) pays a call on his mistress (Florinda Bolkan), a beautiful, kinky masochist with whom he acts out fantasies based on famous crimes. "How will you kill me this time?" she asks. "I'll cut your throat," he says, and she shivers with pleasure. A few minutes later, as they are thrashing around between her Op-patterned sheets, he takes a razor blade and slices her jugular vein.Afterwards, he takes a shower, has a drink (carefully leaving his fingerprints on the glass and the bottle), places a torn thread from his tie under her finger nail, makes several bloody footprints in the hall, and then calls the police to report the crime.As the investigation of the murder proceeds, the police, at the Inspector's urging, first focus their interest on the dead woman's homosexual husband, then on an anarchist student with whom she's been having an affair. The Inspector, however, comes to realize that the conviction of an innocent man will not prove his own inviolability.Thus he arranges a kind of final test, whereby his subordinates and superiors must face the indisputable evidence of his guilt, which, if denied, will be the ultimate affirmation.Mr. Petri ("A Quiet Place in the Country," "The Tenth Victim") is a Communist who does not make light films lightly, a fact, I fear, that prevents him from being taken as seriously as he should by movie puristsa breed known for both lack of humor and complete intolerance for baldly stated dialectics.However, although Mr. Petri quite consciously makes movies about ideas, he has, in his "Investigation," made a movie in which the ideas, and the man who seethes with them, have the shock and impact of the most fundamental kind of melodrama.When it opened in Italy early this year (and later, when it was shown at Cannes), "Investigation" was hailed for the ways in which it exposed the corrupt, authoritarian practices of the police, who place themselves above their own laws. For me, however, it is not most interesting on this social level, or even on the psychological level, if the film means to demonstrate the manner in which power corrupts.The Inspector does make some reference to his long enjoyment of power, and the film, in flashbacks, does suggest that the girl prompted her own death, first by convincing the Inspector that he was above the law, and then by ridiculing his sexual performance. (As did Bernardo Bertolucci in "The Conformist," Mr. Petri equates repressive political philosophy with derailed sex.)The film, however, is not especially convincing as a case historyat least, I was not convinced that, had he gone into another line of work, the Inspector might not have become a psychotic supermarket manager.It is as a kind of political parable that "Investigation" is a stunning movie. From the start, one is fascinated by the methods (rather than origins) of the Inspector's madness, by the terrible logic of his paranoia (at one point he gives an extraordinary speech in which he equates murderers with agitators, rapists with anarchists), and by the brilliance with which he constructs his apotheosis. "Investigation," unlike "The Conformist," is not about the rank-and-file Fascist. It is about a duce, not necessarily Il Duce, but any duce.Dominating the film, which moves forward with the relentless momentum of a good, solid policier, is the performance of Mr. Volonte, who has been seen in this country before ("For a Few Dollars More," "Wind From the East") but never for particular mention.Mr. Volonte has the cruel upper lip and the heavily lidded eye of the young Olivier, and he has the manic energy of the early Cagney, even down to the almost choreographed way in which he walks. One minute he is noisy and arrogant, the next he is obsequious and sly. When he talks to a subordinate, he fondles the back of the other man's neck, although the thought of someone's doing that to him would probably make him literally ill. It's a fine performance, full of stylized detail, like the movie it helps to define.

title: Job Action When Police Pact Ends Remote, P.B.A. President Says
description: The possibility of a police job action here on New Year's day is remote, Edward J. Kiernan, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Asso ciation, said yesterday.

title: ITALY'S NEWSMEN WIN PAY INCREASE
description: ROME, Dec. 20Italian news men won sizable salary raises, a fiveday work week and a measure of participation in management affairs today.

title: CLEANAIR DEVICE EMITS POLLUTANT
description: Let's Clean the Air. Help Control Pollution in Your Home, an advertisement for a device offered here reads. Our answer to air pollu tion, says the ad for another similar device offered to puri fy the air.

title: GARRETT EXCELS IN HIS LAST GAME
description: SAN DIEGO, Dec. 20 (AP) Mike Garrett capped his best day of the season on the foot ball field by reaffirming he was quitting the game in favor of baseball.

title: TIEUP IN CONGRESS LAID TO CONFEREES
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 Many Congressmen believe that the impasse now faced by Congress is due in large part to the breakdown of one of the most important and least understood pieces of legislative machinery  the HouseSenate conference.

title: TV: Gertrude Stein Amidst Her Talented Friends
description: Gertrude Stein, who didn't mind being called a genius and who wasn't above apply ing that term to herself, would, I think, have been pleased at the sudden con vergence of happenings that exalt her name and, inciden tally, that of her family. A stunning show of the pur chases made by the Stein family of the vanguard artist et the turn of the century, al ready called by one critic the event of the season, has been installed at the Museum of Art. Her essay and com ments on Picasso have been published by Liveright in Gertrude Stein on Picasso, and last night National Edu cational Television memorial izing her life on Channel 13 in a film portrait that is a chronological runthrough of her life: When This You See, Remember Me.

title: Protectionism Loses a Round
description: As the Senate deadlock continues on the Social Securityhealthwelfaretrade bill concocted by Senator Long, it has become clear that the ill wind on Capitol Hill has blown at least some good: the highly protectionist Mills bill on foreign trade is not likely to be passed the current session.

title: PRICES DECLINE IN GRAIN FUTURES
description: A Government report, viewed by speculative investors as bullish, plus the usual prehol iday doldrums in the after noon, sent grains and soybeans futures prices down yesterday in quiet trading on the Chi cago Board of Trade.

title: 65,000 IN THE CITY ARE WITHOUT HEAT
description: The first widespread effects of the fuel oil strike became evident yesterday as supplies were exhausted in 13 city proj ects housing 50,000 people.

title: Mary Marston Becomes Bride Of A. S. Gagarin
description: St. James Episcopal Church was the setting here yester day afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Mary Collier Marston, daughter of Mrs. John Hathaway Dyett of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Green wich, Conn., and Hunter Syl vester Marston Jr. of New York, to Andrew Serge Gaga rin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Serge S. Gagarin of Fairfield, Conn., and Peru, Vt. The Rev. Almus M. Thorp performed the cere mony, which was followed by a reception at the Colony Club.

title: Westchester Board Approves $181Million Budget
description: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 21  Westchester County's $181mil lion budget for 1971 was unan imously approved today by the County Board of Legislators.

title: So. Carolina's McGuire Fears Repetition of Maryland Brawl
description: Frank McGuire, coach of the undefeated South Caro lina basketball team, said yesterday he did not want to play Maryland in the Ter rapins' Cole Fieldhouse Jan. 9 if things are like they are right now.

title: MISS DAVIS LOSES EXTRADITION PLEA
description: Angela Davis lost her fight to prevent extradition to Califor nia yesterday when Associate Justice John M. Harlan of the United States Supreme Court declined to approve her appli cation for a stay.

title: Kinney Parking Attendants Vote to Accept New Pact
description: A threatened strike today by parking attendants at 16 park ing lots run by Kinney System, Inc., was called off last night when the involved members of Local 917 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters voted to accept a contract agreement.

title: OSCAR K. DIAMOND, HEAD OF HOSPITAL
description: ORANGEBURG, N. Y., Dec. 21Dr. Oscar K. Diamond, di rector of Rockland Slate Hos pital, died yesterday, apparent ly of a heart attack, at his home on the hospitai grounds. He was 59 years old.

title: PROFIT FORECAST BY CBWLHAYDEN
description: CBWLHayden, Stone, Inc., a medhunsized brokerage con cern, expects to have after tax earnings of $500,000 in the fiscal halfyear ending Dec. 31, Roger S. Berlind, chief execu tive officer, disclosed yester day.

title: Program of Dance By Marian Sarach Conquers Adversity
description: Marian Sarach and Dance Company presented a program of her works Sunday afternoon at the Isidor Straus Theater on East Broadway. The house is nearly impossible to work in, possessing a tiny stage, inade quate lighting, faulty sound re production and no wing space among other infelicities, so that any work that survives unmar red is a triumph.

title: UNDERGROUND TESTS HALTED IN NEVADA
description: YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Dec. 21 (UPI)  Underground nuclear testing has been discontinued in the area where radioactivity leaked into the atmosphere last week, the Atomic Energy Com mission said today. The air mass of light radiation had disap peared over Wyoming and flights of reconnaissance air craft were halted.

title: The Great Soil Swindle
description: The old and evil practice of strip mining, according to a recent report in this newspaper, is spreading and booming. More than 35 per cent of the nation's annual production of coal now comes from this kind of mining in which huge electric shovels gouge out the top soil to get at readily accessible seams of coal.

title: The 18YearOld Vote
description: The Supreme Court of the United States handed down a landmark decision yesterday which sustains the power of the Congress to extend the right to vote in Federal elections to a whole new group of American citizens, those from 18 to 21 years old.

title: AN INQUIRY ON ARSON PRESSED IN TUCSON
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 21 Fire department officials said today that they were actively investigating the possibility of arson in Connection with the worst fire in this city's history.

title: Boy, 6 May Be First Victim of Rabies to Survive
description: A 6yearold Ohio boy is ex pected to become the first per son on record to have sur vived rabies, public health of ficials said yesterday. The boy, who was bitten by a rabid bat on Oct. 10 while asleep in his farm home, has been steadily improving at St. Rita's Hospital in Lima since Nov. 23. Dr. Michael Hattwick, rabies expert at the United States Public Health Service Center for Disease Control in Atlanta, attributed his remark able recovery to intensive, 24 houraday care and anticipa tion of potentially fatal com plications.

title: High Court Refuses to Review California CompanyTax Case
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)The Supreme Court al lowed California today to tax the outofstate earnings of companies that controlled con terns within, its borders.

title: Screen: Perfection and a Love Story
description: What can you say about a movie about a 25yearold girl who died?

title: U.S. TVSET MAKER SUING JAPANESE
description: NEWARK, Dec. 21 (AP)The National Union Electric Corpo ration of Greenwich, Conn., filed a $360million suit in the Fed eral District Court here today charging seven major Japanese televisionset manufacturers and their subsidiaries with vio lating United States antitrust laws and the Federal antidump ing act.

title: GIANT SLALOM WON BY MICHELE JACOT
description: LES CONTAMINES, France, Dec. 21 (Reuters)Michele Jacot of France, the World Cup holder, edged out two Ameri cans today and won the first women's giant slalom of the season at the Grand Prix ski meet.

title: ACE RUNNING BACK IS STILL NOT FIT
description: The Detroit Lions will be bolstered by the return of their most dangerous running back Mel Farr, for the National Con ference semifinal playoff game against the Cowboys in Dallas on Saturday.

title: Martinez and 2 Rivals Card 70's to Lead Coast Tourney
description: SANTEE, Calif., Dec. 21 (UPI) The defending champion, Richard Martinez of Laguna Beach, and two others shared the opening day lead in the Southern California open golf tourney with twounderpar 70's yesterday.

title: Franco Aide Calls Spain Victim Of Red Propaganda Over Trial
description: MADRID, Dec. 21 (Reuters) Generalissimo Francisco Franco's principal assistant, Adm. Luis Carrero Blanco, said tonight that Spain was the vic tim of a Communist campaign waged around the controversial trial of 15 Basque nationalists, and warned that the Govern ment would maintain public order at all costs.

title: Sutton Urges the Renaming Of Mrs. Spatt as a Planner
description: Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton and Dan Col lins, chairman of the New Democratic Coalition, called yesterday for the reappoint ment of Mrs. Beverly Moss Spatt to the City Planning Commission.

title: U.S. Feels Israel Delays
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 United States officials believe that Israel is delaying her re turn to ArabIsraeli negotiations to the last possible moment, but will probably agree to rejoin the talks by Jan. 5 to preserve the Middle East ceasefire.

title: The Oracle Disposes of Santa Claus
description: WASHINGTON, Deed 21So many people have written with questions about Santa Claus this year that we have asked Norton Whizdom, holder of a doctorate in authority from the Pentagon and this nation's most dog matic newspaper columnist, to answer some of the mail. Dr. Whizdom has, fortunately for us all, agreed, but only on condition that everyone act immed iately on his advice. Let us proceed.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION FALLS 2.3% IN WEEK
description: Steel production last week fell 2.3 per cent, compared with output the week before, the American Iron. and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington. The trend of pro duction in the next several months will be sharply unward, but current output continues to show the effect at depressed steel orders in October and No vember, industry sources said.

title: That Holiday Quandary: Which Tree?
description: Contemplate your Christmas tree . . . I like a real crooked tree that smells like a tree, said one woman as she examined a stand of spruce, pine and Douglas fir trees on a windy, cold street corner in Green wich Village.

title: FRANK P. BARRETT, 77, STAMFORD LAWYER
description: STAMFORD, conn., Dec. 21 Frank P. Barrett, a wellknown local lawyer and civic leader, died today in Stamford Hospi tal after a brief illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 3015 High Ridge Road.

title: Congress Reported Adding $7Billion to U.S. Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 Congress is well on Its way to adding more than $7billion to the budget deficit in the cur rent fiscal year, a new tally showed today.

title: PAY FLOOR URGED TO AID DOMESTICS
description: A campaign to place domes tic workers under the $1.85 anhour state minimum wage law was announced yesterday by a group of legislators, la bor leaders and community rep resentatives.

title: ALLENDE ASKS LAW TO SEIZE COPPER
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 21 (AP)  President Salvador Al lende Gossens proposed tonight a constitutional amendment to nationalize the multimillion dollar American interests in the Chilean copper industry.

title: Nixon and Impasse in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  there are almost as many rea ions offered for the impasse on Capitol Hill as there are bills stalled in the legislative proc ess. Some blame the President, laying he is uncertain in his Lions with Congress and dilatory in his support of some of his own most important

title: United Nuclear Receives $50Million Fuel Contract
description: The United Nuclear Corpora tion of Elmsford, N. Y., said yes terday that it has received an order valued at about $50mil lion from the Duke Power Com pany of Charlotte, N. C.

title: City Plan for Minority Building Workers Assailed
description: An official of the National Association for the Advance ment of Colored People yester day criticized as the worst in the country a new city plan to train minority workers for jobs in the construction industry.

title: '74 Copper Output Seen Topping Use
description: George B. Munroe, president of the Phelps Dodge Corpora tion, the second largest pro ducer of domestic copper, fore cast yesterday that production of the metal In the nonCom munist world could exceed con sumption by 10 per cent by 1974.

title: Columbia Meeting: New Stars
description: One of the biggest recent film, hits of Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc., is the comedy Bob & Carol & Ted & Alice. Yesterday the big motion picture and television com pany put on another pro duction that might very well have been called Abe and Dave and Evelyn and Lewis.

title: Man Said to Be SuicideBent Injured in Stolen Ambulance
A 5T04 DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  The Supreme Court upheld to day the 18yearold vote in Federal elections but ruled that Congress acted unconstitution ally when it lowered the vot ing age to 18 for state and local elections.

title: Comprehensive Guide to Sociological Games Modern Adults Play Starts Here
description: Begin here leads any where these days, for a rash of current adult games seize on modern trials, issues and headlines, and send them spinning round boards as de vious as life itself Many of the exercises are fair game for intellectuals, and a few are programed to be down right unfair.

title: JordanianGuerrilla Clash Reported by Syrian Radio
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 21 (Reuters)  Fighting broke out near the northern Jordanian town of Irbid today between King Hussein's army and Palestinian guerrillas, the Da mascus radio said tonight.

title: The Hong Kong Ricksha Is Rolling Into Extinction
New University Names Head
description: PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 21 Dr. Louis J. P. Calisti, dean of the Tufts University School of Dental Medicine, Medford, Mass., was named today as the first president of the new Uni versity of Maine at Portland Gorham. Dr. Calisti, 45 years old, will assume the $32,500 position on July 1, the Univer sity of Maine's chancellor, Don ald R. McNeil, said. The posi tion was created by the merger earlier this year of the Univer sity of Maine in Portland and Gorham State College, with a combined enrollment of 5,780

title: Bonn Aide Calls Ties Good
description: BONN, Dec. 21The Govern ment spokesman, Conrad Ahlers, said today at his weekly news conference that official rela tions between the United States and West Germany were good.

title: JACK AND FIVE PLEAD NOT GUILTY IN FRAUD
description: Assemblyman Hulan E. Jack and five other defendants plead ed not guilty in Federal Court yesterday to a 27count indict ment that named them as par ticipants in a labormanagement fraud in Harlem.

title: CHARLES C. GOODMAN
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Dec. 21 (AP)Charles Clermont Goodman, a retired architect and designer for the Navy, died today in Saratoga Springs Hos pital. He was 84 years old.

title: Fanny May Is Planning to Sell $25Million From Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21In a dramatic illustration of the improved conditions in the mortgage market, the Fed eral National Mortgage Association announced today that itwould sell early next month $25million out of its huge stock of mortgages. The mortgages will be those with an interest rate of 8 per cent. Officials said that the mortgage industry has been clamoring for a chance to buy these mortgages, now that thrift institutions appear to have plenty of funds.

title: ROBERTS FINISHES SPOFFORD INQUIRY
description: The Bronx County District Attorney, Burton B. Roberts, said yesterday that there was no cause for a grand jury investigation into the death last month of a 14yearold resident of the Spofford Juvenile Center.

title: CHARLES R. LEO
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Dec. 21  Charles R. Leo, president of the Westchester Colprovia Cor poration of Katonah and an executive of other paving con cerns, died today at his home, Northgate, Alger Court, after short illness. He was 80 years old.

title: MRS. HUGH H. MACKAY
description: NAPLES, Fla., Dec. 21  Mrs. Helen Holme Warnock Mackie Mackay, wife of Hugh H. Mac kay, died yesterday after a brief, illness. She was 63 years old.

title: NEW POLISH CHIEF IS QUICKLY BACKED BY 3 IN EAST BLOC
description: WARSAW, Dec. 21The new Polish leadership headed by Edward Gierek began its first day in office today with appar ent support from both East and West.

title: NET SHOWS DROP AT PILLSBURY CO.
description: Operations of the Pillsbury Company in the three and six months ended Nov. 30 resulted in lower earnings, despite in creased sales.

title: HOW TO AID THE FUND
description: Checks should be made payable to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund and forwarded to P. O. Box 557, New York, N. Y. 10036, or to any of the following eight organi zations that certify these cases:

title: Swedish Reporter Says 300 Died in Week of Rioting at Gdansk
description: LONDON, Dec. 21Accord ing to Kurt Karlsson, a re porter for the Stockholm news paper Expressen, at least 300 persons were killed an last week's riots in Gdansk. The center of the city, he reported, was destroyed.

title: URBAN BODY PLANS PUBLIC BOND ISSUE
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation, cre ated in 1968 to counter decay and promote growth in cities and towns throughout the state, announced plans yesterday to sell $250million of bonds in January, its first public financ ing.

title: Drive to Race School Board Head Divides Westport
description: WESTPORT, Conn.A po litical hurricane that is dis rupting suburban compla cency and ruffling the pas sions of the affluent has blown into this quaint, ex pensive town on Long Island Sound.

title: Jewish Reading Room Opens on 84th Street
Two L. I. Men Are Sentenced In Mortgage Kickback Case
Per Capita Smoking Up First Time in 4 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  Adult smokers con sumed more cigarettes per capita in 1970 for the first time in four years, partly be cause of stepped up promo tions by manufacturers, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: EMPEROR CONCERTO FEATURES BROWNING
description: John Browning, who played Beethoven's Emperor Con certo with the Musica Aeterna Orchestra. Sunday night at Rogers Auditorium of the Met ropolitan Museum, was magni ficent, scintillating and well nigh letterperfect. The pianist's Beethoven was not warm, how

title: Everyday Objects Yield Magic and Relevancy
description: like the ones in the lobby, are often gigantic and fanciful, such as a huge Claus Olden burgsize sandwich, which falls off a table and pins Miss Martin to the floor.

title: U.S. Reports Close Watch On Soviet Craft Near Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (Reu ters)The White House is watching Soviet submarine ac tivity around Cuba very close ly but does not yet see any threat from Soviet naval activ ity, a spokesman said today.

title: PASSER DISCOUNTS HIS BACK AILMENT
description: Despite a sore back that benched him in the season finale, Johnny Unitas will open as the Colts quarterback against the Cincinnati Bengals in their American Conference semifinal playoff game Satur day at Baltimore. Unitas was replaced by Earl Morrall late in the first quarter of the Colts 3520 victory over the Jets on Saturday.

title: U.S.British Wrangle on 1944 Invasion Disclosed
description: LONDON, Dec. 21 (Reuters)  Disagreements between Brit ish and American military chiefs in 1944 about priorities in the final assault on Hitler's Europe were disclosed today when the records of the Combined Chiefs of Staff were made public.

title: Lawrence Berenson Dies at 79; Counsel for PreCastro Cuba
description: Lawrence Swenson, a New York lawyer and civi?? leader, died of a heart attack Sunday evening at his home, 1150 Fifth Avenue. He was 79 years old.

title: OFFICIALS VEXED
description: Voting officials in 47 states will have their Election Day problems compounded by the Supreme Court's ruling that 18 yearolds may vote in Federal elections even though they are not allowed to vote in state and local contests.

title: BOWDOIN AND YALE HANDED SETBACKS
description: A power packed Clarkson hockey team extended its string of victories in its undefeated season to nine games by rout ing Bowdoin, 61, at Madison Square Garden last night. The game was the first of a double header in the 10th annual East ern College Athletic Conference tournament which will con chide tonight. In the other game on the program Harvard beat Yale, 6 to 2.

title: ERNEST WALLING, 58, EARLY TV DIRECTOR
description: Ernest Walling, a television director since the early days of the industry in this country, died Saturday at his home, 83 Washington Place, after an ill ness of several months. He was 58 years old.

title: John A. Hughes of The News; Travel and Aviation Editor
description: RIVER VALE, N. J., Dec. 21 John A. Hughes, travel and avia tion editor of The New York Daily News, died today of a heart attack at his home, 593 Baylor Avenue. He was 56 years old.

title: FLORIDIANS DOWN COLONELS, 125119
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 21 (AP)  Ira Harge, playing his first game with the Floridians, scored 28 points and grabbed 14 rebounds to lead his team to a 125119 victory over the Ken tucky Colonels in an American Basketball Association battle tonight.

title: U.S. BANS 39 TOYS UNDER SAFETY ACT
Chief Quits United Air; Successor Is Selected
description: UAL, Inc., had a shakeup of its top management yester day. The holding company for United Air Lines announced the resignation of George E. Keck, 58 years old, as president and chief executive officer of both the holding company and the airline, and the election of Ed ward E. Carlson, 59, to succeed him at UAL. It was also noted that Mr. Carlson would take over Mr. Keck's former posi tions at the airline in a few days.

title: MEMOREX UP 7 IN DULL MARKET
description: Memorex, the computer equipment issue that plunged 25 points last week, ranked as the market's big swinger yesterday with a gain of 7 points to 62. But, elsewhere, the stock market generally failed to produce any fire works. It was another session that reflected, in the words of one analyst, yearend cross currents and consolidation.

title: Virginia Tech Names Aide
description: BLACKSBURG, Va., Dec. 21 (UPI)Wally English, assistant offensive football coach at the University of Arkansas, was ap pointed today to a similar post at Virginia Tech. English was signed by the Gobblers' new head coach, Charlie Coffey, who took over recently after also being with the Razorback staff.

title: SOVIET RULES OUT GAINS FOR ISRAEL
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21Pre mier Aleksei N. Kosygin warned Israel today against expecting any concessions in return for agreeing to a peaceful settle ment of the Middle East crisis.

title: Coast Guard Will Retire 2 Who Blocked Defection
Marketplace:
description: Is it possible that, after coming so far in this lame duck session of Congress, the investor protection legisla tion won't make it after all?

title: ARSONIST IS JAILED FOR UP TO 3 YEARS
description: A man found guilty last Fri day by a State Supreme Court jury of setting fire to a neigh bor's luxury apartment, after the latter complained of noisy parties. was sentenced yester day to an indeterminate prison term of up to three years.

title: ASARCO SETS CUT IN PRICE OF LEAD
description: The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday another cut, its fourth this year, in the price of lead.

title: TASTEFUL CONCERT BY EARLHAM GROUP
description: Indiana's Earlham College Chamber Singers and Musicians concluded a brief December tour of the East Coast late Saturday fternoon with a concert in Town Hall. The program was, in part at least, of a seasonal na ture, and the represented com posers included Schtz, Beetho ven, Brahms, Poulenc, Thom son, Krenek and Manfred Blum, the group's musical director.

title: Honor for Margaret Mead
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 21, (AP)Dr. Margaret Mead, the anthropologist, has been se lected to receive the Gimbel National Ward, presented an nually by Gimbels Department Store to a woman whose service has been of national significance.

title: Big Board Short Interest Rose As Amex Total Fell in Month
Albee's Latest Play Will Reach Broadway in Spring
description: Edward Albee has finished a play, All Over, which has been acquired for Broadway presentation in March or early April.

title: PHILIPPINES SEND GRACEFUL TROUPE
description: Bayanihan, the Philippine dance company, opened at Alice Tulley Hall last night. Bayani han, as the program indicates, is a term for mutual helpful ness. The company is, in fact, all together.

title: Big Board Answers Suit, Defends Its Fixed Rates
description: The New York Stock Ex change, responding to a lawsuit filed in October by the National Shareholders Association, as serted in court papers yesterday that its system of minimum fixed commission rates is im mune from challenge under the antitrust laws.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: EAST SETAUKET, L.I.  A few years ago when Victor Yannacone, a lawyer on the South Shore of Long Island, filed suit to halt the use of the pesticide DDT for mos quito control in Suffolk County, he paved the way for the Environmental De fense Fund.

title: McCarthy Praises Senate; 18 Colleagues Reciprocate
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota, de fended today the performance of the Senate in its current marathon session, and said he would continue to speak out on public issues after he leaves office on Jan. 3.

title: Men Wanted: 3 N. F. L. Clubs Seek Coaches
description: Eight of the National Foot ball League's teams are pre paring for playoff games this week while 18 others plan for 1971. The planning con cerns the draft on Jan. 27 and for several the coaching. There are three coaching po sitions to be filled and there could be seven more vacan cies. Wally Lemm

title: REP. RIVERS REVIVED AFTER HEART STOPS
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 21 (UPI)  The heart of Repre sentative L. Mendel Rivers fal tered lest night but a quick acting physician restored the heartbeat of the 65yearold chairman of the House Armed Services Committee.

title: POPE'S POLISH VISIT OFF FOR TIME BEING
description: ROME, Dec. 21  A wellin formed Vatican source said to day, The Pope's trip to Poland is off for the time being.

title: Elliott Gould Vehicle Also Makes Bow
description: There's an exhilarating feeling of high expectancy as "I Love My Wife" takes off in high glee at the Paris Theater to illustrate Elliott Gould's amiable confusion about love, sex and marriage. But after a couple of fast reels, highlighted by some imaginative quick cuts, newsreel footage and equally germane, colloquial wisecracks, a viewer not subject to the draft (and, perhaps, those who are) is left with as much confusion as the film's unfulfilled star. As an attempt to unravel with a light touch the ties that bind, "I Love My Wife" ends up pretty much the same gnarled knot it was at the start.Mel Stuart's direction and Robert Kaufman's hip, glib script is good for chuckles as Gould is kaleidoscopically flipped from virgin, inhibited, middle class youth to marriage (if not precisely wedded bliss) with Brenda Vaccaro and fatherhood as a struggling interne. But the bloom rapidly fades, of course, as Miss Vaccaro grows fat and apathetic to his passes. And a good deal of the ensuing footage is devoted to the hero's succession of extramarital affairs, as, we presume, he searches for true love while exhibiting surface angst and indecision."What happened to the wonderful guy I married?" Miss Vaccaro asks somewhat desperately after her now successful surgeon-husband has turned up bushed after another night in an alien boudoir. It's a good question since, in the generally superficial style of the script and direction, a number of serious questions and problems are posed but rarely solved satisfactorily.Certainly the director and writer touch a good many bases to indicate that their wandering boy is a lovable, contemporary type with contemporary hangups. He's convinced he loves his wife and two children, which is illustrated fleetingly, as in a touching Christmas scene. And he even sends his burgeoning spouse to an expensive slimming establishment and to a psychiatrist and he gets rid of his mother-in-law in efforts to set his house in order while he continues to daily and indulge in further vacillation.When his liaison with Angel Tompkins, as the demanding honey blonde TV actress and wife of a baseball player, becomes too hot for him to handle (even after he's feigned a separation from his hausfrau) the devious doctor is ready to return to hearth and home, but is coolly spurned by his mate, who now seems to be headed for a quieter life of her own. It's hardly surprising that after all the backing and filling this less than fine romance, running down somewhat aimlessly from a promising start, ends nowhere as the indecisive medico is seen in the process of making another quick conquest.As the haphazardly swinging surgeon, Elliott Gould is casually natural even though he appears to be only vaguely bothered by his largely self-imposed troubles. Despite his indicated good intentions and good humor, he emerges as a basically self-centered, shallow citizen. One's appreciation and sympathy mainly go to Miss Vaccaro, whose often zanily comic, sometimes poignantly realistic, characterization as his logically harried wife, is highly polished and looms larger than Gould's stellar services.Miss Tompkins is efficient and notably photogenic as the lady who won't take maybe for an answer. And, more importantly, she stresses one of the film's most pertinent observations, "You can't have it both ways." Unfortunately, "I Love My Wife" tries that trick and doesn't succeed.

title: Five in Family Die in Fire
description: SODUS, N. Y.,. Dec. 21 (UPI) Five persons died today when fire destroyed a frame house in Wayne County. Fire officials said the victims were asleep when the fire erupted. They were George W. Keuney 50 years old; his wife, Midred, 42, and three of their children, Rebecca, 19; Anne 12, and Donald. 9.

title: Brezhnev Praises Gierek, Sees End of Difficulties
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 21  Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, congratulated Ed ward Gierek today on his elec tion as Poland's Communist party chief and said that the Soviet Union was convinced that the Warsaw leadership would overcome successfully recent difficulties.

title: Catholic Marriage Courts Facing Reevaluation
description: Roman Catholic marriage courts, a source of both hope and disappointment for thou sands of believers involved in broken marriages, have en tered a period of crisis and reevaluation.

title: CARL BREER, 87, DIES; CHRYSLER ENGINEER,
description: DETROIT, Dec. 21Carl M. Breer, a pioneer automotive en gineer long associated with the Chrysler Corporation, died to day in the Ford Hospital after an illness of several weeks. He was 87 years old.

title: Screen: Claude Berri's 'Man With Connections':Semi-Autobiographical Tale at Little Carnegie
description: In "The Man With Connections," which opened yesterday at the Little Carnegie Theater, Claude Berri adds another semi-autobiographical fiction to a list of films that includes "The Two of Us" (1968) and "Marry Me, Marry Me" (1969). In tone and attitude, if not in scope, the Berri enterprise begs comparison with Truffaut's great Antoine movies. But on every level and in every way, the comparison goes sadly against Claude Berri.Berri is usually cited as being like Truffaut, but more sentimental. In fact, he is no more sentimental (or, more accurately, no more committed to the primacy of sentiment) than Truffaut, but he is, at least on film, very much less intelligent. For Truffraut's sense of a morally cohesive, humanly relevant universe (a sense that makes "Stolen Kisses" a masterpiece, no matter what its warmth of feeling), Berri can offer only an anecdotal appreciation of experience. Typically, his films get whatever form they have from the shape of public eventsthe great wars of our time. But in the context of the films, those events mean nothing.In "The Man With Connections" the time is the mid-1950's, the war is in Algeria, and young Claude (Guy Bedos), an aspiring actor who meanwhile manufactures caps with his father and mother, faces conscription. His parents counsel courage, his mistress offers logic (one month with her has gone quickly; 18 months in the army can only be one times 18) and a friend promises to pull strings. The strings give the film its title, and by that perverse fatality that guides the cutting of orders, they help move Claude from basic training outside Paris, to Morocco, to Algeriawhere he spends much time in the guardhouse but never does see combat.As a service comedy, "The Man With Connections" is predictable but not unpleasing. The various portraits work well enoughespecially Georges Geret as the French equivalent of a field first sergeant ("Don't play stupid with me. You may not win!") and Jean-Pierre Marielle as a Lieutenant Cassanova, who suavely courts Claude when he thinks that Claude's connections may win the outfit a visit from Brigitte Bardot.But a service comedy in the context of Algeria is a possible improbability, and Berri, who doesn't appear antiarmy or even antiwar, for that matter, ends his film with a wholly unearned irony that is supposed to connect with the larger terror behind every laugh the military mind can give you. Like all the other connections, this one, which opposes a kind of maniacal laughter to all the previous good humor, doesn't work, but to the embarrassment of the film rather than its main character.But even where it avoids embarrassment, "The Man With Connections" touches no major experience it does not belittle. For example, halfway through the film, Claude writes his mistress from North Africa to advise her not to wait for him because he is not ready to marry her. For just a moment we see the girl (Zorica Lozic) on her bed crying, and that is the last we see of her. The shot has the look of romantic economya look we (and surely Claude Berri) have come to value from the best of Truffaut and Jean Renoir. But whereas, in Renoir or Truffaut, that moment's pathos would relate to an orderromantic or notthat such economy might serve, in Berri it has no such relation because there is no order. There is merely the rush of circumstanceindifferent, callous and despite the ready tears, essentially cruel.

title: SAMUELS FAVORS RACES ON SUNDAY
description: Howard Samuels, president of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, said yes terday he favored Sunday rac ing at the state's thoroughbred and harness racing tracks.

title: Sports of The Times
description: All during the week the Giant season ticketholders were grousing and grumbling something fierce. What Giant management was doing to them was insulting, incon siderate and untrustworthy. They were be ing requested to come to Yankee Stadium ticket booths with certified checks in hand yesterday or today or tomorrow in order to pick up tickets for their regular loca tions for all postseason playoff games except the Super Bowlin which the Giant football team might be involved.

title: Manson's Prosecutor Outlines Testimony in Tate Murder Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 21 The detailed testimony of Linda Kasabian was outlined for the jurors in the TateLaBianca murder trial again today as the prosecution began its summa tion.

title: Vikings, Raiders Choice To Reach Super Bowl
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Dec. 21 The Minnesota Vikings and Oakland Raiders were favored today to reach the Super Bowl.

title: House Votes to Drop Curb On Sale of Some .22 Shells
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The House voted today, 247 to 59, to eliminate record keep ing requirements on purchases of certain ammunition that is usable in pistols as well as in hunting rifles.

title: CYANAMID IN PACT FOR SHULTON, INC.
description: The American Cyanamid Com pany announced yesterday that it was planning to enter the cosmetics field and had reached an agreement to acquire Shul ton, Inc., a producer of cos metics, toiletries and perfumes. Under the agreement, stock holders of Shulton will receive 0.96 of a share of Cyanamidcommon for each share of Shulton held. Shulton has 3.1 million com mon shares out standing. Based on the closing price of Cyanamid on the New York Stock Ex change yesterday, which was unchanged at 33, the trans action would involve Cyanamid stock worth approximately $100million. Shulton, which is also traded on the Big Board, ??ose  to 25. The announce ment of the proposed acquisi tion came after the market was closed.

title: JUDY COLLINS SINGS LILTINGLY OF TODAY
description: Judy Collins made an appear ance this weekend at Carnegie Hall, singing a wide range of folk songs, mostly contem porary.

title: WYNN IS RECOVERING FROM STAB WOUND
description: HOUSTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) Jim Wynn, a $57,500ayear outfielder with the Houston Astros, was reported to have been stabbed by his wife today during an early morning argu ment. The couple had cele brated their seventh wedding anniversary yesterday.

title: Principal Fighting for Her School Job
description: This, said Mrs. Lula Bramwell, her voice trem bling, my, Christmas pres ent.

description: Miss Sarah Perry Greene and Stoddard Dixon Fred ricks, graduates of Shimer College in Mount Carroll, Ill., were married here yesterday afternoon.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI) The House, in a surprise move tonight, approved a bill backed by the Nixon Adminis tration that would authorize $1.5billion to help schools meet the costs of desegrega tion.

description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The United States accused the Soviet Union today of jeopard izing the success of Big Four talks on Berlin by allowing continued East German harass ment of traffic into the city.

title: Theater: Paper Bag Players Capture Parents, Too
description: The Paper Bag Players are in residence for the holidays at the Hunter College Play house, providing pure pleas ure for children and for adults fortunate enough to be taken there by their children.

title: Deadlock of Conferees May Kill Food Stamp Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21A deadlock between Senate and House negotiators is threaten ing to end a Federal program under which about nine million Americans receive food at dis count prices.

title: Black Panther Defense Finishes CrossExamining of Infiltrator
description: Black Panther defense law yers completed eight days of crossexamination yesterday of an undercover policeman, De tective Gene Roberts. Two de fendants representing them selves, Mrs. Afeni Shakur and Michael Tabor, declined to question him.

title: SOLITARY FOR GIRL ENJOINED BY COURT
description: A 14yearold Nassau County girl was subjected to cruel and unusual punishment when she was placed in what amounted to solitary confinement at a state training school, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: 4TH JUROR SELECTED IN NEW HAVEN TRIAL
description: NEW HAVEN, Dec. 21 (UPI) A 26yearold former social worker for the Connecticut State Welfare Department was accepted here today as the fourth member of the jury that will try Bobby G. Seale and Mrs. Ericka Huggins, both mem bers of the Black Panther Party, on murderconspiracy charges.

title: PEKING SUPPORTS POLISH DISSIDENTS
description: HONG KONG, Dec. 22China today hailed the outbreak of resistance to Government au thority in Poland and said that it illustrated the crisis of co lonialist rule in East Europe by Soviet imperialism and the bankruptcy of modern revis ionism.

title: EFFECT ON VOTING VIEWED AS SLIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 When he was teaching political science at Columbia University, Dr. David B. Truman, now the president of Mount Holyoke College, used to tell his stu dents that lowering the voting age to 6 would make no great difference in election results unless free bubble gum were a major issue.

title: Bitter Charges Exchanged
description: BERLIN, Dec. 21East Ger mans and West Germans ex changed bitter charges today over West Berlin as border guards increased harassment on the city's access routes.

title: Apollo 14 to Get $15Million in New Safety Devices
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  A peddler's cart of scientific paraphernalia, 25 pieces of fireworks and $15million worth of new safety features will be toted to the moon aboard Apollo 14 next month, the space agency announced today.

title: Chubby Dean, 54, Pitched For Athletics and Indians
description: RIVERSIDE, N. J., Dec. 21 (AP)Alfred Lovill (Chubby) Dean, a pitcher for the Phila delphia Athletics and Cleve land Indians in the nineteen thirties and forties, died today at his home, 319 Middleton Street. He was 54 years old.

title: Jersey Is Said to Harass LongHaired
description: TRENTON, Dec. 21  The State Police were charged to day in Federal court with pur suing a systematic policy of illegal searches of longhaired persons who travel the New Jersey Turnpike and other ma jor highways in the state.

title: Rail Passenger Group Urges Expansion of Essential Network
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The National Association of Railroad Passengers said to day that expansion of the pro posed network of essential in tercity passenger trains would improve the chances of finan cial success.

title: Nixon Said to Be Studying Several Moves on P.O.W.'s
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UPI)  President Nixon has under consideration several rec ommendations for attempting to obtain the release of Amer ican war prisoners in North Vietnam, the White House said today.

title: No Easy Solutions Are Seen for Poland's Deep Economic Crisis
description: Edward Gierek, Poland's new Communist party chief, has taken power in the midst of a comprehensive economic crisis for which Western analysts see no easy or quick answers.

title: U.S. Tells of Plan to Cut Combat Forces in Japan
description: TOYKO, Dec. 21The United States today announced long awaited plans to take most of its combat forces out of Japan, reducing personnel by 12,000 men, to a total of 28,000 by mid1971.

title: MISSISSIPPI VOIDS EVOLUTION CURB
description: JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 21 (AP) Mississippi's law against the teaching of evolution, the last such state law in the nation, was overturned by the State Supreme Court today.

title: HANS G. KAUFMANN
description: Hans G. Kaufmann, a Nether lands and New York industrial ist, died Saturday at his home in Grandvaux, Switzerland. He was 66 years old.

title: SENATE SNARLED ON MAJOR ISSUES; A VETO SUSTAINED
T. O. Bear Marries Barbara Manning
description: MACON. Ga., Dec. 21Miss Barbara Belle Manning and Thomas Oliver Bear were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Roger Marxsen per formed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: PHILADELPHIA BAR SEES BIAS IN EXAM
description: PHILADEPJIA, Dec. 21  A special committee of the Phila delphia Bar Association charged today that procedures used by the State Board of Law Examiners discriminated against blacks seeking admis sion to the bar in Pennsylvania.

title: CONFEREES AGREE ON AID FUND CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (Reu ters)House and Senate con ferees agreed today on cuts in funds for Asian and Latin American development banks.

title: Sheriff Pays Taxi Fare Of Returning Fugitive
description: ROCHESTER, Dec. 21 (AP) The third of four men who escaped from the Monroe County Penitentiary yester day surrendered tonight after taking a taxicab back to the jail.

title: A Christmas Story
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Once upon a time a wave of public indignation arose when persona as different as Robert Kennedy and Senator Ernest Hollings of South Carolina discovered that in prosperous America there were millions of hungry people, many of them helpless children.

title: At Cubiculo, Artist Can Try Anything
description: The show may be the thing formost, but for many young artists today, it's the creation of the show, the need to see something develop and grow, without worry about how the pubilc takes to it.

title: Monzon to Defend Crown Against Benvenuti in Italy
description: BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 21 (AP)  Carlos Monzon of Ar gentina, the world middle weight boxing champion, will give Nino Benvenuti of Italy, a chance to regain the crown in a rematch in San Remo, Italy, next spring.

title: Executive Changes
description: Mutual of Omaha has appointed John D. Min ton as president and chief operating officer of the largest individual health insurance company in the world. Mr. Minton succeeds D. D. Ulfers who has served as president since 1964. V. J. Skutt, who remains as chairman and chief executive officer, announced the promotion of John F. Gaule to exec utive vice president for marketing and David S. Dodson to vice president for agency management and development.

title: U.S. Called Lax on School Segregation
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21Six civil rights groups called to day for strong Federal action against what they termed wide spread evasion by Southern school districts of desegregation requirements.

title: Lacey Slates Resignation To Become Judge in January
description: NEWARK, Dec. 21Frederick B. Lacey Jr., United States At torney for New Jersey, an nounced today that he would resign in January to accept the appointment to the Federal bench that was announced sev eral weeks ago.

title: Soviet Said to Ask Death for 2 of 11 in Hijacking Trial
FRANCIS SPITZER, 61, CORPORATE OFFICER
description: Francis A. E. Spitzer, a for mer secretary and director of Interchemical Corporation and a longtime resident of Forest Hills, Queens, died of cancer Saturday in Paris. He was 61 years old.

title: DESIGN OF HOUSING RELATED TO CRIME
High Court Refuses To Hear Challenge To City Rent Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  The Supreme Court refused to day to consider a challenge to the constitutionality of New York City's two rent control laws.

title: Brazil Is Willing To Free Nearly 50 As Envoy's Ransom
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 21  The Brazilian Government agreed today to free all but 22 persons on a ransom list of about 70 prisoners submitted by the abductors of the Swiss Am bassador to Brazil.

title: Florida Nuptials for Suzan Uchitel
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 21Miss Suzan Beth Uchi tel, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hy Jason Uchitel of Palm Beach and New York, own the Voisin and Camelot restaurants here, in New York, Miami Beach and Aca pulco, Mexico, was married here this evening to Fran cois Minoret, executive di rector of commercial cater ing for the Tour Nobel office building in Paris.

title: Debutantes Presented at 35th Cotillion
description: The 35th Debutante Cotil lion and Christmas Ball for the benefit of the New York Infirmary was held at the WaldorfAstoria last night. Seventyone debutantes were scheduled to be presented in the hotel's Grand Ballroom, where the decor was in the Shades of pink that have be come traditional with this party, but two young women developed flu and stayed home.

title: Baez's Husband Wins Parole
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) The Board of Parole today granted parole effective March 15 to David Victory Harris, a draft resister who is the hus band of Joan Baez, the folk singer. He is serving a three year term for refusing to submit to induction into the armed forces.

title: A Beame Aide on Labor Matters Is Pension Consultant to Union
description: A key aide to Controller Abraham D. Beame whose re sponsibilities include matters involving labor unions is re ceiving a monthly fee as a consultant to a union local.

title: First Flight of Navy's F14 Is Made in Brief L.I. Test
description: The Navy's new F14, de signed as successor both to the esteemed F4 Phantom fighter and the canceled F111B fleet defense plane, took to the air for the first time yesterday.

title: PLUNKETT HEADS HULA BOWL TEAM
description: HONOLULU, Dec.21 (UPI) The Heisman trophy, winner, Jim Plunkett, and Jim Still wagon of Ohio State, will spearhead a 29man North squad named today for the 25th annual Hula Bowl game Jan. 9.

title: SECURITIES ADVISER IS BARRED BY S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission has barred Philip R. Gould, president and sole stockholder of Gould's Position?? Inc., from association with any investment advisory publica tion without prior consent from the commission, it was an nounced today.

title: Reed, in Hospital, Applauds Jobby Fillmore, Knick Rookie
description: The telephone rang in Willis Reed's room yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. It was Red Holzman, the Knicks' coach, calling from Phoenix, Ariz.

title: Giants Have Time to Ponder Two Games They Should Have Won
description: Before the Giants turn their thoughts to legitimate optimistic planning for 1971, they can indulge in one quick backward look and contemplate two mighthave beens and one harsh large fact. The might  have  beens were contained in two close losses to fundamentally weaker teams, 1410 to the Saints at New Orleans on Oct. 4 and 2320 to the Eagles at Philadelphia the frigid night of Nov. 23.

title: Cowboys Offer Seats At Season's Prices
description: DALLAS, Dec. 21 (UP1) The boxoffice sale of tickets for next Saturday's Dallas Detroit football playoff game in the Cotton Bowl resumed today here and in Fort Worth, with about half the 72,000 to tal available.

title: Chief Sees a 33% Cut in Staff If Peace Corps Fund Is Pared
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 The Peace Corps will be com pelled to reduce its ranks of volunteers by onethird and curtail many of its programs if the Nixon Administration imposes a substantial budget cut in the coming year, Joseph H. Blatchford, the agency's direc tor?? said today.

title: Vast Purge Is Shattering Framework of Czech Life
description: A purge is devastating the political, intellectual, cultural, social and economic life of Czechoslovakia. The purge, tak ing the form of dismissal from key jobs, is still under way. Its effects are so far reaching that the buoyancy and hope so evident less than three years ago seem to have disap peared, and intellectuals, now condemned to manual labor or unemployment, appear deeply demoralized.

title: Fire Union Will File Charges Accusing City of Not Bargaining in Good Faith
description: Michael J. Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters As sociation, announced yesterday that he would file charges this morning that the city was re fusing to bargain in good faith on a new contract.

title: Louisville Tops Kansas, 8775; Harvard Is Routed by Michigan
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP)The University of Louisville, capital izing on free throws, upset eighthranked and previously undefeated Kansas, 8775, to night.

title: BURST IN 2D HALF SEWS UP CONTEST
description: MILWAUKEE, Dec. 21 (AP)  Lew Alcindor, the student, turned teacher tonight as he poured in 37 points to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 11388 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Reverse Effect Feared in Pushing Black Pride
description: According to two black psy chiatrists, though, most effects of black consciousness have been beneficial, it is possible that drilling black pride into a child's head in a stereotyped and isolated manner may actually have the reverse effect.

title: Advertising: Carl Ally Wins Fiat Account
description: Carl Ally, Inc., has won the FiatRoosevelt Motors ac count, its fourth nice piece of new business in the last eight months. According to the En glewood Cliffs, N. J., distrib utor of the Italian car, the billings on the account (in cluding the dealer coopera tive) are between $4.5million and $5million.

title: When Painters Try Their Hands at Jewelry and Clothes...
description: Edward C. Stevens is an observant man. As owner director of the Greenwich Gallery, 43 Greenwich Ave nue, he is surrounded by art ists. Recently he noticed that Carole Moskowitz, a painter whose work the gallery has exhibited, was wearing hand painted belts and carrying handbags of her own design. Futhermore, so were some of her friends. On further in vesigation, Mr. Stevens said, I found that a number of our artists were doing origi nal designs that, I believe will, in time, be adapted for the mass market.

title: 2 Who Aided Berrigan Warn of U.S. Repression
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., Dec. 21The first decision Dr. Wil liam Stringfellow and Anthony Towne had to make this morn ing was which of an assortment of 16 new and Colonial Amer ican flags to fly from the staff in front of their home.

title: STEP IN M.S.I. CASE BLOCKED BY COURT
description: PORTLAND, Maine, Dec. 21 (AP)A motion to dissolve a restraining order limiting trans fer of property between Maine Sugar Industries, Inc., and its affiliates was denied today in United States District Court.

title: Paul Boepple, Leading Choral Director, Is Dead
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt.. Dec.21 Paul Boepple, one of the na tion's leading choral directors and professors of music, died early today of pnuemonia. Mr. Boepple, who had been in fail ing health for the past two years, was 74 years old. He made his homer in nearby North Bennington.

title: Justices to Weigh Rights of Negroes Due to Lose Homes
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21  The Supreme Court agreed to day to consider the constitu tional and statutory rights of urban blacks whose homes are scheduled to be razed to make way for a Federal interstate highway.

title: Baker's Conviction Stands; ExSenate Aide Faces Jail
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 21The Supreme Court let stand today the Federal conviction of Robert G. Baker, once the protg and assistant to Lyndon B. Johnson when he was majority leader of the Senate.

title: Council Wants Better Service In Return for Taxi Fare Rise
description: The City Council is prepared to insist on improvements in taxi service before approving fare increases to meet new labor costs of the industry, sources close to the Council said yesterday.

title: Books of The Times
description: In the foreword to this survey of con servationist movements around the globe, Peter Scott, a painter, explorer and a man with a hand in many conservationist proj ects, uses what is to me an original and insightful phrase. He calls Earth our spaceship. All our lifesupport systems are right here, but unlike manmade space ships, they are not monitored elsewhere, watched over and guarded while we are sleep. If mankind insists on sleeping while air, water, greenery and animal life are polluted, destroyed or caused to disappear, no one is going to ring any bells or flash warning signals. This book does shoot of warning flares and even tells what should be done about the troubles it has found.

title: U.S. Denies Hanoi Charges In U.N. of War Atrocities
description: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 21 (Reuters)The United States circulated to all United Nations members today a detailed de nial of North Vietnamese charges that the United States was following a general policy of massacring civilians in In dochina.

title: Executive jet Cutting Penn Central Tie
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 21 Executive Jet Aviation, Inc., a flight charter service that was the subject of a critical Congressional report, has been reorganized under new man agement, is making a profit and is severing its ties with the Penn Central Transportation Company, its president said to day.

title: Pupils Assist the Neediest
description: Miss Breshin's class at Pub lic School 152class 4305 had heard about the needy, people and wanted to help. So some of the youngsters baked cookies and took them to school, and others took in old books.

title: JEWS WILL BEGIN HANUKAH TODAY
description: The eightday long observ ance of Hanukkah, the Festival of Lights marking the Macca bean victory over Syrian tyranny more than 2,000 years ago, begins at sundown today with celebrations in homes and synagogues.

description: Three stockbrokers, a Wall Street concern and a Canadian associate were indicted in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of attempting to evade United States taxes on the purchase of $20million of foreign securities??

title: Government Delaying Talks On Peace, Pathet Lao Says
