description: The cast was halfhour late for rehearsal and Patricia Elliott, one of the few to ar rive early, was waxing ec statically about the new John Bury set, which had just been put in place.

title: CATHOLICS REVIVE OFFICE OF DEACON
description: CHICAGO, Dee. 24Two hundred and seventyfive men are now training to be among the first group of permanent deacons of the Roman Catholic Church in the United States.

title: West Side Rent Strikers Lose Elevator Service
description: A group of tenants in a 12 story West Side apartment house who are on a rent strike charged yesterday that their landlord had denied them the use of the elevator.

title: Rise in Federal Pay Is Stalled Behind Defense Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) An estimated $1.1billion pay rise for Federal employes for next year is stalled in Congress behind a defense appropriation bill, but Congressional sources say it will probably be passed by Jan. 3.

title: John Jay Hooker Sr., Prosecutor Who Put Hoffa in Prison, Dead
description: NASHVILLE, Dec. 24John Jay Hooker Sr., the Nashville lawyer who was the Govern ment's chief special prosecutor in the jurytampering trial of James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, died at his Frank lin, Tenn., home today, appar ently of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

title: Gilmore Off to Fast start In Collegiate Rebounding
description: Artis Gilmore, Jacksonville's 7foot2inch star, is off to the fastest start in rebounding by any college basketball player an the last 16 years.

title: 2 PLANTS TO BE SHUT BY CONTINENTAL CAN
description: MONTVILLE, Conn., Dec. 24 (AP) The Continental Can Company will close two small plants here by the end of the year, putting 195 employes out of work, plant manager Bruce C. Duffy said yesterday.

title: 200 to 250 Stewardesses Of T.W.A. to Be Furloughed
description: Trans World Airlines an nounced yesterday that it would furlough 200 to 250 of its 5,000 stewardesses in the next several weeks because of normal seasonal reductions in flight operations in the first quarter of the year.

title: CHILDREN'S FOOD AID REPORTED IMPERILED
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI)  The Nixon Administration plans to eliminate from its next budget two programs that now feed thousands of poor children at an annual cost to the Gov ernment of $36million, Capitol Hill sources said today.

title: Hotel Strikers in Hawaii Vote to Accept Contrac??
description: HONOLULU, Dec. 24 (AP) An 11week hotel strike offi cially ended today with ratifi cation of a threeyear contract by some 2,000 employes. Gov. John A. Burns announced ten tative agreement on the con tract a week ago.

title: MRS. RICHARD GRANT SR.
description: Mrs. Laura Williams Grant, widow of Richard H. Grant Sr., former vice president of sales and board member of the Gen eral Motors Corporation, died Wednesday in Roosevelt Hos pital. She was 87 years old and lived at 1 Sutton Place South.

title: AEOLIAN CORP. WINS IMPORTINSURY HELP
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP)  The Aeolian Corporatio, a manufacturer of pianos, has been certified as eligible to ap ply for adjustment assistance tinder the Trade Expansion Act of I962, It wasannounced to day.

title: BECK PLANS SALE OF SEVERAL UNITS
U.S. REPORT LIFTS WHEAT FUTURES
description: Following the Agriculture Department's report on winter wheat production, the futures prices of that commodity rose sharply yesterday on the Chi cago Board of Trade. The re port predicted a reduction in winter wheat production for 1971.

title: Entertainment Events
description: TODAY

title: Gift to City Motorists Proves to Be a Hoax
description: The City Traffic Depart ment was swamped with calls yesterday morning from angry motorists who had been misled by broadcasts of an unauthorized announce ment that alternatesideof thestreet parking regulations would be suspended for the day.

title: New Kind of Bond Confuses Dealers In Europe Market
description: PARIS, Dec. 24European in vestors have recently sunk $50 million into a revolutionary type of bond issue.

title: JAPANESE ECONOMY SEEN TURNING DOWN
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24 (UPI)The Economic Planning Agency said today that the Japanese economy had turned down ward for the first time after 58 straight months of rising.

title: NIKOLAI SHVERNIK, SOVIET LEADER, 82
description: MOSCOW, (UPI)Nikolai M. Shvernik, President under Stalin, died today, the official Soviet press agency, Tass, an nounced. He was 82 years old.

title: Where Christmas Spirit Lives All the Year
description: SAN FRANCISCOImagine what it must have been likeBob's telling his parents he was courting a widow with nine children, said Mrs. Robert W. De Bolt of Piedmont, an went San Fran cisco suburb on the ?? of the bay.

title: Insurer Tests Sales by Mail
description: The St. Paul Fire and Marine Insurance Company and In vestors Diversified Services Inc., the mutual fund organiza tion, have been experimenting with the sale of St. Paul auto insurance by mail, Carl B. Drake Jr., president of the insurer, said yesterday.

title: Chavez Union Calls Strike Against 6 Lettuce Growers
description: CALEXICO, Calif., Dec. 24 (AP)The United Farm Work ers Organizing Committee call ed a strike today against six lettuce growers shortly after the union leader, Cesar Chavez, was released from jail.

title: BIG BOARD DELAY ON RATES IS SEEN
description: The New York Stock Ex change is expected to defer action on a permanent new commissionrate structure for securities transactions until next June, according to Wall Street sources.

title: Soviet Dooms Two Jews In Plane Hijacking Plot
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 24A Lenin grad court tonight found all 11 defendants guilty of planning to hijack a Soviet airliner and sen tenced two of them to death by the firing squad. Nine others received prisoncamp terms ranging from 4 years to 15.

title: Music: A Revival of Acis and Galatea
description: If it were no more than Handel's first dramatic work in English, Acis and Gala tea would be important enough to revive regularly; but, beyond its historical cachet the scare happens to be one of the most beguiling ever composed.

title: Drive Brings 15,000 Gifts
description: More than 15,000 gifts have been collected in the annual drive to make Christmas and Hanukkah more pleasant for patients in the municipal hos pitals and for children in orphanages, Mrs. John V. Lind say, wife of the Mayor and leader of the campaign, re ported yesterday. Mrs. Lindsay said the gifts exceeded all esti mates. She lauded the help of WOR television and radio, the New York Newspaper Reporters Association, the Police, Fire and Sanitation Departments and the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Masses, Caroling and Prayers Herald the Coming of Christmas
description: Christmas came to town last night at midnight masses in lofty cathedrals, at simple can dlelighting services in little churches, in joyous caroling and in solemn prayer.

title: Concessions in Warsaw
description: Edward Gierek, Poland's new Communist party chief, is moving swiftly to make more concrete the conciliatory policy he announced immediately after succeeding Wladyslaw Gomulka.

title: From Calcutta With Love
description: Pope Paul gave the first Pope John award this week to a 60yearold Yugoslavborn nun whose pioneer ing work among the poor in Calcutta has expanded into a universal mission of love.

title: CAHILL PLANNING MAJOR TOLL ROM
description: TRENTON, Dec. 24  Gov. William T. Cahill disclosed a uomprehensive masstransporta tion program today that in cluded a major new toll turn pike, extension of the New Jer sey Turnpike, a series of air ports for shorttakeoffand landing aircraft and a rapid transit network radiating from Newark.

title: Aussie Wins at Junior Net
description: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 24 (AP) Allan Boss of Australia ral lied today to beat Cary Brow der of Stillwater, Tenn., 57, 186, 64, in the third round of the Orange Bowl junior tennis championships for boys 18 years and under.

title: BERNARD SACHS
description: MAHOPAC, N.Y., Dec. 24 Bernard Sachs, editor and pub lisher of World Coffee and Tea, a trade journal, died yesterday at his home on Mexico Lane following a long illness. He was 57 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, DECEMBER 25, 1970

title: PRICES ADVANCE  IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange scored a strong advance yesterday as the list made its biggest gain in more than three weeks in slow trad ing.

title: Unions Aim for Big Raises Despite Lagging Economy
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24  The Administration calls it wage inflation, but labor leaders and workers call if catchup. And despite a slow economy and high unemployment rates, some union men say they will keep on running after big raises until they have caught up.

title: NorthSouth Test Shapes Up Today As Aerial Battle
description: MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP)  Abi lene Christian's Jim Lindsey will display his passing prowess for the South tomorrow in the NorthSouth Shrine football game. Lindsay has thrown 64 career touchdown passes for the small Texas school. The 5 foot11inch sharpshooter fin ished his collegiate career with an eyepopping total of 8,721 yards.

title: Court Compromise To Let Seale See Private Psychiatrist
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 24Bobby G. Seale, the Black Panther party's national chair man, will be allowed to see his own psychiatrist under a com promise worked out in Federal Court here today on a suit in volving the rights of jailed prisoners.

title: KENTUCKY FRIED RAISES EARNINGS
description: Record sales and earnings were achieved by the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, it reported yesterday.

title: Massachusetts Aide Bars 24% Auto Insurance. Rise
description: BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP)In surance Commissioner C. Eu gene Farnam turned down to day, a propoied 24.7 per cent rise in automobile, fire, theft and comprehensive Insurance premiums sought by the Travel ers, Insurance Company.

title: Books of The Times
description: Once upon a time there was a prince who grew up in a gingerbread castle decorated with mediocre paintings of the Grail leg end, Tannhliuser and the swanknight Lo hengrin. The boy loved swans, and next

title: Fire Ruins Newspaper Plant And Stalls Trains in Jersey
description: RED BANK, N.J., Dec. 24 A fire wrecked the editorial and business offices and com posing room of the Daily Register here this afternoon and officials said that they doubted that the next issue, which is due on Monday, could be printed in the plant.

title: Savings Office Held Up
description: Four gunmen held up the First Federal Savings and Loan Association at 4404 Kissena Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, yesterday and escaped with an undetermined amount of money, the police reported. The gun men fled in a maroon Cadillac.

title: Poet and Composer Join in a Recital
description: Two 1970 Pulitzer Prize winners, Richard Howard, poet, and Charles Wuorinen, composer, got together at the Few York Cultural Center on Wednesday night to present a program of their works.

title: A Word for Christmas
description: Merry is an old and honored English word, much favored by Shakespeare, but its association with Christ mas seems to be the work of Charles Dickens and other Victorians. For example, the much misquoted last line of Clement Moore's A Visit From St. Nicholas written in 1823 actually reads: Happy Christmas to all, and to all a good night!

title: De Gaulle Memoirs the Rae of Paris
description: PARIS, Dec. 24The hottest literary property in France now is anything by Charles de Gaulle: as of Dec. 1, various works by the late President had together passed the mark of lone million copies sold during the outgoing year.

title: A Black Christmas Mythology Evolves
description: CHICAGO, Dec. 24  When more than 10,000 black chil dren crowded into the Capitol Theater on Chicago's South Side yesterday to watch special Christmas programs by the cast of Sesame Street, a brightly clad personage, equal in impor tance to any of the players, bounded among them.

title: NIXON MESSAGE: A HOPE FOR PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UM)President Nixon issued a special Christmas message to day in which he expressed con fidence that proxpects for a generation of peace were brightening. He urged the American people to put aside what divides us.

title: Hanoi Negotiators in Paris Willing to Hold Private Talks
description: PARIS, Dec. 24 (AP)North Vietnam said tonight that it was willing to hold private talks with the United States to break the deadlock in the peace conference.

title: Trial in The Hague Emphasizes Plight Of the Displaced Arnboinese Islanders
description: THE HAGUE, Dec. 19  Barbed wire seals off the streets around the Hague dis trict court. Armed policemen stand guard, silently watching the young defendants step into the courtroom and raise their fists in militant salute.

title: Marshall Fund at $177,996
description: HUNTINGTON, W. Va., Dec. 24 (UPI)Marshall University reported today its memorial fund had grown to $177,996 since the Nov. 14 crash of a chartered jetliner that killed most of the school's football team and eight athletic depart ment members. Contributions included a $50,000 gift from Carroll Rosenblum, the Balti more Colts owner, the school said.

title: Film Critics Will Select Best Movies on Monday
description: The season for movie bests is at hand.

title: Jewish Groups Denounce Soviet Death Sentences
description: Jewish organizations yester day strongly protested the death sentences of two Jewish prisoners in the Leningrad hi jacking trial and other groups staged demonstrations in front of the Soviet mission to the United Nations, at 136 East 67th Street.

title: New Left's PhilosopherHero
description: PARIS, Dec. 24Respond ing at last to appeals by Charles de Gaulle, Pope Paul VI and thousands of others, the Bolivian Government has restored to freedom one of the world's most redoubtable intellectual foes of estab lished order.

title: GABRIEL FERRAS, LED SETTLEMENTS BANK
description: LYONS, France, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Gabriel Ferras, gen eral manager of the Bank for International Settlements, died in a hospital here after his car was involved in an accident near Lyons last night. He was 57 years old.

title: PRICE INDEX IS UP 0.3% FOR MONTH, BUT PACE SLOWS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 The rise in consumer prices slackened in November, the Labor Department reported to day.

title: Executive Changes
description: William T. Saeger has been named president of the Registrar and Transfer Company of New York and New Jersey. He has been executive vice presi dent since late 1969. John E. Buell, previously president, will continue as chairman of the com pany which provide record keeping services for more than 900 corporations. Rollins International, Inc., of which Registrar and Transfer is a subsidiary, also announced the appointment of R. Gene McCor mick as vice president and controller of Rollins. He was formerly vice presidentfinance of the PhilcoFord Corporation.

title: Colt Star Tickles Em Pink
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 24 (AP) I'm not what you would call a flashy dresser, said Roy Jef ferson, zipping up the front of his knitted onepiece pink jump suit.

title: Slight Upturn Seen in British Economy
description: LONDON, Dec. 24Britain is ending a disappointing eco nomic year with welcome signs of a slight business upturn.

title: U.S. ASKS REVIEW OF PROXY RULING
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) The Supreme Court was asked today to review a lower court decision that the Securities and Exchange Commission said; in effect overturns more than 30 years of settled administrative practice in handling business proxy case disputes.

title: It's Not the Hills of Rome, It's Also Nearby Slopes
description: ROCCARASO, Italy, Dec. 24The timing was perfect. Just when resort owners in this central Italian region of the Apennine Mountains were getting ready to press the panic button because of a shortage of snow, a storm that produced 10 inches came along two clays ago.

title: Col. Joel Adams, 60, Dies; 1st Negro Draft Board Head
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) Col. Joel G. Adams, the fiist Negro to head a state head quarters of the Selective Serv ice System, died today, the na tional headquarters announced. He was 60 years old.

title: JOHN STEPHENSON, EXTIMES EDITOR
description: John Stephenson, former head of the national copy desk of The New York Times, died Wednesday evening at Halifax General Hospital in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 69 years old and had lived in Ormond Beach since his retirement in 1997.

title: Japan to Replace U.N. Envoy
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24 (UPI) Japan will replace its United Nations representative Senjin Tsuruoka, with Toru Naka gawa, who is now Ambassador to the Soviet Union?? the news agency Kyodo said today.

title: Nobody's Story. .. by Charles Dickens
description: He lived on the bank of a mighty river, broad and deep, which was always silently rolling on to a vast un discovered ocean. It had rolled on, ever since the world began. It had changed its course sometimes, and turned into new channels? leaving its old ways dry and barren but it had ever been upon the flow, and ever was to flow until Time should be no more. Against its strong, un fathomable stream, nothing made head. No living crea ture, no flower, no leaf, no particle of animate or inani mate existence, ever strayed back from the undiscovered ocean. The tide of the river set resistlessly towards it; and the tide never stopped, any more than the earth stops in its circling round the sun.

title: Adm. Charles M. Cooke of Pacific Fleet Is Dead
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI)Adm. Charles M. Cooke, former Deputy Chief of United States Naval Operations and former commander of the Pa cific Fleet, died today after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: PROTESTS BY WELSH STOP DAM IN VALLEY;
description: Dispatch of The Times. London

title: Ozark Airlines Will Defer Paying Interest on Bonds
description: Ozark Airlines said yester day that interest payments due Jan. 1 on its 6 per cent and 5 per cent subordinated con vertible debentures would be deferred.

title: Many of Neediest Face Lonely Day
U.S. CONCERNS DELAY PAYMENT CHILE SAYS
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  The Chilean Gov ernment accused the American copper companies of Anaconda and Kennecott today of delay ing payment of a total of $40 million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Tragedy and Guilt at Mylai

title: Santa Anita Open Tomorrow
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 24 (UPI)Overflow fields were the order today as horsemen jammed the racing secretary's office to file entries for Satur day's opening day program of the 75day Santa Anita winter thoroughbred meeting.

title: Shortage of Trains And Crews Delays Commuters on L.I.R.
description: Thousands of Long Island Railroad commuters, many of them laden with lastminute Christmas purchases, were de layed up to an hour at Penn sylvania Station last night by a shortage of both trainmen and trains.

title: When You Want Chinese Food at Home
description: **Jolly Chan's Chinese Kitchen, 1069 First Avenue (at 58th Street), 4861182. This is the latest in a long line of Chinese kitchens with takehome foods. It is in the Sutton Place area, and it may very well have the most extensive and best menu of them all. It is the enterprise of Robert Tsang, who owns the wellregarded Mon Sing restaurant on Mott Street in Chinatown.

title: Pope, at Diplomats Mass, Calls Christmas an Antidote for Despair
description: ROME, Friday, Dec. 25  Pope Paul VI celebrated mid night mass for diplomats in the Vatican's Sistine Chapel early today and in a sermon spoke gravely about the state of the world.

title: New Women's Prison to Open Here in February
description: Officials will begin moving inmates of the Women's House of Detention to a new facility on Rikers Island in February, it was announced yesterday by the Department of Corrections.

title: Unitas Sprains Shoulder
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 24 (UPI) Johnny Unitas suffered a slight shoulder sprain during workouts today, but the Colts 37yearold quarterback said he would be able to start in the playoff game against the Ben gals.

title: Goodman Lays BailJumping to Courts
description: A State Senator charged yes terday that inefficiency by the court system and the Police Department was responsible for the continued freedom of thou sands of criminal defendants who have jumped bail.

title: Palmer Enters Coast Golf
description: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 24 (UPI) Arnold Palmer, who failed to win a tour event during 1970, informed the sponsoring Los Angeles Junior Chamber of Commerce today he was enter ing the $110,000 Los Angeles, open, which kicks off the win ter tour starting Jan. 7.

title: Market Place:
description: The Morgan Guaranty Sur vey, a review of economic and monetary affairs; has been using fables to illustrate our nation's economic pre dicament.

title: Nixon Vetoes Loss Claim
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) President Nixon vetoed today a relief bill that would have permitted the Foreign Claims Settlement Commission to pay Miloye M. Sokitch of Washing ton $215,200 for property losses he suffered in Italy during World War II. In a memoran dum, Mr. Nixon said he could find no true equities to sup port Mr. Sokitch's claim.

title: DOWNSTATE NURSES DROP RESIGNATIONS
description: The Downstate Medical Cen ter in Brooklyn announced yes terday that its staff nurses had rescinded resignations submit ted last week following resolu tion of a wage dispute.

title: VILLEMURE PUTS SELECTORS ON SPOT
description: Gilles Villemure not only is making life difficult for op posing National Hockey League players he's giving the all star team selectors moments of hesitation as well.

title: Horses Sent Abroad to Race Now Exempt From U.S. Fee
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) President Nixon signed into law today a bill permitting United States horses to reenter the country duty free when they have been temporarily sent abroad for racing.

title: CONGRESS PASSES RELOCATION FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24A bill nearly 10 years in the mak ing that would provide finan cial assistance to persons dis placed by federally funded projects has been sent to Pres ident Nixon.

title: Pro Basketball Fight Leads to Arrest of Squires Coach and 2 Players
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 24 (AP)The cases of Al Bi anchi, coach of the Virginia Squires, and two of his play ers, who were arrested after a basketball brawl at the Indiana State Fairgrounds last night, were continued to Jan. 29 today in Indianapolis Municipal Court.

title: Autos Will Shelter Fish
description: VARAZZE, Italy (AP)This Italian Riviera town decided to dump 1,000 wrecked automo biles into the Ligurian Sea to make a feeding ground that will shelter fish from fishermen.

title: BAIL DENIED LAWYER CHARGED IN SLAYING
description: BALTIMORE, Md., Dec. 24 Baltimore Supreme Bench Judge Paul A. Dorf refused today to grant a request for bail by Arthur Turco, a New York law yer who is in jail here on five charges in connection with the torture and murder of a Balti more Negro in July, 1969.

title: BUSINESS DEMAND FOR CREDIT WEAK
description: Demand for shortterm busi ness credit was notably weak in the latest twoweek period, data published by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed yesterday.

title: Plane Crash Survivor Hit and Killed by Auto
description: COLDWATER, Miss., Dec. 24 (AP)Two men survived the crash of their light plane near here last night, but one was killed a short time later by an automobile.

title: Escaper Gives Himself Up
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 24 (AP)A convicted murderer who escaped from Ohio Peni tentiary on Monday gave him self up at the prison yester day, saying he did not want to disappoint people who had trusted in him. Hollis B. Leigh, 54 years old, serving a life term for a firstdegree murder conviction, surrendered to a guard captain at the prison.

title: Pound Circulation Increases 23.79Million in the Week
description: LONDON, Dec. 24 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended Wednesday in thousands of pounds follows:

title: ROBERT S. M'CALLUM, LARCHMONT LEADER
description: Robert S. MacCallum, a former Republican and Red Cross leader in Larchmont, N.Y., died Wednesday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he was spending the winter. He was 67 years old.

title: Quakers Attempt to See the President
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 Members of the American Friends Service Committee at tempted to deliver to the Presi dent today a report condemn ing Vietnamization and United States policies on the war in Vietnam.

title: LAYOFF OF 60 DUE AS CITY CUTS BACK
description: A cutback in the printing of official city records as an aus terity measure may force the layoff today of about 60 print ers.

title: Closing of Rochester Plant Upheld by Federal Judge
description: BUFFALO, Dec. 24 (UPI) Federal Judge Harold P. Burke refused today to block the clo?? ing of the General Dynamics plant in Rochester.

title: Donation to Aid Museum
description: The Field Museum of Nat ural History in Chicago has re ceived a contribution of a half milion dollars from the Stand ard Oil (Indiana) Foundation to aid the museum to undertake a longpostponed program of re pairs and improvement.

title: Grenade Hurled Near Bethlehem
description: BETHLEHEM, Friday, Dec. 25 (AP)A hand grenade ap parently thrown by an Arab guerrilla, exploded last night on the outskirts of Bethlehem, Israeli security agents said, No one was injured, they reported. They said that the grenade had been hurled at an Israeli civil ian car but had missed.

title: 75 Million Americans To Get U.S. Forms
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP)  Your 1970 Federal in come tax form will soon be on the way.

title: Continental Insurance Reaches Interim Bond Pact With Banks
description: The Continental Insurance Company disclosed yesterday an interim agreement with ma jor New York City banks that likely will enable the market in Government securities to function smoothly until Con gress can pass legislation that would lead to a permanent so lution.

title: Views Attributed to Miss Dohrn Indicate Shift From Violence
description: A significant shift in emphasis for the Weatherman faction of radicals, both in philosophy and tactics, has been suggested in a recent statement allegedly Written by Bernardine Dohrn, a fugitive leader of the underground group.

title: Rising Service Cost Keenly Felt By Consumers Around Country
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 Patricia Plants complains that the rent for her efficiency apartment in the East Liberty section of Pittsburgh has gone up to $132 a month from $125. But for Miss Plants, and mil lions of other people, rent is only one of many services that are costing more and more.

title: Maddox Plays Santa
description: ATLANTA, Dec. 24 (AP) Gov. Lester G. Maddox dis guised himself as Santa Claus today and took Christmas gifts to an 11yearold girl and her 11 brothers and sisters who be lieve he has connections at the North Pole. Mr. Maddox, re sponding to a plea from Wanda Wallace, took a station wagon full of toys and food to the children's house in a lowincome section of Atlanta.

title: 24 Killed in Collision of Ships Of U.S. Company in Java Sea
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 24 (AP)  Twentyfour per sons were killed last night when two vessels operated by an American oil service com pany collided in the Java Sea east of Jakarta and one vessel sank.

title: Mrs. Bette S. Joblin Rewed Here
description: Mrs. Bette S. Joblin of New York and Quogue, L. I., an investment executive with the stock exchange firm of Shearson Hammill & Co., was married here yesterday to Hilliard Myron Budd Mittle man, a vice president of the Armour Pharmaceutical Com pany in Chicago.

title: In Memoriam
description: BECKENSTEINSamuel. In cherished memory of a truly, beloved and inspiring founder. S. BECKENSTEIN INC.

title: Court Denies Dock Job To Man With a Record
description: A former longshoreman with an early criminal record ?? been denied the right to return to work on the docks..

title: Agnew Scholarship Award
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UPI) An 18  year  old Athens Uni versity student, Angelika Krit hara, has been named winner of Vice President Agnew's sec ond annual college scholarship award of $1,600 to a resident of the Greek town of Garga Hanoi. Mr. Agnew established the Spiro Anagostopoulos Me morial Scholarship in 1969 in honor of his grandfather, who was a notary public in Garga lianoi, in the southwest Pelop poriesus, 27 miles west of Kala mata.

title: Walton of Leafs Reinstated As Report Confirms Illness
description: TORONTO, Dec. 24 (AP) The suspension of Mike Walton, a Toronto Maple Leaf center, was lifted today by Clarence Campbell, the president of the National Hockey League.

title: Faking Denies Agreement With Moscow on Rivers
description: TOKYO, Dec. 24 (AP)  Peking today disputed a Soviet report of a SovietChinese agreement on navigation along rivers that form their boundary.

title: Screen: Perfection and a Love Story
Three Principal Performers Are Signed for New Shows
description: Three principal performers have been signed for forthcom ing shows here.

title: New Books
description: A Guilty Thing Surprised, by Ruth Rendell (Doubleday, $4.50). A Crime Club detective story.

title: Christmas Season in Washington
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24The capital's oldest parish church, named for Christ, has been promised special police for the traditional midnight eucharist. President Nixon held out a vi sion of peace for all Americans except members of Congress from whom he wants 10 more days of hard labor. Lobbyists

title: Harried New Yorkers Jostle Toward Holiday
description: Nostrils steaming as it ex haled, the horse trudged pa tiently along the road be tween the snow  mantled fields and hillocks where small children wearing bright knitted caps coasted on their sleds.

title: Voices of Harlem Swing at Concert With a Gospel Beat
description: When the 18 Voices of East Harlem poured out on the stage of Carnegie Hall Wednesday night and started swinging through a joyous, jumping ver sion of Hark, the Herald Angels Sing, it was obvious that this was going to be no ordinary Christmas concert.

title: Council Names 4 to Board of Elections
description: The City Council last night elected two new members to the city's Board of Elections and renewed the terms of two others.

title: FUEL DELIVERERS WORK ON BACKLOG
description: Fuel oil was being distributed throughout the city yesterday and deliveries will continue through the weekend as hun dreds of tank trucks were pressed into service to catch up on a backlog of orders fol lowing a weeklong strike of deliverers.

title: EXPASSER SHAPED TEAM INTO WINNER
description: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 24 (UPI)Bennie Ellender, who converted Arkansas State from a loser to national smallcollege champion, accepted the head football coaching job at Tulane University today.

title: Blackman's Coaching Guide: Old Fight Talk Gives Way to Talking Sense
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 24 (AP) What kind of football coach is Bob Blackman, who at 52 years of age is leaving the Ivy League he dominated for 16 years to take over at downtrodden Illinois in the dogeatdog Big Ten?

title: Pravda Notes Polish Discontent
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 24  Prav da, the Communist party news paper, said today that every thing was not going smoothly in Poland and suggested that the new leaders in Warsaw would have to make great ef forts to resolve the difficulties that have arisen.

title: Some Filipinos Want U.S. to Stay Awhile
description: MANILA, Dec. 24  To the usual demonstrators cry of Yankee, go home! a Manila columnist has wryly added, and take me with you. He was referring to the attitude of some 80,000 residents of Cavite Prov ince over the proposed return of Sangley Point Naval Base to the Philippines next year. The Cavitenos sent a 40Man delegation to President Ferdi nand Marcos this month to ask for a delay in taking over the United States Navy's airsea complex south of Manila.

title: Often, Computers Spoil Cupid's Aim
description: Claudia Lovell got divorced after six years of marriage, west to Los Angeles, got a job as a secretary and moved in with a girl friend. But she said that the men she started meeting were not a very nice class of people.

title: Lindsay Says City Will Examine Books Of State Units Here
A Buying Surge Lifts Volume of Retailers

title: Tricia Wedding Rumor Still Just That
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24  The White House backed and filled and finally fell silent today on reports that Tricia Nixon, the President's older daughter, would marry Edward Finch Cox, a Harvard Law student who has been a beau of Miss Nixon's for varying periods over the last six years.

title: MISS KEMMER BOWS IN ADELAIDE TENNIS
description: ADELAIDE, Australia, Dec. 24 (Reuters)Kris Kemmer of Los Angeles was beaten by top seeded Olga Morozova of the Soviet Union in the women's singles final of the South Aus tralian tennis championship to day. The score was 64, 46, 97.

title: Vast Ibadan a Most Genuinely African City
description: IBADAN, Nigeria, Dec. 21  This vibrant city, alive with music and color, is one of the two or three largest urban areas in black Africa, and there is scant sign of Eu ropean influence here.

title: Freed French Marxist Reported in Santiago
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 24 (AP)  Rgis Debray, the French Marxist who was re leased yesterday from a Bo livian military jail, report edly arrived here tonight under tight security.

title: INDIA EXPLORING OFFSHORE AREAS
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 24 (Reu ters)After several decades of suceessful exploration on land, India is now venturing offshore in a big way in search, of min erals and oil under the sea.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Urged to Call A Parliamentary Election
description: NEW DELHI, Dec. 24.Jag jivan Ram, president of the rul ing New Congress party, to night reported a consensus among party leaders that we will have a good chance if an early midterm election is held for Parliament.

description: MARSEILLES, France, Dec. 24 (Reuters)  The Marseilles Nautical Society announced to day it would challenge for the America's Cup in 1973.

title: Manager of Bowery Hotel Slain In an Argument Over Cigarettes

title: Saigon's Gunfire, for a Night, Is From Toys

description: HONG KONG, Friday, Dec. 25 (Reuters)A British banker, David Johnston, was released by China today after 28 months detention in Shanghai, and arrived in Hong Kong, the Government here announced.

title: ShortTerm SST Appropriation Is Viewed as Futile
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 23  The Senate leadership's idea for breaking the logjam on the Su personic Transport with a short extension of funding has gen erated the mixed feelings that greet any stay of execution: shortterm relief, and longterm dread. If current trends con tinue, the SST's escape from the death sentence may prove to have been an illusion.

title: 1970 Auto Output: 6.55 Million Units, Lowest Since 1961
description: DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP) New car production in the United Staes will close out the year at about 6.55 million units, which is 1,669,463 less than in 1969 and the lowest number since 1961, a trade publication, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.

title: Puerto Rico Is a New Beachhead for the Jingle of Santa's Joy
description: SAN JUAN, P.?? R.?? Dec. 21 The approach of Christmas this year has highlighted the grow ing North. American influence on one seasonal aspect of life in Puerto Ricogift giving. It Is a trend that works to the advantage of the young.

title: The Meadows in Perspective
description: For decades dreamers have envisioned a city growing out of the huge Hackensack Meadowlands. In 1968 the New Jersey Legislature appointed a commission to under take the thirtyyear task of converting a noisome swamp into a community larger in area than Manhattan. Publi cation of the commission's plan is a landmark, nonethe less historic for the serious questions posed by the swiftly changing nature of the metropolitan region.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE DECLINES FOR WEEK

title: Walter van Benschoten, Maker of Airplane Parts
description: CHICO, Calif., Dec. 24  Walter van Benschoten, retired owner of the Highland Engi neering Company of Santa Monica, died of a heart attack last night at his home here, 604 Arbutus Ave. He was 69 years old.

title: Seeking a Drug Cure
description: Long after public officials should have formulated effective policies for curbing what they freely recognize to be a drug epidemic, a privately sponsored confer ence on drug abuse for community school board members has revealed the appalling absence of almost any kind of policies at all. This conference was organized jointly by the Community Service Society of New York and by the Public Education Association, two immensely valu able agencies.

title: Jerusalem the Golden
description: PARISPeace prospectS in the Mid dle East are probably less bad today than at any time since I967. That is not to say prospects are good: simply that talks between both sides will almost certainly be resumed and that pressures by the Big Four powers and by public opinion in Israel, Egypt and Jordan are conducive to agree ment.

title: New York's Freshmen in Congress Get a Head Start on Homework
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 The eight newly elected Representatives from New York will not go on the Fed eral payroll until next month, but they already are im mersed in almost as much Congressional business as some House members who have been here for years.

description: DETROIT, Dec. 25 (UPI) If it hadn't been for Dr. Frank Soler's quick diagnosis over the phone, a veteran policeman, his wife and their four children might be dead in their home in northwest Detroit.

They were the last of 34 freed in the s??v case.

title: COMPUTER SPEEDS CLINIC'S SERVICE
description: Ramon, a spindly, darkeyed nineyear old fidgeted nervous ly while waiting at Bellevue Hospital's pediatric outpatient clinic recently. Suddenly he slid to the floor in an epileptic seizure. As nurses moved in to help him, a whitecoated physi cian stepped up to a keypunch machine at the clinic's registra tion desk and typed a short code on the keyboard.

title: More Students Forced to Work To Cope With Cost of Education
description: John Porterfield, a 22year old senior at Ohio State Uni versity, works four afternoons a week for the city National Bank in Columbus. At night he tends bar at Charlie Brown's near the campus, using the in comes to rent a room and buy infrequent meals.

description: After six months in office under the new school de centralization law, members of the District 10 Community School Board in the north west Bronx are confident that they have found more flex ible and rewarding ways of educating the 28,000 pupils in their area.

title: ISRAELI KNESSET ASKS CLEMENCY FOR SOVIET JEWS

It also asked freedom for nine other defend ants given prisoncamp sen tences of 4 to 15 years in the Leningrad court case yester day.

title: Bullets Beat Bulls, 128112
description: BALTIMORE, Dec. 25 (AP) The Baltimore Bullets crushed Chicago, 128112, tonight de spite a 42point performance by?? Bob Love of the Bulls.

title: Condors .Sink Cougars
description: PITTSBURGH, Dec. 25 (UPI) John Brisker scored 30 of his 39 points in the second half to pace the Pittsburgh Condors to a 136121 victory over the Carolina Cougars tonight. The victory moved the Condors ahead of the Cougars and out of last place in the Eastern Division.

title: Books of The Times
description: History, said James Joyce, is a night mare from which I am trying to wake up. The cold war is just such a historical bad dream and we are still in Its throes, for all the political rhetoric of going beyond the cold war. Berlin is still divided; West and East Germany inch glacially toward a min imal accommodation: American troop re ductions in Korea are talked about but the two sides still peer across the DMZ; the stra tegic arms limita tion talks drag on; a purified Cze??ho slovak Govern ment initiates purges as relent less as those in the days of Benes and Masaryk; and Poland undergoes  for what out come it is not cer tain  another pe riod of civil tur moil. All of these events may be traced back to the immediate postwar era when the Soviet Union militarily occupied Eastern Europe and when the former Allies fell out over the terms of peace; The first five years of that postwar era when the balance shaky wartime trust was con verted to our present balance of terror are the subject of. Herbert Feis's latest foray into the brambled paths of diplomatic history.

title: Stalinism in Leningrad
description: Incredulity and indignation have been justifiably and widely aroused by the Leningrad court that handed down death sentences against two of eleven defendants found guilty of having plotted to hijack a Soviet plane. The senseless brutality of this verdict is apparent from the fact that no hijacking actually took place, and the alleged conspirators were arrested before they ever, boarded the plane. Moreover the, information of the Soviet secret police about the whole matter was so complete that the suspicion must arise that the supposed hijacking plot was a provocation arranged by a government agent.

title: BUCKS PLAYHOUSE PLANS EXPANSION
description: The 33yearold Bucks County Playhouse in New Hope, Pa., one of the few professional rep ertory theaters operating 52 weeks a year without subsidy, is planning a $6.5million 10 year development program.

title: 60 Yachts Depart Today In SydneyHobart Event
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 25 (UPI)Sir Frank Packer, the Australian newspaper executive whose yacht Gretel II waged a stiff but losing battle to Intrepid in this year's Ameri ca's Cup Race, will fire the starting gun tomorrow for the 26th annual SydneytoHobart race

title: Hanoi Says Prisoner Mail Was Given to U.S. Visitors
description: TOKYO, Dec. 25 (UPI)The Hanoi radio said today that an American delegation had been given 319 letters and 330 Christmas cards for the fam ilies of United States prisoners of war in North Viet??am.

title: Who is Guilty?
description: A large number of liberal whites and movement blacks accept the prin ciple of collective and inherited guilt Collective guilt means that every member of a group is guilty for the sins or, crimes committed by a single member. Thus, every white man is guilty of the oppression committed against black men.

title: 76ers Win 6th Straight
description: PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 (UPI)  Hal Greer scored 28 points tonight, including the 2 that put Philadelphia ahead to stay as the 76ers defeated the Detroit Pistons, 105100, for their sixth straight victory.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Last Christmas I wrote a column on economics and love. Under the mistaken preconcep tion that these, like oil and water, cannot mix, several people applauded either my innovation or my recan tation.

description: For the most part; the sports world spent the day at home yesterday, opening presents, and the competition centered on breaking the record for the fastestopened packages.

description: PARIS, Dec. 20A Turkish Air Force officer, under ques tioning, acknowledged recently that Soviet MIG21 fighter air craft, on their way to Egypt, had landed in Turkey to refuel. But, he added, only this one time.

On the contrary, it is quite probable that fewer than half of those given the franchise will actually exercise it.

title: West German Freed by Basques, Tells of Captivity
description: BONN, Dec. 25  Eugen Beihl, an honorary West Ger man consul in Spain, was freed today by the Basque separatists who kidnapped him 25 days ago. He arrived in Wiesbaden and told the nation on West German tele vision about his ordeal in the hands of armed, masked men. His release came a day before a verdict is expected in Burgos, Spain, in the courtmartial of 15 Basques on charges of murder and terrorism. Mr. Beihl was ab ducted by a faction of the Basque guerrilla organization, known as ETA, as a hostage for the lives of the 15. Six death sentences have been asked. There was no indica tion that the kidnappers had received any special assur ances about the verdict. Mr. Beihl, 62 years old, looked tired and distraught during his television appearance. He said he was given a signal of his impending release about 7:30 A.M. when a number of armed Basques entered his room at an undisclosed location in northern Spain. He is honor ary consul in San Sebastin, a port city in the south, where he has lived for almost three decades.

title: A Committed Scientist
description: One of the most critical decisions in the race to pro duce the first atomic bomb was, whether to fuel it with uranium or the newly dis covered synthetic element, plutonium. On Dec. 6, 1941, eve of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, three lead ers of the atomic project discussed the problem, in low voices, over a lunch at the Cos mos Club in Washington. They were Dr. Arthur H. Compton, Dr. Van never Bush and Dr. James B. Conant. Dr. Bush and Dr. Conant said the plutonium approach was virtually hope less. The chief problem, after plutonium had been synthe sized by neuton bombard ment of uranium, would be to extract the plutonium from the other materials, all highly radioactive and haz ardous.

title: Romans Hold Polish Protest

title: Screen: 'There Was a Crooked Man ...' and a Myth:Mankiewicz Western Begins Local Run
description: "There Was A Crooked Man . . ." and his name was Paris Pitman Jr. (Kirk Douglas), a charming, red-haired outlaw who didn't hesitate to shoot his best friend in the back to get closer to $500,000. There also was a straight man, named Woodward Lopeman (Henry Fonda), a fine, brave, incorruptible sheriff who had liberal ideas about penology and a civilized distaste for violence.In that legendary time of the West (when it's always 1870), the two men meet at the Territorial Prison, set in the middle of a plain as arid and bleak as a landscape out of Krazy Kat. Lopeman is the warden and Pitman is his prisoner.With all the patience and understanding of a sidewalk salvationist confronting his first live sinner, the warden sets out to rehabilitate Pitman. He works and works and works until, one day . . . . but I'd better not say since that is, after all, the point of "There Was A Crooked Man. . ."The new film, which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East and Trans-Lux West theaters, was written by David Newman and Robert Benton, best known for "Bonnie and Clyde," a movie that combined Americana, melodrama, farce, legend and social satire to make the practically perfect movie for the schizoid '60's. It was directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz, who usually writes his own scriptsurbane, sardonic comedies ("Letters to Three Wives," "All About Eve," "The Honey Pot") that belong to an earlier, more classic period of movie-making.Whatever might be one's expectations of such a collaboration, they may, unfortunately, work against an easy appreciation of the completed movie. Although "There Was A Crooked Man. . . ." is rather low-keyed and takes its own sweet time to reveal itself, it is a movie of the sort of taste, intelligence and somewhat bitter humor I associate with Mr. Mankiewicz who, in real life, is one of America's most sophisticated, least folksy raconteurs, especially of stories about (the old Hollywood."There Was a Crooked Man. . . ." is the veteran movie maker's first Western, but it is somehow illuminated by his awareness of the heritage of old Hollywood, epecially in the roles of Mr. Douglas and Mr. Fonda, who play variations on their mythical movie selves. Mr. Douglas is an outlaw who, for a change, really is as mean as he's supposed to be, and Mr. Fonda is the pure herowith both feet in a clay pit.One of the movie's bothersome idiosyncracies is that it wants to utilize its myths and to work against them. Thus, the film, which begins as broad satire, turns into fairly straight melodrama involving prison riots and such things, before ending on a note of gentle cynicism that is not as dramatically satisfying as it is theoretically intelligent. The mixtures of moods and genres require some patience on our part.It's worth it, I think, for "There Was A Crooked Man . . ." is full of what seem to be (but aren't) the old-fashioned virtues of commercial moviemaking. Mr. Douglas and Mr. Fonda are in splendid shape Hollywood stars performing with the kind of ease and wit that comes with nondebilitating age. Equally at ease are the members of the large supporting cast, including Burgess Meredith, Warren Oates, Martin Gabel, and especially Hume Cronyn and John Randolph, who play a pair of aging confidence men whose long-time homosexual relationship has evolved into crochety, benign despair.Mr. Mankiewicz is not at his best in staging the big, brawling scenes of roughhouse and riot that erupt throughout the film, but that may be simply because they don't seem to fit into the main scheme of the movie. "There Was A Crooked Man . . ." is really a duel between two men, one good, one bad, and it's these smaller, more civilized confrontations, done with irony and wit, that make the film one of the more pleasant things you're likely to see this season.

title: Spirit of Christmas at Bar

John Volpe Jr., the man who usually tends bar at Sar dino's South, was at home with his family. He bad the night off because Mr. Rosen had volunteered to work for him. Mr. Rosen is Jewish and does not observe the holiday, but he offered to work for free for a Christian on Christmas Eve so that Mr. Volpe could have the night off.

title: screen: 'The Lady in the Car With Glasses and Gun':Samantha Eggar Stars in Mystery Story
description: As movie titles go, "The Lady in the Car With Glasses and a Gun" will serve for at least two reasons. First, it tells you several things that are in the movie, one-half of which (lady and gun) are probably dangerous, without, however, presuming to tell you how you should feel about them. And second, it helps render the movie review-proof, for after the critic has mentioned the title a few times he will, if all goes well, have no space left for his review.Anyway, Anatole Litvak's "The Lady in the Car With Glasses and a Gun," based on a novel of the same name by Sebastien Japrisot, opened yesterday at the Festival and Rivoli Theaters. And while it as not as good as it ought to be, given the excellence of its fiction and some of its leading cast, it is nevertheless good enough in mood and in performance to offer more than routine satisfaction to any lover of mystery films.The lady (Samantha Eggar) is an English girl working in a Paris advertising agency. The car is an enormous white American convertible with which her boss (Oliver Reed) entrusts her after she drops off him and his wife (Stephane Audran) at the airport for a business-pleasure trip to Geneva.In the crush of holiday traffic she makes a wrong turnsouth, instead of back to Paris, and when she discovers her mistake she decides to take the car on a brief Mediterranean holiday of her own.It is her dark glasses (on prescription  she is terribly nearsighted) as much as anything else that convinces people along the way that they have seen her before, in the same car, driving north along the same road that very morning. And when her hand is painfully crushed by an unseen stranger in a service station, and the attendant swears that she was wearing a bandage for the sprain hours before, when she stopped for a minor repair, she realizes that she is facing not just disturbing coincidence but very real danger.By the time she finds the gunaccompanying a corpse that turns up in the car's trunk  she is desperate. Along the way she has picked up a young drifter (John McEnery) who may be her salvation or her doom.But there is really nobody she can trust, not even, given the weight of circumstantial evidence, herself. Everything in considerable and quite intimate detail, seems to prove that she has committed murder.Given the possibilities of his plot, Mr. Litvak has emphasized local effect and psychological thrills at the expense of the malevolent logic that is supposed to trap his heroine. Although it is often properly terrifying, one (night-time) meeting between Mr. McEnery and Miss Eggar in an automated garage full of cars and empty of people is especially unsetting. "The Lady in the Car, etc," doesn't always make senseor even those gestures toward sense that will sometimes do if the theme is dark enough.Consequently, in relation to better works in its genre, the film looks rather like an example of the decline of craftsmanship  effective, well-colored, but uncertain in line and construction.Both Stephane Audran (a superb actress in other movies) and the uncomfortably ponderous Oliver Reed contribute to the uncertainty. John McEnery (who, as Mercutio, was the best person in the Zeffirelli "Romeo and Juliet") plays his semi-sympathetic role, however, with the right ambivalent mixture of charm, menace and indifference. Samantha Eggar is so fine that she is in herself sufficient justification for the movie. Beautiful, intelligent and tough enough to be fascinatingly vulnerable, she seems almost to have been type-cast into excellent roles: "The Collector," "The Walking Stick" and now "The Lady in the Car."The last may be her best. She makes of it something wonderfully complex, sustained, varied. She marvelously suggests, in what is really a virtuoso performance, those dim and half-felt areas where mysterious fate and the mysteries of personality touch and merge.

title: 'The Aristocats,' Warm Animated cartoon by Disney, Opens
description: Bless the Walt Disney organization for "The Aristocats," as funny, warm and sweet an animated, cartoon, package as ever gave a movie marquee a Christmas glow. The color feature is a joy andfortunately for everybody, young and young-heartedtheaters are playing it all over the metropolitan area. Talk about cats, manthese aristocats have it.The real beauty of the picture, which is as amusing, smoothly machined and beautifully colored as any Disney should be, is in the characterizations, sustained within a sprightly but simple format. Back in 1962, the brilliant over-stylization of "Gay Purr-ee," from the rival U.P.A. company, for instance, all but rendered it juiceless in the human interest department, cat-people style. Not this round-up.Again, the settings are Paris and the countryside, all in pretty pastels. The plot concerns the "catnapping" of an elegant mama cat and her three kittens by a jealous butler and the victims' adventuresome homeward trek. The original story is credited to Tom Rowe and Tom Mc-Gowan. But in any animated feature, bulging with technical contributors plus director plus producer, it's hard to know who really did what.What matters is that the picture is grand fun all the way, nicely flavored with tunes, and topped with one of the funniest jam sessions ever by a bunch of scraggly Bohemians headed by one Scat Cat. And dig that yellow-cat hippie with the purple glasses and beads, sawing on his cello.But the animal characters with their human nuances are the main dish and delight, ranging from cute to hilarious, thanks to animation wizardry and flavorsome voice-matching by Eva Gabor, Phil Harris, Hermione Baddeley and a battery of others.It would be hard to imagine a more disarming woman in distress than the purry heroine, Duchess, with her toddling Toulouse, Berlioz and Marie, who are protected by O'Malley, a kind-hearted, alley cat Don Juan. Quite a guy, this one. Likewise brave little Roquefort, a pearshaped mouse. Let's also salute Napoleon and Lafayette, two tired Southern-fried hounds who are a riot. The wily butler, his gracious employer and her frisky, ancient lawyer do well enough forwell, human beings.But funniest of all are Agatha and Abigail, two bonnet-wearing, spinster geese  very proper, very giggly and very British"on a walking tour of Frawnce." Wait until you see them walk. And hooray for their Uncle Waldo, a swinging old gander who escapes from a restaurant kitchen, half-crocked and with tail-feathers plucked. Attaboy, hic, Waldo!Thanks for the Christmas cheer, all you aristocats, mice, horses, hounds, web-footers, humansand invisible Disneyites.

title: Let Em Eat Coquilles SaintJacques
description: FINCH COLLEGE, a school that is perhaps best known for hav ing in 1968 graduated Patricia Nixon, the President's daughter, has an image problem that is driving everybody concerned with the place virtually up the wall with rage and frustration. For those who havemaybe never heard of Finch, or think vaguely that it is in Maryland or Virginia, it is a private New York col lege for girls that is elegantly set up in a complex of converted town houses and miscellaneous other struc tures on the Upper East Side of Manhattanspecifically, on East 77th and East 78th Streets between Madi son and Park Avenues. And its crip pling image is more or less this: a snapcourse college for snobbish, dumbbunny rich girls who are too dimwitted to get into places like Barnard, Vassar, Bryn Mawr or Sarah Lawrence.
